3 
 1. Executive Summary 
Rutile (TiO 2) is a physically and chemically robust heavy mineral which inherits a geochemical 
“fingerprint” during formation that may unambiguously characterise its formation environment, 
in particular with respect to origin in a mineralised vs barren host rock. This project utilises the 
combination of these features to assess the viability of using detrital rutile as a new tool for 
mineral exploration, focussing on gold and base metals.  
Through a PhD project funded by this project (see Appendix), we have established and fine-
tuned sample processing protocols to extract rutile grains from rocks, unconsolidated 
sediments and polished thin sections, identify rutile from other TiO 2 polymorphs using EBSD-
SEM techniques, and perform in-situ chemical and isotopic analyses on rutile using LA-ICP-
MS and SHRIMP methods. The in-situ analytical techniques include establishing glass and 
natural rutile standards to produce optimal geochemical data.  
A geochemical database of rutile analyses from known formation environments has been 
established and interrogated. The trace element “fingerprint” of rutile formed in Kalgoorlie-Big 
Bell-type orogenic gold ore systems may be unambiguously distinguished from the chemical 
signature of other gold systems and all other rutile-forming environments. Further, this 
chemical signature appears to survive regolith formation and later overprinting events, except 
for extreme metasomatism, and is preserved in detrital grains derived from weathering-
erosion, transport, deposition and diagenesis. As such, use of detrital rutile in gold exploration 
may be comparable to diamond indicator minerals for diamond exploration, with similar 
transport scales from their source (i.e. >100 km).  
Published literature suggests that rutile from base metal ores may be similarly endowed with 
a distinctive geochemical fingerprint. However, study of a limited number of Western 
Australian examples suggests the validity of this or other geochemical fingerprints unique to 
base metal ores has yet to be confirmed.   
4 
 2.  Introduction 
Indicator mineral geochemistry is widely used in exploration for some commodities, notably 
diamonds. Applications of indicator mineral geochemistry for metals exploration are being 
developed (e.g. Mao et al., 2016), and rutile has shown some initial promise in this area (e.g. 
Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004; Meinhold, 2010) which has not been significantly advanced. 
Rutile has many favourable attributes in its physical and chemical robustness to geological 
processes (e.g. alteration, weathering, transport, deposition, diagenesis), its development of 
a distinctive trace element geochemical “signature” reflective of its formation environment, its 
ability to preserve this geochemical signature through secondary events, and its ability to 
provide both geochronology and geothermometry data in some cases. Accordingly, a research 
project was constructed and funded in 2014 with support from industry, government and the 
Minerals Research Institute of Western Australia (MRIWA).  
The research objectives of this work were to:  
1. Utilise publicly available geochemical data on rutile grains formed in different ore and un-
mineralised environments to build a geochemical database, and to add new geochemical 
data for rutile from Western Australia (WA) ore systems and barren rocks. From this 
database, existing geochemical discriminants of mineralisation will be tested, and by 
virtue of the enhanced capabilities of the modern analytical techniques to be employed, 
new discriminants will be developed for each ore commodity that will shed light on the 
origin of formation of rutile. The project will produce new rutile geochemical data for WA 
ore systems and compare these new data with and contrast it against published data.  
2. Undertake rutile U/Pb geochronology of studied ore systems, together with pilot studies 
to independently determine the mineralisation age of each system. The latter will use 
other relevant and proven minerals/techniques (e.g. 39Ar-40Ar in ore-related sericite; U/Pb 
on other ore-associated minerals), to determine an accurate and precise ore-formation 
age for each ore system.  
3. Research and development (R&D), in parallel with the PhD study and geochronology 
program, to explore and refine technical advances such as (a) automated searching and 
characterisation of rutile grains in polished sections and heavy mineral concentrates by 
TIMA scanning electron microscope; (b) liberation protocols of rutile from rocks using 
selFrag rock fragmentation technology; (c) development of laser ablation inductively 
coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) analytical techniques and mineral 
standards to obtain optimum analytical precision and accuracy for quantitative analysis of 
rutile grains, and (d) further develop SHRIMP procedures for rutile U/Pb geochronology, 
including searching for and characterising new isotopic standards.  
4. Combine geochemical fingerprinting and age data from individual rutile grains to assist 
4D metallogenic reconstructions at the deposit at terrane scales.  
5. To test the exploration potential of combining the improved geochemical fingerprinting 
approaches developed with the age of rutiles from: (i) areas with known mineralisation 
(e.g. Tropicana); and (ii) areas known, or suspected to be, barren of mineralisation. 
6. Develop sample processing protocols to determine the quickest and most cost-effective 
procedures to process rock samples to liberate rutile grains, and apply detrital rutile 
geochemistry/geochronology to aid metals exploration.  
 
The outcomes in respect of the main objectives are given in the Appendix to this report, the 
PhD thesis by Jennifer Porter. Highlights and other project aspects not included in the PhD 
thesis are described below.  
 
3. Sample processing flow chart 
A schematic diagram of the optimum sample processing method developed is shown in Figure 
1. Rutile grains can either be physically separated from their host rock using crushing/rock  
5 
 disaggregation and heavy mineral (HM) separation, or by drilling selected grains from polished 
thin sections.  
In-situ analyses were undertaken first by SHRIMP (sensitive high resolution ion microprobe) 
and then by quadrupole Laser Induction-Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). 
The sequence of SHRIMP analysis followed by LA-ICP-MS was chosen because the sputtered 
pit created by SHRIMP analysis is smaller than the LA-ICP-MS ablation pit, and small grains 
were often essentially destroyed during LA-ICP-MS analysis. For larger grains, the order of 
analysis is less important and was often reversed. In some cases the U contents of the rutile 
grains were too low to acquire meaningful SHRIMP ages, so SHRIMP was not used or used 
sparingly.  
 
 
Figure 1:  Sample processing workflow. 
 
Once heavy mineral grains were separated and mounted in a polished 25 mm diameter epoxy 
mount, TiO 2 grains are identified by SEM (scanning electron microscope) using the Tescan 
TIMA (https://www.tescan.com/en-us/technology/special-solutions/tima-x), and rutile 
distinguished from the polymorphs anatase and brookite using EBSD (electron backscattered 
diffraction) on a Tescan MIRA SEM (https://www.tescan.com/en-us/technology/sem/mira3).  
New procedures were developed to improve the in-situ analytical methods applied. For both 
SHRIMP and LA-ICP-MS, a new natural, single crystal rutile standard (Wodgina) was 
assessed and adopted. LA-ICP-MS chemical data are referenced to both glass and two 
natural mineral standards. For SHRIMP, a new procedure was developed which used an O- 
primary ion beam instead of O 2-. The latter is typically used for the dating of zircons and other 
minerals for U/Pb geochronology. The technical details of these methods are described in the 
Appendix.  
  
4. Identifying the geochemical fingerprint of ore-related rutile 
Background:  We collected a suite of ore samples from many of WA’s orogenic gold deposits, 
two Cu-Au deposits and two base metal deposits, and analysed the trace element 
compositions in rutile present. These data are compared to published chemical discrimination 
diagrams (Figs 2 & 3) for gold and base metal deposits, respectively. 
 
6 
  
Figure 2:  Rutile trace element discrimination diagram for mesothermal gold deposits. Source: Clark & Williams-
Jones, 2004; Meinhold, 2010. 
 
 
Figure 3:  Rutile trace element discrimination diagram for Canadian and other volcanic-hosted massive sulphide 
(VHMS) deposits. Source: Clark & Williams-Jones, 2004. 
 
Figures 2 and 3 utilise trace elements Fe, Cr, V, W and Sn in ternary plots. Our aim was to 
analyse rutile from ~20-30 orogenic gold deposits in WA, together with rutile from available 
Cu-Au and base metal deposits to assess the veracity of these discrimination diagrams and 
to identify other discriminants, if possible. Most rutile is formed by metamorphic processes 
(Meinhold, 2010), so we also sought to compare the compositions of metamorphic and 
igneous rutiles from barren rocks with ore-related rutiles.  
Overall, 164 samples were analysed for 35 trace elements and isotopes producing a database 
of ~206,000 analyses. This database is presented in the form of the PhD thesis of Jennifer 
Porter: see Appendix. Although the initial aim of this project was to develop simple x-y or 
triangular geochemical plots to discriminate rutiles from different origins, as discussed below, 
the geochemical complexity encountered led to the adoption of a more statistical approach 
involving Principal Component Analysis: see Porter et al. (2020).  
 
7 
 Rutile geochemistry applications:  Several key applications assist in the interpretation of the 
geochemical fingerprints captured by rutile when it forms. These are: 
1) The Nb/Cr ratio of rutile has been utilised to differentiate between mafic host rock 
compositions, which tyically have Nb/Cr<1.0, and felsic-pelitic host rocks with 
Nb/Cr>1.0 (Zack et al., 2002; 2004; Triebold et al., 2012). However, there are some 
published examples where this discriminant is unreliable due to differential Nb-Cr 
substitution into other phases (e.g. Zack and Kooijman, 2017). Most of our studies 
described herein support this view. However, during extreme metasomatism this 
relationship appears to break down. Hence, for detrital grains of unknown origin, we 
use this criterion with caution.  
2) In the presence of quartz and zircon, Zr partitioning into rutile is temperature dependent 
and slightly pressure dependent (Zack et al., 2004; Watson et al., 2006; Tomkins et 
al., 2007). Herein we use Zr-in-rutile geothermometry (ZiRGy) of Tomkins et al. (2007) 
in the interpretation of rutile formation conditions.  
3) Interpreting U/Pb geochronology of rutile depends on the blocking temperature for Pb-
diffusion from the rutile crystal structure, which also depends on effective grain size 
and cooling rate. Previous studies have not reached a consensus on this temperature 
and it has variously been determined to be high (i.e. 630-600oC (Cherniak, 2000; Vry 
and Baker, 2006) and as low as ~400oC (Mezger et al., 1989).  The latter has now 
largely been discredited but temperatures as low as 490oC remain possible with fine 
grains and slow cooling: i.e. optimum conditions for diffusional Pb-loss (Kooijman et 
al., 2010).  
 
General geochemical discussion: binary and ternary geochemical plots 
Orogenic gold deposits:  Unless otherwise indicated, ternary plots in the following figures 
have the same parameter at the top (Ti) and lower left (100*(Fe+Cr+V)), and the element 
indicated (*1,000) at the lower right apex, similar to Figures 2 and 3. Different colours 
represent different samples. Figures 4, 5 and 6 shows key elements W, Sb and Sn for  WA 
orogenic gold deposits, Cu-Au ores (Boddington and Telfer) and VHMS ores (Nimbus and 
Bentley), respectively.   
 
Figure 4:  Rutile from orogenic gold deposits: ternary plots (as Fig. 2) with the element indicated (*1,000) as the 
lower left apex. For reference, the blue and green symbols are for Big Bell and Tropicana, respectively. Different 
colours represent different samples. 
 
 
8 
  
Figure 5:  Rutile from Cu-Au ores (Boddington and Telfer): ternary plots (as Fig. 2) with the element indicated 
(*1,000) as the lower left apex. Different colours represent different samples. 
 
 
Figure 6:  Rutile from VHMS ores (Nimbus and Bentley): ternary plots (as Fig. 2 and 3) with the element indicated 
(*1,000) as the lower left apex. Different colours represent different samples. 
 
All three ore types plotted in Figures 4-6 display W-trends that mirror Fig. 2 to a certain extent. 
Cu-Au ores are distinct from the others in their lack of Sb (Fig. 5), whereas VHMS ores 
generally tend to have higher Sn values than gold ores (compare Figs 4, 6). The Sb contents 
in rutile from Bentley are generally low, although one sample has higher Sb contents, similar 
to those observed in some gold deposits.  
Similar plots for rutile from pegmatites (Fig. 7) also show high W-contents, but a distinctive 
lack of Sb and generally higher Sn when compared to gold deposits (Fig. 4). Note that clusters 
represent data from single samples, and generally form “bulls-eyes” of data in pegmatites and 
linear trends in gold deposits (compare Figs 4, 7). Pegmatitic rutiles also have the highest Ta-
Nb-contents (not shown). A combination of Sn-Sb-W and high-Nb can reliably identify rutile 
from pegmatites (Fig. 8). Rutile in lamprophyres and carbonatites (not shown) have scattered 
data but are distinctive with high Sc-contents.  
 
Figure 7:  Rutile from pegmatites: ternary plots (as Fig. 2) with the element indicated (*1,000) as the lower left 
apex. Different colours represent different samples. 
 
 
9 
  
 
Figure 8:  Rutile geochemical discrimination diagrams for pegmatites (green), compared to all other data for rutile 
from ores, lamprophyres and carbonatites. Different colours represent different samples. 
 
Overall, the trace element distributions of rutile in gold ores can be broadly distinguished from 
those in all other formation environments, except for a slight overlap with VHMS ores (e.g. 
compare Figs 4 and 6). However, our data for VHMS rutile only represent two deposits 
(Nimbus and Bentley) and do not conform to the published discriminator shown in Fig. 3. 
Further, only one of eight VHMS samples has the high Sb-contents which are typical of some 
orogenic gold deposits, particularly one sample from Tropicana and Big Bell (Fig. 4), the two 
reference deposits for gold deposits discussed in more detail below.  
Igneous and metamorphic rutile:  Rutiles from barren (non-ore-hosting) systems are shown 
in the same ternary diagrams in Figs 9-10 (i.e. W, Sb and Sn variations against Ti and 
(Fe+Cr+V)). It is important to compare rutile compositions from these barren environments to 
the ore environments depicted above.  
 
10 
  
Figure 9:  Geochemical discrimination diagrams for igneous and metamorphic rutile. Different colours represent 
different samples. Red is data from Wodgina. 
 
Although many igneous-metamorphic samples contain high levels of W, the distinguishing 
features of gold-related rutile are their sometimes higher Sb-contents (compare Figs 4, 9) and 
typically lower Sn-Nb (Fig. 8). Further, the linear trend of data towards the W-apex on the W-
plot at intermediate Ti/100*(Fe+Cr+V) ratio (e.g. Fig. 2 and black ellipse bounding the Big Bell 
and Tropicana data in Fig. 10) is not always seen in the igneous-metamorphic data (e.g. 
Wodgina – red dots – in Fig. 10). However, the Ti/100*(Fe+Cr+V) ratio for a linear trend of 
data towards the W-apex on the W-plot is typically controlled by Cr-content, and is probably a 
host rock feature. In summary, gold-related rutile, as a population, is best discriminated from 
igneous-metamorphic rutiles by: (a) high W+/-Sb, (b) a linear trend of data towards the W-
apex on the Ti-100*(Fe+Cr+V)-1000*W plot, and (c) generally much lower Sn and Nb than 
rutile in pegmatites (Fig. 8).  
 
Figure 10:  Geochemical discrimination diagram (for W) for igneous and metamorphic rutile (from Fig. 9), with the 
field for Big Bell and Tropicana (black ellipse) shown for comparison. Different colours represent different 
samples. 
 
Principal Component Analysis 
The above discussion highlights the complexity of rutile geochemistry. Using a Principal 
Component Analysis (PCA) approach, Porter et al. (2020) and Appendix concluded:  
 
11 
 Clustering all rutile chemistries based on PCA of 12 elements, identiﬁed nine chemically 
distinct groups from ore mineralisation, and barren igneous and metamorphic rocks, primarily 
using variation in W and Cr contents. Two groups are solely derived of rutile from Au ores 
(high versus low Sb rutile). Of the remaining seven groups, one group is comprised mainly of 
rutile from pegmatites (high Nb, Ta, Sn), four groups are comprised solely of rutile from barren 
rocks and two groups are a mix of ore and non-ore rutile. Rutile from Au ore, similar to the 
giant Kalgoorlie and Big Bell Au deposits, is distinctive compared to rutile from all other rocks 
and can be distinguished from other ores and barren environments using multi-element 
clustering of PCA analysis. Thus rutile chemistry of detrital rutile grains is a valuable tool in Au 
exploration. 
Readers are referred to the details in this publication (also presented in the Appendix to this 
report).  
 
5. Projects 
Understanding the veracity of rutile geochemical fingerprints for exploration is considered in 
the following seven projects, which each look at different aspects of the robustness and 
preservation of rutile geochemistry and U/Pb geochronology in a number of different 
geological situations and processes. 
Project 1: 4D gold deposit geochronology: Big Bell, Boddington 
Big Bell:  The reason for a comprehensive geochronology study of one deposit was to assess 
rutile U/Pb geochronology against other dating methods. Big Bell is the most “isotopically 
dated” gold deposit in WA. Together with unpublished data from MRIWA project M0446, the 
available age data are compiled in Fig. 11. This includes U/Pb dating of three rutile samples 
and Ar-Ar dating of one muscovite sample undertaken within MRIWA project M0448.   
 
Figure 11:  Compilation of isotopic ages from the Big Bell gold deposit and environs. Data from this study in red. 
 
In addition, geothermometry data for mineral assemblages associated with the Main Lode ore 
body (Mueller and McNaughton, 2017) and Zr-in-Rutile Geothermometry (ZiRGy) are 
compiled in Fig. 12.  
 
12 
  
Figure 12:  Compilation of geothermometry data from the Big Bell gold deposit. The rutile blocking temperature 
for Pb-diffusion is poorly constrained but for the coarse grains encountered are likely to be at the higher end of 
the range shown. 
 
Big Bell has two different ore types characterised by reduced and oxidised mineral 
assemblages (Mueller et al., 1996), with ages of ~2.66 Ga (U/Pb in garnet by TIMS) and ~2.61 
Ga (U/Pb in hydrothermal zircon by SHRIMP, and titanite by TIMS), respectively (Fig. 11).  
The rutile in the Main Lode yielded ZiRGy temperatures compatible with the peak metamorphic 
temperature (Fig. 12). This indicates that the ore-related, high-W (and Sb) rutiles formed at 
temperatures about that for peak metamorphism, in keeping with field and petrographic 
observations. Two independent rutile samples and one muscovite sample from the older 
“reduced” Main Lode gave the younger age of ~2.61 Ga. The blocking temperature for Ar-
diffusion in coarse muscovite is ~400oC and for Pb-diffusion in rutile is variable, but probably 
in the 480-630oC range. Nonetheless, these temperatures are both below the calculated 
mineralisation temperatures for Main Lode mineralisation, and as such these minerals would 
not be expected to accumulate daughter isotopes while at higher temperature and hence not 
register their formation ages. Instead the ages would record the time when these minerals 
cooled below these blocking temperatures, which in this case corresponds to the zircon and 
titanite formation ages for the younger mineralisation event. The implication is that the rutiles 
and muscovite analysed are recording the uplift or cooling age which corresponds to the 
second “oxidised” mineralisation event. Post-ore pegmatites intruded shortly after.  
Boddington:  Rutile in ore samples from Boddington did not have sufficient U to provide 
reliable ages. However, within the sister MRIWA project (M0446) we used zircon to date the 
older diorite, associated with porphyry-style Cu-Au mineralisation, and the younger 
Wourahming Granite, which intrudes adjacent to the Cu-Au ore body. A compilation of 
available age data (Fig. 13) shows the zircon U/Pb diorite age confirms earlier results, whereas 
the younger granite age is slightly older than a published result, probably because the 
published data for zircon had high U-contents and therefore may have become partly metamict 
and lost Pb, yielding a slightly younger age. Zircon from our sample had lower U-contents 
compared to zircon from the same unit published by Allibone et al. (1996), and provided a 
more coherent data set suggesting a more reliable age. Our Re-Os ages on molybdenite 
replicate previous results (Fig. 13), although the latter were only published in abstract form 
(Stein et al., 2001).  
 
13 
  
Figure 13:  Compilation of geochronology data on the Boddington gold deposit. Data from companion MRIWA 
project M0446 in red. 
 
Project 2: WA gold deposits 
To get rutile from representative examples of WA gold deposits, we accessed the extensive 
collection of samples curated at the UWA Geology Museum, mostly from past research 
student projects. We focussed on samples which had been previously analysed for other 
purposes. For example, Figure 14 shows an SEM image of ore from Kanowna Belle (from 
Vielreicher et al., 2015) which was studied to isotopically date REE-phosphates (monazite and 
xenotime). We accessed the same material to analyse rutile.  
 
Figure 14:  SEM-BSE image of gold-ore from Kanowna Belle (Vielreicher et al., 2015). “mon” is monazite and the 
red circle indicates a TiO 2 grain, confirmed to be rutile by EBSD. 
 
 
14 
 The key W-plot for WA gold deposits was presented in Fig. 4 and reproduced below in Fig. 
15. Compared to the published discrimination diagram (Fig. 2), Big Bell and Tropicana show 
a distinctive linear trend to high W values, whereas most other deposits show greater spread, 
with more variable Ti/[100*(Fe+Cr+V)], including many rutile with very high (Fe+Cr+V). All 
samples with gold-related rutile show some anomalously high W, but some analyses have 
little W, even though they were from ore samples. This suggests that high-W may not be 
ubiquitous in gold-related rutile, or some rutile grains in ore samples may have formed prior to 
gold mineralisation and don’t possess the gold fingerprint of high-W. In the eastern Yilgarn, 
where most samples came from, peak metamorphism typically pre-dates gold mineralisation. 
It remains plausible that pre-existing metamorphic rutile were overprinted by later mineralising 
fluids which produced the gold ores, and two generations of rutile resulted, with dissimilar 
trace element signatures. As both generations have low U-contents, we cannot date them and 
hence distinguish them from each other on the basis of age. Interestingly, most, but not all, of 
the rutile analysed which show scatter in Fig. 15 were <50 micron grains, generally smaller 
than the grain shown in Fig. 14. Larger rutile grains (i.e. >100 microns), such as those from 
Big Bell and Tropicana, tended to show more coherent and linear arrays. 
 
Figure 15:  All rutile data from WA gold deposits (from Fig. 4) with the field for Big Bell (blue) and Tropicana 
(green) data indicated. Different colours represent different samples. 
 
As previously noted, the simple ternary plot approach to identifying gold-ore geochemical 
signatures has limitations. The study by Porter et al. (2020 and Appendix) provides a more 
detailed and robust assessment of WA gold deposits.  
 
Project 3: Tropicana revisited 
Doyle et al. (2015) and references therein described the Tropicana ore bodies as associated 
with shear zones at greenschist facies conditions, hosted by granulites. The host granulites 
were dated at ~2.64 Ga by U/Pb in zircon and monazite, whereas rutile with high W was dated 
at ~2.52 Ga. The rutile age was broadly confirmed by other (less precise) chronometers. 
However, in this study we found the same rutile grains that yielded the ~2.52 Ga age had 
ZiRGy temperatures of ~730-790oC, compatible with granulite temperatures (Fig. 16). These 
temperatures are incompatible with gold mineralisation occurring under greenschist facies 
conditions.  
 
15 
  
Figure 16:  All rutile data from Tropicana (pink) and Big Bell (blue) showing their ZiRGy temperatures of 
formation. 
 
Given that all other gold deposits in the eastern Yilgarn are ~2.64 Ga in their mineralisation 
age, and the published mineralisation age for Tropicana at ~2.52 Ga was the only known 
anomaly to this observation, it is now possible that Tropicana also formed at ~2.64 Ga and 
that the ~2.52 Ga event was an overprint, seemingly associated with shearing under 
greenschist facies metamorphic conditions. The rutile geochemistry appears unaffected by 
this overprint, but the U/Pb age reflects the terrane cooling at this time, to below the rutile 
blocking temperature for Pb-diffusion. Hence, the ~2.52 Ga event and shearing may represent 
a remobilisation of pre-existing gold mineralisation and may have either upgraded or 
downgraded the ~2.64 Ga ore body. A more detailed study of the Tropicana ore bodies would 
be required to assess this further.  
Gold mineralisation at granulite facies conditions is rare (Barnicoat et al., 1991; Qiu et al., 
1997; Blenkinsop et al., 2004) with known deposits at Griffin’s Find (Yilgarn) and Renco 
(Limpopo Belt, Zimbabwe). If the findings herein are verified by future work, Tropicana may 
be added to this list of rare orogenic gold deposits formed at high temperature.  
 
Project 4: Detrital rutiles in WA Basins: assessing gold prospectivity 
To assess the rutile geochemical discriminators of gold deposits, we undertook to take 
advantage of data collected as part of a GSWA-Curtin (John de Laeter Centre - JdLC)-
AuScope-ANDS (Australian National Data Service)  project which quantified the mineralogy 
of heavy mineral concentrates from selected samples from the GSWA geochronology 
program. GSWA had collected a number of sedimentary rock samples from across WA and 
undertaken SHRIMP age analyses on detrital zircon to identify sediment source areas and 
assist the ongoing mapping and geological understanding of the State. The JdLC undertook 
TIMA mineral identification of the heavy mineral concentrates of 200 samples, which included 
clastic sediments. These data are available on-line: 
http://portal.auscope.org/portal/gmap.html.  
Based on samples with the highest rutile abundance, which were consistently from 
sandstones, we assessed rutile in 15 samples from three basinal areas for gold prospectivity. 
The W and Sn ternary plots (cf Figs 2, 3), together with the Sb plot used above for other 
formation environments, for rutile from the three areas are shown in Figs 17-19.  
 
16 
  
Figure 17:  All detrital rutile data from sandstones-metasandstones from the Amadeus Basin. Ternary plots (as 
Fig. 2) with the element indicated (*1,000) as the lower right apex. Different colours represent different samples. 
GSWA sample numbers in legend. 
 
 
Figure 18:  All detrital rutile data from sandstones-quartzites from the Officer and Canning Basins. Ternary plots 
(as Fig. 2) with the element indicated (*1,000) as the lower right apex. Different colours represent different 
samples. GSWA sample numbers in legend. 
 
Figure 19:  All detrital rutile data from sandstones-quartzites from the Aileron Province and Murraba Basin, 
Western Australia. Ternary plots (as Fig. 2) with the element indicated (*1,000) as the lower right apex. Different 
colours represent different samples. GSWA sample numbers in legend. 
 
From these data, all areas show some detrital rutile grains with high W-contents. A detailed 
analysis of the rutile data, using the PCA approach documented by Porter et al. (2020), is 
presented as a chapter in the PhD thesis by Porter (see Appendix).  
From the initial data, it was observed that GSWA sample 184341 from the Arunta shows the 
greatest proportion of high-W data, and a linear array similar to gold-related rutile (compare 
Figs 4 and 19). Accordingly, we undertook further work on this sample to better understand its 
 
17 
 geological history and to assess whether these detrital rutile are indicating an ore body in the 
hinterland source of this quartzite.  
 
GSWA sample 184341: Lake Mackay Quartzite 
Sample:  The sample is a deformed and folded quartzite in the north-central part of the Webb 
1:250,000 map sheet within the Aileron Province of the Arunta Orogen. The quartzite dips at 
60o and exhibits a vertical cleavage. It is interpreted to overlie metamorphosed granites of the 
~1805-1770 Ma Carrington Suite.  
Previous geochronology:  Detrital zircons from 184341 were dated from the Archean (2695 
Ma to a youngest population of 1775+/-7 Ma), which is considered to be the maximum 
depositional age for the precursor sandstone (Kirkland et al., 2009).  
As the sample had been metamorphosed, a literature review suggests the last metamorphic 
event of sufficient grade to form a quartzite was the Chewings Event, reflecting the collision of 
the North and South Australian Cratons at ~1.59-1.57 Ga.  
New geochronology:  We obtained the heavy mineral (HM) concentrate for 184341 from the 
GSWA and assessed it for other datable minerals, including rutile. We subsequently dated 
rutile, monazite and xenotime grains from the HM concentrate: results are shown graphically 
in Fig. 20. The non-zircon age data (Fig. 21) indicates that both monazite and xenotime grains 
in the quartzite, and the three oldest rutile ages, gave a consistent age of ~1.60 Ga. SEM 
observations of the dated phosphate grains indicate these grains were of detrital origin, rather 
than formed during metamorphism. The high U-Th contents in monazite and the U-Th 
discriminator for xenotime support an igneous origin.  
We consider ~1.60 Ga to be the age of the youngest datable detrital grains in the original 
sandstone. This constrains deposition of the sandstone to the interval between the youngest 
detrital population and the assumed metamorphic event: i.e. ~1.60-1.57 Ga.  
 
Figure 20:  SHRIMP age data (histogram and relative probability) for zircon (Kirkland et al., 2009), rutile, 
monazite and xenotime from quartzite sample 184341. 
 
 
18 
 The rutile age data varied from a probable detrital age of ~1.60 Ga to younger results towards 
~1.3 Ga (Fig. 21). Given the blocking temperature for Pb-diffusion from rutile may be as low 
as 480oC, and is significantly lower than for zircon, monazite and xenotime, we consider that 
the variable ages from rutiles reflect a post-depositional heating event which could be ~1.3 Ga 
or younger. No such event has yet been rigorously recognised. Nonetheless, it appears some 
rutile grains preserve the ~1.60 Ga age of other detrital phosphate grains and could either 
have formed at this time or been reset at this time by an event in the source region of the 
rutile. There is no positive link of a common source for the monazite-xenotime grains and the 
rutile: the phosphates appear igneous in origin whereas the rutile could be from various 
sources, all pre-1.59-1.57 Ga. The zircons and at least one monazite grain are clearly from 
different sources (Fig. 20).  
 
 
Figure 21:  SHRIMP age data (histogram and relative probability) for <1.7 Ga rutile, monazite and xenotime from 
quartzite sample 184341. Expanded from Fig. 20. 
 
Rutile geochemistry:  Given evidence presented elsewhere in this report that the 
“compatible” trace element chemistry of rutile is resistant to change by most later geological 
processes, we now assess the various rutile populations which may be represented in sample 
184341. Most significant are the data for the high-W grains. The highest-W analyses (i.e. 
>5,000 ppm W) all have a Nb/Cr ratio that indicates they are from a felsic (or pelitic) rock, and 
have ZiRGy temperatures suggesting formation in the 740-690oC range: i.e. intermediate 
formation temperatures to rutile from Big Bell and Tropicana (Fig. 16), equivalent to high-
amphibolite or transitional granulite temperatures.  
The high-W grains have distinctively low Sb (Fig. 19), which is most similar to rutile from Cu-
Au ores (Fig. 5) and pegmatites (Fig. 7), and also similar to some, but not all, gold ores (Fig. 
4). Some gold ore samples have rutile containing significant Sb, including some from the 
reference ores at Big Bell and Tropicana (Fig. 4). This may be pertinent because the detrital 
rutile grains in 184341 are relatively coarse-grained (i.e. >100 m). The only gold and Cu-Au 
deposits with rutile grains of this size are Big Bell, Tropicana and Telfer.  
Significantly, the detrital high-W rutile grains in 184341 have moderately low Sn contents (Fig. 
19), which are much lower than most pegmatites (Fig. 7) but very similar to Cu-Au ores (Fig. 
 
19 
 5). [However, note that the Cu-Au dataset is limited, with comparative rutile data only from 
Boddington and Telfer]. The high-W grains also fall below the high-Sn pegmatite field in Fig. 
8 with their lower Sn-contents, leaving Telfer rutile as the closest Cu-Au comparative dataset. 
However, gold-only ores sometimes have low-Sb (e.g. Tropicana) and are otherwise 
indistinguishable from the detrital rutile.  
Consideration of other rutile grains with lower, but still anomalous W-contents (i.e. 1,000-5,000 
ppm W) provides the same conclusions: Nb/Cr indicates a felsic host rock and most ZiRGy 
temperatures are in the same 740-690oC temperature range. These rutile grains probably 
came from the same source rock as the >5,000 ppm W grains. Rutile grains with “barren” 
levels of W (i.e. <500 ppm W) are generally from a mixed mafic-felsic source rock (based on 
Nb/Cr) and have the lowest ZiRGy temperatures in the 700-600oC range.  
Overall, we conclude that there are probably detrital rutile grains from multiple source rocks 
which were concentrated by sedimentary processes in sample 184341, and a significant 
proportion of these grains (i.e. ~20%) with >1,000 ppm W are probably sourced from a 
significant Cu-Au deposit, similar to Telfer, or a gold-only ore, similar to Tropicana. However, 
there is some overlap between the geochemistry of the high-W detrital rutile and rutile from 
pegmatites, but this origin can be ruled out on the basis of higher Sn-Nb-Ta.  
 
Conclusions:  This project on detrital rutile grains from sandstones and quartzites, supported 
by a specialised spectrum of available analytical data, demonstrates that:  
1) Heavy mineral concentrates from sediments/sedimentary rocks collected for other 
purposes may provide an untapped resource for metals exploration;  
2) Sandstones are a natural concentrator of detrital rutile grains which appear to faithfully 
preserve their source characteristics for the compatible trace elements; 
3) The Lake Mackay Quartzite was deposited shortly before the Chewings Event, 
between ~1.60 and 1.57 Ga, possibly in a collisional regime;  
4) A ~20% proportion of detrital rutile grains with >1,000 ppm W found in 184341 probably 
derived from a Cu-Au or possibly gold-only deposit exposed to erosion at ~1.60-1.57 
Ga, which was possibly hosted by felsic rocks and formed at high-amphibolite or 
transitional granulite temperatures. The closest Cu-Au analogies are Boddington and 
Telfer, both of which are considered magmatic-related (Roth, 1992; Rowins et al., 
1997), whereas the closest gold-only analogy is Tropicana. Note, however, that only 
Telfer and Tropicana have rutile of sufficient grain size to compare with the high-W 
rutiles in 184341.  
 
Project 5: Rutile “fingerprints”: surviving later alteration/metamorphism 
Rutile grains from the regolith over the Big Bell gold deposit has been shown to preserve the 
chemical fingerprint of the underlying ore (Scott and Radford, 2007). This study was restricted 
to compatible elements in the rutile structure: i.e. not including radiogenic Pb, which is 
incompatible in rutile and can be measured indirectly via U/Pb ages. Herein we assess how 
the compatible elements “survive” other secondary events, such as metasomatism and 
metamorphism.  
Metasomatism:  Examples in which rutile is stable in both a precursor rock and its 
metasomatised equivalent are rare. We were fortunate to identify an example from the Bamble 
area, Norway, through an international colleague. Here, a metagabbro is pervasively albitised 
and the metasomatic front is <1mm wide such that both rock types occur at the scale of a 
single polished thin section (Fig. 22). Intermediate stages of metasomatism are documented 
from the area as various scapolite- and albite-bearing rock types. A more detailed description 
of the following section is presented in the Appendix.  
  
20 
  
Fig. 22. Polished thin section of an albitised metagabbro with the metasomatic front visible (red dashed line) and 
rutile present in both rock types. 
 
The salient rutile trace element geochemistry is presented in Fig. 23. The most striking aspect 
of these data is the large variations in trace element compositions that accompany 
metasomatism. From the Nb/Cr vs V plot, metagabbro and scapolitised metagabbro have 
Nb/Cr ratios more akin to non-mafic rocks. This is attributed to the high proportion of 
hornblende (+/- minor oxides), which is inferred to partition Cr more favourably than Nb. V is 
also lower, probably due to partitioning into oxides. The more metasomatised rocks have 
neither hornblende nor oxides, allowing the rutile to be a more effectively host for Cr and V. 
Ratios of elements with similar geochemical properties (i.e. Nb-Ta and Zr-Hf; Fig. 23) also 
show systematic groupings, suggesting that Nb (in preference to Ta) and Hf (in preference to 
Zr) are preferentially partitioned into the metagabbro minerals.  
 
Fig. 23. Geochemical plots for rutile from metagabbro and metasomatised equivalents from the Bamble area, 
Norway. 
 
Further, the ZiRGy temperatures (Fig. 24) for all rock types are all consistent with the local 
metamorphic conditions of granulite facies, indicating that metasomatism occurred at high 
temperature. Importantly, at these temperatures and metasomatic conditions, there appears 
 
21 
 to be no memory of the metagabbro rutile composition across the narrow metasomatic front 
shown in Fig. 22: i.e. the rutile in the albitite probably grew from the available components 
once the mineralogy changed, totally overprinting or replacing the pre-existing rutile. The U/Pb 
age for rutile in all samples was identical and significantly younger than the rutile formation 
ages in the metagabbro: these are interpreted to record the age of cooling through the Pb-
diffusion “blocking temperature”, rather than the rutile formation ages at higher temperatures.  
 
Fig. 24. Box-plots of formation tempertures using ZiRGy (at estimated 7 Kbars). Legend colours are the same as 
Fig. 23. Dots within boxes are averages, lines are medians, circles and triangles are outliers at 1.5 and 3 times 
the interquartile range, respectively. 
 
Overall, it is clear that extreme and high temperature metasomatism can dramatically influence 
the rutile geochemistry. Importantly, compatible element contents are preserved from their 
formation, whereas incompatible Pb is not. At high tempertures, the compatible trace elements 
in rutile seem to be controlled by partitioning between coexisting mineral phases. In this case, 
the metagabbro rutile shows a Nb/Cr ratio indicative of a mafic rock but is changed to the 
signature of a non-mafic rock during metasomatism. Hence, caution should be used when 
inferring the source rock composition using Nb/Cr in detrital rutile grains.  
 
Metamorphism:  A previous study on a 3.58 Ga leucogabbro enclave in a 3.43 Ga granodiorite 
from the Pilbara identified abundant and coarse rutile, thought to have formed during thermal 
metamorphism when the enclave was incorperated in the granodiorite. U/Pb geochronology 
of the rutile grains showed a spectrum of ages (Fig. 25), with significant peaks at ~2.94 and 
~3.08 Ga. The younger age corresponds to a known magmatic event in the area and both are 
considered to be a response of partial Pb-loss from rutile due to post-formation thermal events.  
 
22 
  
Fig. 25. Age relative probability and histogram for SHRIMP age determinations on rutiles from a 3.58 Ga 
leucogabbro in the Pilbara. The two main peaks in rutile ages are considered to reflect post-formation thermal 
events which affected the rutile in the sample. 
 
The age data are interpreted to reflect partial Pb-loss from rutile in response to later heating. 
Lead is an incompatible element in rutile and the question raised is whether the compatible 
elements have also been affected by the thermal overprints. We undertook to analyse the 
rutile with SHRIMP for age data, and then analyse the same locations in each rutile grain by 
LA-ICP-MS for trace elements. In Fig. 26, the ZiRGy temperature, reflecting Zr-content, is 
plotted against the rutile age. The colour coding is into age groups and is used in subsequent 
plots.  
 
23 
  
Fig. 26. Age vs ZiRGy temperature plot for rutile from the 3.58 Ga Pilbara leucogabbro. Colour coding is for age 
groups. 
 
The ZiRGy temperatures (and Zr ppm) show no systematic variation with age. Other trace 
elements (Fig. 27) are similar in that there is no systematic variation with age, which reflects 
the observed Pb-mobility. In this case, the thermal overprints recorded as partial Pb-loss in 
the rutile age data do not appear to have had any detectable influence on the concentration 
of compatible elements.  
 
Fig. 27. Trace element plots for rutile from the 3.58 Ga Pilbara leucogabbro. Colour coding is for age groups as 
per Fig. 26. 
 
One aspect shown in Fig. 27 is that the Nb/Cr ratio for all analyses is >1.0, notionally indicating 
a non-mafic hostrock. As with the metasomatic example above, the leucogabbro contains 
abundant hornblende and preferential partitioning of Cr into coexisting hornblende is thought 
to increase the Nb/Cr in rutile, making this ratio an unreliable indicator of hostrock composition 
when hornblende is present. This is the same observation as for metagabbro in the example 
of metasomatism.  
Summary:  The available data suggest that the compatible element geochemistry of rutile 
survives regolith formation and thermal overprints, but not extreme metasomatism. A 
subsidary conclusion is that the compatible trace element contents for rutile formed at 
temperatures above ~600oC seem to be controlled by partitioning into coexisting mineral 
phases such that rock discrimination ratios (e.g. Nb/Cr) may become unreliable. Further, the 
 
24 
 incompatible element Pb, formed by U-decay, is lost or partially lost by diffusion during thermal 
overprints, whereas compatible elements are not.  
 
Project 6: Field testing in Yilgarn: detrital rutile in surficial sediments 
The previous reporting has been on establishing and using rutile geochemical discriminators 
for ore-associated rutile, and their chemical robustness against later events. Here we consider 
a practical test. A drillhole through surficial sediments in the Tropicana belt, ~20 kms from a 
known gold prospect, was tested for detrital rutiles and their geochemical fingerprint. The 
drillhole encountered the Archean basement, which had anomalous gold. Samples of surficial 
sediments were taken 7m, 5m and 4m above basement. For each sample, heavy minerals 
were separated, rutile was identified and then analysed for trace elements. The data are 
presented in Figure 28 and compared to data from gold-related rutiles from Tropicana and Big 
Bell. The detrital rutiles from surficial sediments overlap in their W contents but are more 
similar to Tropicana than Big Bell in their Sb contents.   
Considering the data from the three samples from different depths, Figure 29 shows that the 
rutile grains from 7m above basement have low W contents which notionally excludes their 
potential derivation from a gold ore. The rutile data from 4m and 5m above basement both 
contain grains which overlap the Tropicana field with moderately high W.  
Overall, the high-W detrital rutile grains from <5m above basement in the surficial sediments 
are geochemically similar to ore-related rutile from Tropicana. They could, in fact, come from 
the Tropicana ore bodies, or alternatively from unrelated and potentially undiscovered ores. 
Unfortunately, we could not collect detrital material from the basement unconformity, or the 
basement rocks, for comparison.  
 
Fig. 28. Ternary plot (as Fig. 2) comparing data for rutile from surficial sediments and Tropicana and Big Bell for 
reference. 
 
 
25 
  
Fig. 29. Ternary plot (as Fig. 28) showing rutile compositions from the three different samples of surficial 
sediments. Tropicana and Big Bell data shown for reference. 
 
Conclusions:  This pilot project suggests: 
1) Detrital rutile grains from surficial sediments in the eastern Yilgarn environment 
preserve geochemical signatures through weathering-erosion, transport, sediment 
deposition and diagenesis; 
2) The geochemical fingerprint in detrital rutiles from surficial sediments is similar to 
Tropicana and could derive from that or an unrelated (undiscovered) deposit;  
3) Together with the ability of rutile to preserve its source chemical characteristics in 
regolith, this project emphasises the potential utility of detrital rutile as an exploration 
tool, particularly under cover;  
4) If future studies confirm the veracity of detrital rutile geochemistry in gold exploration, 
rutile may be akin to diamond indicator minerals in diamond exploration, with a 
potential “exploration halo” of >100 kms.  
 
Project 7: Rutile in VHMS ores 
At the beginning of this project, it was recognised that there was potential for rutile 
geochemistry to be used for base metal exploration as well as gold: see Fig. 3. To assess this 
on WA deposits, we sought through an independent MRIWA-supported project on VHMS 
deposits, to collect rutile-bearing samples from at least three VHMS deposit in WA for initial 
study herein. Unfortunately, the start of this other project (M0446) was delayed such that rutile 
data were only available for two deposits: Nimbus, near Kalgoorlie, and Bentley, in the 
Teutonic Bore area. The data with the published discrimination diagram from Fig. 3 are shown 
in Fig. 30.  
 
26 
  
Fig. 30. Comparison of rutile compositions from Canadian and other VHMS deposits (from Fig. 3) with rutile from 
Nimbus and Bentley. Different colours for Nimbus and Bentley data represent different samples. 
 
The data for Nimbus is unlike the reference Canadian and global data. This may be because 
Nimbus is considered to be a shallow-water, low temperature deposit with epithermal 
characteristics rather than a classic exhalative VHMS (Hollis et al., 2017). Bentley, on the 
other hand, shows some similarities with a trend to high Sn-contents.  
 
Fig. 31. Ternary plots of rutile compositions from Nimbus and Bentley (as Fig. 30) with the element indicated 
(*1,000) as the lower right apex. Colours from Fig. 30. Different colours represent different samples. 
 
Considering other trace elements (Fig. 31), Bentley shows linear high W and Sb trends similar 
to gold deposits (Fig. 4). However, these trends are largely from one sample and we conclude 
that there is insufficient data to: (a) properly confirm the geochemical discrimination shown in 
Figs 3 and 30, and (b) propose any further discriminants of value to exploration.  
 
27 
  
6. Project summary 
This project has: 
1) Established and fine-tuned sampling and analytical protocols for the characterisation 
and analysis of rutile grains, including establishing appropriate mineral and glass 
standards and analytical techniques.  
2) Identified reliable chemical discriminants for rutile from ore vs barren rocks, particularly 
for gold-related rutile and specifically for Kalgoorlie-Big Bell-type ores.  
3) Established that the compatible elements in rutile are robustly held through 
metamorphic heating and regolith formation, but not extreme metasomatism.  
4) Concluded that detrital rutiles can reliably characterise their source region via their 
compatible element geochemistry, through weathering, erosion, transport and 
deposition, and diagenesis.  
5) Concluded that rutile in metals exploration may be akin to diamond indicator minerals 
in diamond exploration, with sedimentary distribution distances >100 km, and with the 
added advantage that our own and a published study indicates that rutile survives in 
the regolith, making it an untested tool for exploration under cover.  
 
7. Recommendations 
Although this project has improved our understanding of rutile geochemistry and tested many 
aspects of its application to mineral exploration, it is only considered a pilot project: there are 
many practical aspects of this potential technique remain to be clarified. Below is a list of the 
most significant questions, which will require further study to answer. 
1) Grain size:  From this pilot study of gold deposits in WA, gold-related rutile seems to 
occur as either fine (mostly <20 m grains, best observed using an SEM), and coarse 
(i.e. >100 m) grains. The latter have only been observed in a small number of 
deposits, with large grains suitable for analysis found at Tropicana, Big Bell, Telfer and 
Hopes Hill. Although these include significant deposits that are well worth exploring 
for, it is possible that giant gold deposits such as at Kalgoorlie will not be found if 
exploration focuses solely on coarse detrital rutile grains.  
This assumes that our current knowledge about Kalgoorlie is correct and that coarse, 
gold-related rutile is absent from the ore. This assumption should be addressed. 
Furthermore, study could be extended to identifying coarse rutile in other giant gold 
deposits globally.  
One alternative is to direct research towards detrital rutile in the <20 m size range. 
This is practical using current analytical facilities and protocols: i.e. the sample 
processing flow chart in Fig. 1 can be adapted such that 10-20 m rutile grains are 
captured and identified automatically by TIMA. Grains of this size can be reliably 
analysed for trace elements by LA-ICP-MS. However, a pilot study based around 
Kalgoorlie, or a similar, preferably giant deposit with no known gold-related “coarse” 
rutile, should be undertaken to test this concept.  
2) Ore body-scale studies:  The data available from all deposits as been limited to what 
can be obtained from curated material, largely from the GSWA, PhD studies at UWA 
and personal contacts via the Chief Investigators. No deposit has been thoroughly 
assessed for the rutile chemical signatures for proximal vs distal ores vs un-
mineralised wall rocks.  
Using Tropicana as an example, only two ore samples containing rutile were studied: 
one from each of the Havana and Boston Shaker ore bodies. Notably, the chemistries 
of these two rutiles were broadly similar but had some subtle but distinctive differences. 
One sample was obtained from a published study and the other via correspondence  
28 
 through the operating company to mine staff. The latter provided material from several 
different locations in and around several ore bodies but only one sample contained 
suitable rutile, which was subsequently analysed.  
Ideally, exploration for a targeted deposit like Tropicana should start with a detailed 
geochemical study of rutile from different ore bodies and types, low and high grade 
ores, different wall rock compositions and un-mineralised wall rocks, and even regional 
rock types. Assessing these data may provide specific chemical discriminators far 
more sophisticated than that presented in this pilot study. Armed with this knowledge, 
rutile recovered from basal units of surficial sediments, regolith and modern drainage 
samples could provide both vectors to ore and quantify practical transport distances 
for “labelled” rutile grains in the terrane being explored. All of the above will await future 
research.  
3) Global sampling:  The ore-related rutile data collected within this project was confined 
to WA. Extrapolation globally has yet to be undertaken, particularly for detrital rutile 
grains in other non-arid erosion-transport-deposition environments. Further, although 
gold-related rutile data are well represented, further work is needed on Cu-Au and 
VHMS ores, in particular. For example, the proposition that a Cu-Au ore such as Telfer 
or gold ore such as Tropicana contributed rutile to the heavy minerals found in GSWA 
sample 184341 (Project 4) remains tentative, simply because of the limited 
geochemical database for rutiles from this type of deposit. It is clear that a globalised 
study of ore rutiles from many more significant ore bodies is necessary in the future to 
expand the utility of this new exploration tool.  
4) Multi-element attributes of rutile and multi-mineral geochronology:  The study of 
datable detrital minerals in quartzite 184341 has significantly revised the 4D 
understanding of this area, as well as suggesting a potential ore type and mineralised 
host rock in the sandstone hinterland. Together with the information garnered from 
rutile geochemistry, multi-mineral geochronology and petrography on detrital grains 
and integration with the local tectonic and metallogenic history may provide a hitherto 
hidden but exciting new research direction for 4D analysis. Similarly, integration of 
ZiRGy temperatures at Tropicana with the 4D history provide an alternative ore deposit 
model, which should be thoroughly tested.  
In these examples, the integration of rutile geochemical attributes with other, key 
geological data may provide a quantum leap in exploration target definition, and should 
be tested by future research.  
 
8. Acknowledgements 
This study was directly funded by GSWA, Independence Group, MRIWA and Curtin University: 
all are thanked for their direct financial support. The advanced analytical facilities and 
contributions from the technical expertise of staff within the John de Laeter Centre were 
important to the success of this project. The JdLC facilities have been built up over many 
decades with support from Curtin, UWA and GSWA, with significant support from the 
Australian Government through the Australian Research Council, the Strategic Infrastructure 
Initiative, AMMRF and AuScope. Access to samples, including curated, drillcore and field, was 
possible through the UWA Geology Museum, GSWA, Independence Group, AngloGold 
Ashanti, MacPhersons Resources and Boddington Gold Mines. Indirect field support from 
Independence Group, MacPhersons Resources and Boddington Gold Mines is gratefully 
acknowledged.

March 2019DECLARATION OF AUTHORSHIP
I, Jennifer Karin Porter, declare that to the best of my knowledge and belief
that this thesis entitled, ‘Application of Rutile Geochemistry to Base and Precious
Metal Exploration’ contains no material previously published by any other per-
son except where due acknowledgement has been made. This thesis contains
no material which has been accepted for the award of any other degree or
diploma in any university.
The author acknowledges that copyright of published works contained within
this thesis resides with the copyright holder(s) of those works. I warrant that
I have obtained, where necessary, permission from the copyright owners to
use any third-party copyright material reproduced in the thesis (e.g. question-
naires, artwork, unpublished letters), or to use any of my own published work
(e.g. journal articles) in which the copyright is held by another party (e.g. pub-
lisher, co-author).
Jennifer Karin Porter
20/03/2019
Date
iiiABSTRACT
The need to assess new exploration techniques in order to ﬁnd undercover
mineralisation has become more necessary as easy to ﬁnd and more accessible
ores are depleted and advances in technology drive the need for more metal
resources. Pathﬁnder minerals, those with chemistries that are associated with
speciﬁc ore types, have been used in areas where ore is covered or easily
weathered. These minerals are of greater abundance and are more durable
during weathering and transport than their associated ores. Pathﬁnder min-
erals are found in detrital sediments and are easily identiﬁed in the heavy
mineral separates collected during exploration campaigns. Pyrope garnet and
chrome diopside are examples commonly used in diamond exploration, and
here rutile is assessed as a pathﬁnder mineral applicable to precious and base
metal exploration.
Trace elements in rutile can be associated with certain ore types; i.e., Sn can
be associated with VHMS deposits and W, associated with Au ore. However,
these elemental anomalies are not unique and an elemental pattern that can
ﬁngerprint any one ore type has not been identiﬁed. To better assess ore as-
sociations with trace elements in rutile, a multivariate approach to statistical
analysis was used to compare trace element patterns with different ore types.
A database of 3149 rutile analyses (LA-ICP-MS and SHRIMP) from a variety of
ore types and non-ore-related igneous and metamorphic rocks, primarily from
Western Australia, has been created to address this issue.
Multivariate PCA (principal component analysis) and hierarchical cluster-
ing of high ﬁeld strength elements within rutile were used to distinguish trace
element signatures of different ore types (Au, Au-Cu, pegmatites, carbonatites,
vAbstract J.K. P ORTER
lamprophyres, VHMS) and their associated rocks. Sb and Cr were determined
to be most important in differentiating Au deposits from pegmatites enriched
in Nb, Ta and Sn, and from other ore types. In rutile from barren rocks, W
and Fe were the most important elements in differentiating rock types, which
were distinguished based on a combination of metamorphic grade and source
rock characteristics. Nine groups were identiﬁed when all rutile from ores and
barren rocks were clustered together, using primarily the variation in W and
Cr. Two groups are solely derived from Au ores (high versus low Sb rutile).
One group is comprised mainly of pegmatites (high Nb, Ta, Sn rutile). Four
groups are comprised solely of rutile from barren rocks, and two groups are
a mix of ore and non-ore rutile. Rutile from Au ore, similar to Kalgoorlie and
Big Bell Au deposits, is distinct compared to rutile from other rocks and can be
distinguished from other ores and barren environments using multi-element
clustering of PCA analysis, making rutile chemistry a valuable tool in Au ex-
ploration.
Detrital rutile from the basins of Western Australia were compared to and
classiﬁed as one of nine rutile groups using the supervised machine learning
algorithm, Random Forests, in order to assess rutile’s potential in Au and base
metal targeting. Rutile grains were classiﬁed into Au-related and barren rock
groups with a >95% accuracy. Sample 199418 of the Amadeus Basin repre-
sents the highest potential for Au exploration, as 9% of rutile grains have trace
element chemistries similar to those from Kalgoorlie- and Big Bell-style Au ore.
In addition to identifying rutile grains associated with mineralisation, charac-
teristics of basin source rocks; i.e., number of basin sources, their formation
temperatures and ages, and their metamorphic history may be determined us-
ing Random Forests for class prediction.
In addition to the pathﬁnder study, the trace element discriminants for ru-
viJ.K. P ORTER Abstract
tile rock source conditions were evaluated to critically assess Nb-Cr system-
atics, Zr-in-rutile thermometry and U-Pb dating in a case study of rocks in
the Bamble Sector of southern Norway that have undergone multiple stages
of metamorphism and metasomatism. The geochemical and isotopic signa-
tures in rutile occurring across metasomatic contacts between scapolite and
albite rocks were compared with those of rutile from less metasomatised gab-
bros. Zr-in-rutile geothermometry indicated that rutile formed at temperatures
above 760 °C, at granulite-facies conditions. Rutile grains from all rock types
have statistically identical U–Pb ages (1079.3 ±4.0 Ma), which reﬂects the time
that rutile cooled through the Pb closure temperature. Metasomatism affected
rutile prior to this time, constraining the timing of scapolite metasomatism at
granulite-facies temperatures prior to 1079 Ma.
Rutile Cr and V contents increased with progressive scapolite metasoma-
tism and remained unchanged during subsequent albitisation. The rutile Nb–
Cr ratio was affected by extreme metasomatism to indicate a more maﬁc source,
despite all rocks having the same gabbroic source. This has implications for us-
ing Nb–Cr signatures in detrital rutile provenance studies. Trace element data,
combined with textural relationships, suggest rutile is relict within albitite and
that albite metasomatism occurred after scapolitisation during the Sveconor-
wegian Orogeny, or possibly as late as the Permian, during low-grade meta-
morphism associated with the Oslo Rift.

ern Australia (MRIWA) M448 grant with contributions from Independence
Group and the Geological Survey of Western Australia. The SHRIMP II anal-
yses were carried out with the ﬁnancial support of the Australian Research
Council and AuScope NCRIS. GeoHistory Facility instruments were funded
via an Australian Geophysical Observing System grant provided to AuScope
Pty Ltd. by the AQ44 Australian Education Investment Fund program.

ity in the John de Laeter Centre. Kelly Merigot provided extensive help us-
ing the TIMA, and Elaine Miller and Zakaria Quadir aided in using the SEM
and EBSD. J. Reeve at the E. de C. Clarke Earth Science Museum at UWA
is acknowledged for providing access to UWA thesis and sample collections.
Muriel Erambert provided assistance on the EMP at the University of Oslo.

and ﬁxing the SHRIMP , especially after midnight.

tirement.

This thesis compiles a collection of research papers that were either pub-
lished, under review, submitted or in preparation at the time of writing this
document. The relationship between different papers are described in the
introductory chapter. All papers have statement of co-authorships and pub-
lished papers are reprinted in Appendix A at the end of the thesis.
The research papers contained within this thesis are listed below.
