xxxCHAPTER 1
INTRODUCTION
Humans have been exploiting metals in the Earth for thousands of years and
the development of human civilisation has depended on the ability to ﬁnd and
extract these metals in an efﬁcient and proﬁtable way. Society’s need for met-
als has not subsided with time, but rather has become more fervent with the
advancement of modern technologies. Unfortunately, the continual extraction
of metals over thousands of years has depleted the obvious and most surﬁcial
ore deposits and has forced the development of new technologies and innova-
tive techniques in order to discover ores further undercover and in harder to
detect locations.
In order for deposits of metal to be considered proﬁtable, metals have to
be present in concentrations considerably above average crustal levels. For
example Pb, Au and Cu have to be concentrated at 5000, 2000 and 250 times
crustal levels, respectively, in order to be extracted at a proﬁt. Common ore ac-
cessory minerals are often used as a vectoring tool to aid exploration targeting
for these metal enrichments. For example, pyrope garnet and Cr-diopside are2 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.1
common accessory minerals in diamondiferous kimberlites and are often used
as pathﬁnder or indicator minerals in diamond exploration.
To aid metallic ore exploration, a potential indicator mineral must be phys-
ically robust enough to withstand weathering, transport and deposition in
sediments. It must form within the same environments as ore and carry a
chemical signature that can ﬁngerprint that ore. Ideally the indicator min-
eral will be abundant and of sufﬁcient size not only to identify and collect,
but to analyse using low cost and efﬁcient techniques. Fortuitously, rutile
fulﬁls these requirements, as described in more detail below, and possesses
many chemical traits that make it useful for studying detrital sediment his-
tory. Trace elements incorporated in the structure of rutile can provide insight
into rock provenance, formation temperature, age and ore association, which
provides a more comprehensive understanding of the history of the rock in
which rutile formed. Here, the chemical properties of rutile are assessed to
determine if it can be used as an indicator of ore, and to assess its robustness
as a geochronometer and geothermometer.
1.1. R EVIEW
1.1.1. T RACE ELEMENTS IN RUTILE
Rutile forms in a variety of environments including igneous, and more com-
monly in metamorphic and hydrothermal environments, including under con-
ditions that form precious and base metal mineralisation. Generally reported
as stable at high temperatures and pressures, rutile is also found at lower
greenschist facies conditions ( <450 °C) (Meinhold, 2010; Putnis, 1978). Ru-Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 3
tile can be found in association with mineralised deposits, in ore zones and
alteration zones, frequently in greater abundance than the ore minerals them-
selves (Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004). The concurrent formation of rutile
during ore deposition allows it to place temporal constraints and composi-
tional ﬁngerprints on ore-forming processes. Rutile grains incorporate trace
elements that are reﬂective of the formation environment, including wall rock
and ﬂuid chemistries. Rutile has a dense, chemically and physically stable
structure that is resistant to weathering and capable of surviving transport,
lengthy residence times in regolith, diagenesis and low-grade metamorphism.
Rutile is a common constituent of sediments and detrital rocks, such as sand-
stones and quartzites.
Rutile, anatase and brookite are the three common polymorphs of TiO 2.
Both anatase and rutile are found in mineralised occurrences and heavy min-
eral deposits. Anatase formed during diagenesis, is stable at lower P–T con-
ditions and reverts irreversibly to rutile at >600–700 °C (Hanaor and Sor-
rell, 2011). Distinguishing rutile from other polymorphs is important in that
anatase and brookite are not typically associated with ore processes and in-
corporate different elements within their structures (Triebold et al., 2011). RA-
MAN spectroscopy and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) can be applied
to samples to discriminate the polymorphs of TiO 2. In addition, inter-element
ratios of Cr, V , Fe and Nb can correctly identify rutile with an accuracy of >97%
(Triebold et al., 2012, 2011).
Rutile is a useful mineral in that it incorporates a variety of trace elements
that can be used to elucidate information on a rock’s history. Uranium is taken
into rutile at the exclusion of Pb and Th, allowing for precise U–Pb age dating.
The blocking temperature of Pb in rutile ( 630 °C, Cherniak, 2000; Vry and
Baker, 2006) is lower than that of other minerals typically used in U–Pb dat-4 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.1
ing, such as zircon and monazite, thus can date metamorphic, hydrothermal
and formation events that occur under different conditions, and can provide
insights on cooling rates and terrane evolution. An important development
is the advent of rutile in U–Pb dating using in situ SHRIMP and LA-ICP-MS
analyses. Luvizotto et al. (2009a) and Zack et al. (2011) have improved these
techniques by developing matrix-matched natural rutile standards, improving
the precision of measured ages, although matrix effects and lack of sufﬁcient
natural standards, particularly for trace element analysis, still remain issues to
be improved. Rutile includes up to 200 ppm U in its lattice and excludes Pb,
due to differences in ionic charge and radius. An advantage to using rutile in
U–Pb dating is the exclusion of Th in its structure, allowing for a more robust
correction for common Pb using the208Pb correction. This increases precision
as208Pb is 30 to 40 times more abundant than204Pb, so corrections are more
accurately determined.
Trace element geochemistry can be used in provenance studies and geother-
mometry. The relative abundance of Cr and Nb has been used to distinguish
between pelitic and maﬁc rock sources (Zack et al., 2002, 2004b; Triebold et al.,
2012). Generally, a rutile that exhibits a Nb/Cr >1 is considered to be from a
pelitic source, with more felsic input. Rutile with higher Cr and Nb/Cr ratios
<1 is representative of a mantle or maﬁc source.
If rutile is in equilibrium with quartz and zircon, the amount of Zr substi-
tuted into its lattice is a function of temperature (Zack et al., 2004a). Increased
incorporation of Zr with temperature has led to the development of a Zr-in-
rutile thermometer, useful in rocks such as quartzite and sandstone, which are
devoid of minerals typically used in geothermometry. The calibration of Zr as
a geothermometer in rutile has been determined empirically (Zack et al., 2004a)
and experimentally (Watson et al., 2006; Ferry and Watson, 2007; Tomkins et al.,Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 5
2007). The geothermometer developed by Tomkins et al. (2007) was veriﬁed as
reliable at ultra high pressures by Kooijman et al. (2012) and further certiﬁed
by Triebold et al. (2012) as the most robust tool, as it takes pressure into account
in determining T and has an uncertainty of ±35 °C.
1.1.2. R UTILE IN ORES
Certain trace elements within rutile have been identiﬁed as having anoma-
lous concentrations when associated with speciﬁc ore types. For example,
Clark and Williams-Jones (2004) determined W is enriched in rutile formed
in mesothermal Au deposits and other researchers have identiﬁed that vari-
able amounts of V and Sb in rutile are also associated with Au ore (Scott and
Radford, 2007; Plavsa et al., 2018; Agangi et al., 2019). Previous studies (see for
example Williams and Cesbron, 1977; Scott, 1988; Clark and Williams-Jones,
2004; Scott, 2005; Rabbia et al., 2009) have assessed the relationships between
ore and trace elements in rutile and demonstrated the potential of rutile to act
as an indicator mineral. Research determined that multiple trace elements (W,
Sn, Sb, Ni, Cu, Cr, Ta, Nb, V and/or Pb) in rutile can be correlated to spe-
ciﬁc metallic mineralisation. A table summarising some of the known trace
element and ore type associations is presented in Table 1.1. A more in-depth
description of the trace element associations in rutile formed with Au, VHMS,
carbonatite, kimberlite and eclogite, Cu-Mo porphyry and pegmatite ores is
presented below.
MESOTHERMAL AU DEPOSITS W-rich rutile has been identiﬁed at the Tropi-
cana Gold deposit in the Albany-Fraser region of Western Australia. Two gen-
erations of rutile were identiﬁed based on age and trace element signature: a6 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.1
TABLE 1.1: A compilation of rutile data highlighting the main anomalous
elements associated with speciﬁc deposit types. Compiled from Clark and
Williams-Jones (2004); Scott (1988, 2005); Scott and Radford (2007) and Hag-
gerty (1995).
younger zone within rutile contained little W enrichment while an older zone
contained approximately 6000 ppm W (Doyle et al., 2015).
The Big Bell Au complex, Western Australia, has multiple ore zones that
contain rutile variably rich in V , W, Sb and Fe. Regional variation shows a
complex trace element make-up between deposits and across alteration (Scott
and Radford, 2007). Graham and Morris (1973) studied W- and Sb-rich rutile
in Big Bell that contains up to 5.8 wt% WO 3, 1.7 wt% Sb 2O5and 1.7 wt% FeO
and noted that the rutile compositions were similar across different host rocks,
suggesting a common origin. However, at Fender, an ore zone of the Big Bell
complex that is less deformed, rutile is enriched in Fe and Nb, and low in V
and Sb. In all Au-bearing zones in the Golden Giant and Page-Williams ore
bodies of the Big Bell complex, rutile contains high V , (5.6% V 2O5), Sb (6.5%
Sb2O3) and W (3.2% WO 2) (Harris, 1989). Sb and W anomalies are obvious
within rutile hosted in the ore, but not in rutile within the alteration zones.
Conversely, rutile found at the periphery of these deposits, contains high Nb
and Ta contents, possibly delineating the extent of mineralisation (Scott and
Radford, 2007).Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 7
Scott et al. (2011) studied the Kalgoorlie Goldﬁelds, Western Australia, in-
cluding the closely associated brittle Mt Charlotte and the ductile Golden Mile
(Fimiston) deposits. Rutile was identiﬁed in the lode, altered and unaltered
zones of the Fimiston deposit. Mt Charlotte has Fe-rich rutile that is depleted
in other trace elements, whereas Golden Mile rutile is W- and Fe-rich. Lake
View Lode, also part of the Kalgoorlie Superpit, contains rutile consistently
high in V (1.48 wt%). Rutile from these three deposits at Kalgoorlie can be
distinguished using these trace element contents.
VOLCANIC -HOSTED MASSIVE SULPHIDES (VHMS) The study by Clark and
Williams-Jones (2004) summarised the trace element contents of several VHMS
deposits in the Superior Province of eastern Canada (Ansil, Bell-Allard, Garon
Lake, Kidd Creek, Langlois, Norita, Radiore). The summary suggests that high
Sn contents in rutile point towards a VHMS source, although most Sn-enriched
rutile were also enriched in Nb. Studies by Petersen (1986) at the Geco Sn
VHMS deposit in Ontario support this assertion. Rutile associated with cassi-
terite from this deposit contains 2.9 wt% SnO 2and 3.99 wt% Nb 2O5.
Rutile was identiﬁed within the deposit and alteration zones of Gossan Hill
(Sharpe and Gemmell, 2002; Smith, 2003), Golden Grove (Frater, 1983; Wang
et al., 1993) and Scuddles VHMS deposits (Ashley et al., 1988) but no system-
atic studies of the trace element signatures in rutile were conducted.
CARBONATITES Niobium has been identiﬁed as a major trace element in rutile
of carbonatites (Mitchell, 2015; Chebotarev et al., 2017). Nb-rutile has been re-
ported as a primary accessory mineral in the Chuktukon carbonatite in Russia
(Chebotarev et al., 2017) and the Oka carbonatite in Qu ´ebec (Mitchell, 2015),
but also as a minor secondary hydrothermal mineral after pyrochlore and rip-8 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.1
pite (Chebotarev et al., 2017). These hydrothermal rutile grains are up to 17
wt% Nb 2O5(Chebotarev et al., 2017). Mitchell (2015) also reports that sec-
ondary rutile can contain up to 9 wt% Nb 2O5at the Arax `a supergene Nb de-
posit, formed through hydrothermal or deuteric processes.
Weathered rutile grains sourced from carbonatites are found to contain less
V , Fe, and Nb than primary and hydrothermal rutile (Chebotarev et al., 2017).
Nb-brookite and Nb-anatase are also observed at the Arax `a deposit in Brazil
and brookite observed at Chuktukon, Russia likely formed by sub-aerial weath-
ering (Mitchell, 2015; Chebotarev et al., 2017).
KIMBERLITES AND ECLOGITES Rutile has been found within kimberlites and
eclogites associated with diamonds; not as a primary mineral, but likely formed
after ilmenite. Rutile grains frequently contain lamellae of ilmenite within
their structure (Smythe et al., 2008). Malkovets et al. (2016) have identiﬁed
Cr-bearing rutile as one of the indicator minerals of kimberlite, along with Cr-
pyrope and Cr-diopside at the Mir kimberlite pipe in Russia. They suggest that
rutile with Cr 2O3in excess of 1.7 wt% indicates rutile sourced from the man-
tle. Smythe et al. (2008) studied kimberlite-derived rutile to develop a possible
discriminant to determine a crustal vs mantle source discriminator and sug-
gested rutile from eclogite contains more Al than mantle-derived kimberlitic
rutile. Rutile with at least 1000 ppm Mg is interpreted to be sourced from the
mantle (Smythe et al., 2008). The high Al content in diamondiferous eclogitic
rutile was also observed by Sobolev and Yeﬁmova (2000), along with high Cr,
Fe and Nb.
CU-MO-PORPHYRIES Trace elements contents in rutile found in porphyry de-
posits are as varied as the deposit types in which they are found. Rabbia et al.Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 9
(2009) showed the dominant trace element within rutile associated with a Mo-
porphyry is Mo, which is also enriched in rutile found within the wallrock, not
associated directly with the ore. The changes in rutile Mo content on the de-
posit scale at El Teniente, Chile, is due to the temperature dependence on the
stability of molybdenite and availability of Mo during rutile formation (Rabbia
et al., 2009).
Rutile at the Ajo, Bingham, San Manuel and Bagdad, USA, Cu-porphyry
deposits also exhibit heterogeneity on the deposit scale and in their alteration
zones. Rutile increases in abundance and grain size ( <40 µm) within alteration
zones and is enriched in Fe and V (Czamanske et al., 1981). Williams and
Cesbron (1977) also noted heterogeneities within Cu porphyries and found a
positive correlation between the red colour in rutile grains and Cu content,
which varies from 100 to 500 ppm. Chromium and V content in rutile also
increased closer to the ore zone and rutile grains became increasingly elongate
away from the ore zone (Williams and Cesbron, 1977).
Scott (2005) studied the Cu-Au porphyry in North Parkes, Australia and
noted V contents >4000 ppm. Niobium was also enriched ( >1500 ppm), but
not consistently. The ore related rutile grains were also larger and exhibited
stronger compositional zoning.
PEGMATITES AND GRANITES Rutile from pegmatites is typically high in Nb,
Ta, and Fe, and is commonly associated with ferrocolumbite and/or columbite-
tantalite (Cern ´y et al., 1999; Klementov ´a and Rieder, 2004). Cern ´y et al. (1999)
observed that up to 40% of Ti in rutile from pegmatites in Colorado can be
substituted by other cations, especially Nb and Ta. The Minnie Creek shear
zone-related Mo prospect in Western Australia contains up to 17 wt% com-
bined Nb and Ta (Plavsa et al., 2018).10 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.1
Tin deposits from Sn granites in southeastern Australia contain rutile with
up to 26% Nb 2O5, and high Ta, Sn and W (Scott, 1988). Additionally, W-Sn
granites of Regoufe, Portugal are enriched in Nb ( ≤3.56 wt%), Fe ( ≤10.24 wt%)
and Ta (1.32 wt%; van Gaans et al., 1995). Columbite-tantalite is also present
and associated with rutile in these deposits.
One of the only recorded deposits that is not Au-related, but contains high
Sb-rutile is a quartzite in St. Marcel-Praborna, Italy (Smith and Perseil, 1997).
Rutile is associated with basal sediments of an ophiolite sequence, cut by veins
and fractures along which elements were mobilised. Rutile contains up to
33.75 wt% Sb and 15.45 wt% Fe, which is close to the chemical content of
squawcreekite (FeSbO 4).
1.1.3. R UTILE IN EXPLORATION
Evident in the discussion above is that no one element, or seemingly any com-
bination of elements, is unique to a speciﬁc ore environment or rock type. In
order for rutile to be useful as a pathﬁnder to ore, a distinct pattern, or ﬁnger-
print, of elements should be identiﬁed that can uniquely identify a speciﬁc ore
type.
Clark and Williams-Jones (2004) attempted to develop a way to easily iden-
tify trace element patterns in mesothermal Au and VHMS deposits. They de-
veloped a ternary diagram that uses the Ti, 100*(Fe+Cr+V) and 1000*W con-
tents at triangle apexes to highlight W anomalies in the ore and alteration
zones of Au deposits (Figure 1.1). A similar ternary diagram was developed
for VHMS deposits using Sn instead of W as the anomalous element (Fig-
ure 1.1). In this study, these diagrams are used for comparison and are assessed
for utility in metal exploration using a variety of elements and ore types.Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 11
FIGURE 1.1: Rutile compositions from the Langlois, Qu ´ebec Zn-Cu deposit
showing Sn and W anomalies in the ore (red squares) and sub-ore zones (yel-
low diamonds). Barren wallrock rutile (blue triangles) show no anomalous
Sn and W concentrations. Dashed lines represent the lower detection limits
for WO3and SnO2using the EMP (electron microprobe). From Clark and
Williams-Jones (2004).
In addition to trace elements, U–Pb dating can be useful to metals explo-
ration by establishing a temporal context to mineralisation. Rutile has been
used to date Au deposits in Western Australia. Gold-related rutile from the
Tropicana Au occurrence in the eastern Yilgarn was dated using the SHRIMP
(Doyle et al., 2015). The sub-grain analyses showed heterogeneity within grains,
both geochemically and isotopically. Regions of high W concentration exhib-
ited a statistically older age (2521 ±5 Ma) than regions of low W ( 2450 Ma)
(Figure 1.2). These in situ analyses give unique age information on Au min-
eralisation at Tropicana and may be applied to other areas in order to resolve
growth events associated with different metallic mineralisation stages. The
data on Tropicana also permitted the Au mineralisation to be placed in tem-
poral context with other Au ore bodies in the Yilgarn; i.e., the Kalgoorlie Au
province of the eastern Yilgarn is older by over 100 Ma (Vielreicher et al., 2015).
This shows the importance of independent dating of ore when using rutile in
exploration as geochronology can indicate whether the source is located within
a speciﬁc mineralised terrane.12 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.2
FIGURE 1.2: Age frequency plot for rutile grains at Tropicana Au indicating
high- and low-W populations. Modiﬁed from Doyle et al. (2015).
1.2. R ESEARCH DESIGN
The purpose of this project was to assess the minor and trace element geo-
chemistry and isotopic signatures within rutile and develop a database that
can form the foundation of a tool for precious and base metal exploration in
Western Australia. Speciﬁc objectives were as follows:
To reﬁne analytical and processing protocols for laser ablation inductively
coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) and sensitive high-resolution
ion microprobe (SHRIMP) in order to create an efﬁcient method of character-
ising the trace element patterns of single grains and sub-grains. The LA-ICP-
MS technique surpasses previous EMP studies involving rutile geochemistry
ﬁngerprinting in their lower level of detection and ability to probe different
areas within the rutile grain, allowing analysis of how the chemistry of grains
changed during growth and multiple growth histories.Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 13
Rutile chemistry from a variety of well characterised background samples is
undertaken to determine if speciﬁc patterns of elemental anomalies can iden-
tify rock types (e.g., dolerite, syenite, granite) and source terranes. Rutile
chemistry from a variety of mineral deposit types are assessed to qualify and
quantify trace element signatures associated with each deposit type so that
a unique geochemical signature can be established for speciﬁc mineralisation
types.
Detrital rutile from sedimentary rocks characterised by the GSWA (Geolog-
ical Survey of Western Australia) are assessed for anomalous trace element
chemistry in order to identify any potential mineralisation signatures.
An algorithm for data processing and statistical analyses is developed in
order to accommodate the large amount of geochemical data generated, im-
prove processing times and reduce costs, with eventual mineral exploration
applications in mind.
Where possible, U–Pb geochronology is used to determine the ages of min-
eralisation associated with trace element anomalies in rutile so that a temporal
component can be added to the database and any anomalies can be associated
with speciﬁc events (i.e., known mineralised provinces or collision/orogenic
events).
The database of rutile trace element chemistry is applied to detrital rutile
and used to determine provenance, establishing the environment of formation
and potential of associated metallic mineralisation. This knowledge can aid
in exploration by delineating speciﬁc targets. The signiﬁcant outcomes of the
research will be:
development of new, efﬁcient exploration techniques with regard to data14 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.2
collection and sorting
providing an exploration tool for ore deposits in bedrock-barren and
under-explored terrain
establishing a database of correlated geochemical and geochronological
signatures in order to enhance our understanding of the 4D metallogeny
of Western Australia
potential discovery of new types of deposits and/or mineralised events
previously unknown in Western Australia
1.2.1. M ETHODS
The following section outlines what was done in order to meet the objectives
of the project. One of the objectives was to develop an efﬁcient process to
identify, prepare, analyse and assess rutile for ore prospectivity. The follow-
ing outlines the workﬂow followed fro any given sample, from collection of
material, through processing, analysis and database creation (Figure 1.3).
Rutile samples were collected both from background and mineralised loca-
tions. The GSWA heavy minerals collection was selectively sampled for rep-
resentative rutile from background or barren rock types and terranes in West-
ern Australia. Mineralised samples came from various mineral deposit types,
such as VHMS, Au, carbonatite and pegmatite ores. These samples came from
known collections at museums, universities and other individual collabora-
tors. In addition, samples containing rutile were taken within VHMS ore de-
posits in the Yilgarn of Western Australia.
Samples from ore were made into polished thin sections to preserve textu-Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 15
FIGURE 1.3: Work ﬂow plan made on rutile sample processing from sample
selection to database processing.
ral references, and samples from igneous and metamorphic rocks were made
into epoxy grain mounts at the John de Laeter Centre at Curtin University in
Perth. Textural analysis of rutile thin sections was performed, where possible,
to determine growth relationships and identify if analysed rutile was directly
related to, or was of the same generation as the ore.
Preliminary analysis was performed to assess if any thin section or epoxy
mount contained rutile grains that were of sufﬁcient size and quantity to anal-
yse for trace elements or isotopes. The TIMA (Tescan integrated mineral anal-
yser), a ﬁeld emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) with four EDS (en-
ergy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy) analysers was used to quickly identify
TiO2grains, to scanning up to 25 epoxy mounts in one setting, using a typical
step size of 3 m (Ward et al., 2018). The TIMA software can be used to deter-
mine how many TiO 2grains exist in the sample, their size and abundance and
when analysing thin sections, their mineralogical and textural associations.
Samples of interest were then analysed using the EBSD (electron backscatter16 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.2
diffraction) in order to determine which TiO 2polymorphs are present within
the sample. Crystallographic mapping can be done using EBSD whereby crys-
tal structures are indexed by matching diffraction patterns produced by elec-
trons when they interact with a crystal lattice with those of known crystals
(Humphreys, 2001; Schwartz et al., 2009). In this way the polymorphs of TiO 2,
rutile, brookite and anatase, are identiﬁed. As brookite and anatase form in dif-
ferent environments to rutile, and retain different trace elements within their
structures (Triebold et al., 2011), they are eliminated from further analysis.
SEM and EBSD analyses can identify sub-grain boundaries and foreign min-
erals and within rutile grains, which can improve targeting for later LA-ICP-
MS and SHRIMP analyses. The SEM with BSE (backscatter electron) imaging
was used to further characterise grain textures, compositions and to document
grain images before and after trace element analyses using more destructive
techniques.
LA-ICP-MS is a destructive technique that measures the trace element con-
tent of solid materials. A 193 nm laser beam is used to remove a small vol-
ume of material that is ionised in a high-temperature plasma and separated
on the basis of mass/charge and counted on a detector. The trace geochem-
istry of 34 elements were measured using laser spot sizes between 15 and 50
m. Here, isotopic intensities are measured using an Agilent 7700s quadrupole
ICP-MS, with high purity Ar as the plasma gas. These are compared to the iso-
topic intensities in known silicate glass standards (international glasses TiG;
Jochum et al., 2010; BCR-2G and BHVO; Jochum et al., 2007); and natural ru-
tile standards R10 (Luvizotto et al., 2009a) and Wodgina, WA, characterised
for trace elements (Ewing, 2011). Blocks of standards are run in blocks after
20 unknown analyses. Elemental concentrations are calculated using47Ti as
the internal standard isotope, and to correct for instrument drift and monitorChapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 17
accuracy and precision. A Ti content of 59.95% in rutile is assumed. The mass
spectra are reduced using the Trace Element data reduction scheme in Iolite 3.5
(Paton et al., 2011).
The SHRIMP (Sensitive High-Resolution Ion Microprobe) uses an ion beam
that is focused on a mineral target in order to sputter particles that can be used
in U–Pb dating. The sputtered ions are focussed into a secondary beam and are
separated on charge and mass by passing them through a magnetic ﬁeld with
a large turning radius. The SHRIMP is primarily used here for high precision
U-Pb dating of rutile. An O-beam was used in order to minimise orientation
effects as described in Taylor et al. (2012). Natural rutile grains with multiple
orientations from the Windmill Hill Quartzite (207Pb/206Pb age 2633 ±1.1 Ma,
assessed in house) are used as a standard, with a 20 m spot size. SHRIMP
data are reduced and analysed using Squid and Isoplot 3.75 (Ludwig, 2001).
208Pb can be used for the common Pb correction in rutile, as the Th content in
rutile is low ( <1 ppm). This is the preferred correction method, as208Pb is 30–
40 times more abundant than204Pb, which produces a more precise correction.
Trace element data collected for rutile were compiled into a database. Anoma-
lously high or low trace element analyses, usually caused by contaminating
minerals being intersected during ablation, were eliminated and null values
are imputed. All elements were normalised so that no one element dominated
the variation of the dataset. Log ratio transformation was used to minimise the
problem of closure, a potential problem when analysing multivariate composi-
tional data (Aitchison, 1986; Grunsky, 2010). PCA (principal component anal-
ysis) was performed after centred log-ratio transformation to identify natural
chemical similarities within multi-variate chemical datasets. PCA reduces the
dimensionality, ﬁlters the noise, random patterns and/or under-sampled pro-
cesses of a multivariate system and simpliﬁes and highlights major processes18 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.3
usually using the ﬁrst few principal components (Grunsky, 2010; Grunsky and
Kjarsgaard, 2015).
After PCA, hierarchical clustering, a form of unsupervised machine learn-
ing, was applied to the dataset to identify chemically similar groups. The sim-
ilarity of chemistry in rutile may be explained by a common origin; i.e, they
formed at similar metamorphic grade, their host rocks were compositionally
similar or they formed under the same mineralisation processes. Once groups
of chemically similar rutile were identiﬁed, trace element data of rutile from
unknown sources were compared using a supervised machine learning algo-
rithm, Random Forests (Breiman, 2001). Random Forests makes predictions
on the classiﬁcation of rutile using the votes of individual trees, each of which
classify the rutile using a different subset of variables at varying distances
down the tree. Combining their votes reduces the variance of the Random
Forest model, improves its robustness with respect to noise and over-training,
and gives estimates on internal error and variable importance.
1.3. R ESEARCH OUTCOMES
The results of this study are presented in three papers, each brieﬂy summarised
below.
1.3.1. C HAPTER 2 - C LASSIFYING RUTILE FROM KNOWN SOURCES
Chapter 2 amalgamates a rutile geochemical dataset from ore deposits, and
igneous and metamorphic rocks of Western Australia. The datasets are as-
sessed for utility in distinguishing different ore types from each other, as wellChapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 19
as distinguishing ore rutile chemistries from non-ore chemistries. This paper
incorporates rutile chemistries from known ore deposits, sourced primarily
from university and museum collections, and from barren rocks of Western
Australia, sourced from the geochronology collection of the Geological Survey
of Western Australia. Hierarchical clustering of the results of principal compo-
nent analysis of 12 high ﬁeld strength elements in rutile produced nine distinct
groups representing rutile source rocks. Clustering of rutile chemistries from
various ores, igneous and metamorphic rock sources can uniquely identify the
chemistry of rutile from Au ore, especially Kalgoorlie- and Big Bell-style Au
deposits. The variation in W, Cr and Sb contents are key in identifying rutile
from different source rocks and ore and identifying rutile from rocks formed
at different temperature, metamorphic grade and how evolved the host rocks
may be.
1.3.2. C HAPTER 3 - C LASSIFYING RUTILE OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN
Chapter 3 uses the results of Chapter 2 by using the geochemical groupings of
rutile that identify ore and non-ore rocks and comparing them to the chemistries
of detrital rutile. The metal prospectivity of several sedimentary basins of
Western Australia was assessed by comparing trace element chemistry of ru-
tile grains of unknown source using the supervised machine learning algo-
rithm Random Forests . Rutile are clustered into one of the nine groups from
Chapter 2 with >95% accuracy. Basins were identiﬁed with grains associ-
ated with Kalgoorlie- and Big Bell-style Au, including a sample (199418) in the
Amadeus Basin that consists of rutile in which 9% of the grains cluster with
Au ore. This represents the most prospective sample with regard to Au ex-
ploration. Samples within the Amadeus Basin (199408, 199414, 143783) and20 J.K. P ORTER Section 1.3
Albany-Fraser Orogen (194874) were identiﬁed with grains that are similar to
Nb-pegmatites. The clustering of Nb-pegmatites with other non-ore related
rocks lessens the certainty that these samples are derived from ore, but they
still represent the most prospective samples for Nb-pegmatites. Classifying de-
trital rutile in siliciclastic sandstones and quartzites can elucidate information
such as how many rock sources contribute to the sample and their thermals
and compositional histories. Consistency in rutile trace element chemistry and
geothermometry can also show whether the rutile formed after deposition and
thermal history of the basin.
1.3.3. C HAPTER 4 - T ESTING TRACE ELEMENT AND ISOTOPIC DISCRIMI -
NANTS IN RUTILE
Chapter 4 provides a case study in which the changes in rutile trace element
and isotopic chemistries during extreme metasomatism are assessed on a small
scale. Rutile grains were analysed using LA-ICP-MS and SHRIMP across two
metasomatic fronts of rocks of the same gabbroic source. Textural evidence
suggest the metagabbro underwent scapolitisation then albitisation. U–Pb dat-
ing of rutile in the metagabbro, scapolite fels and albitite reveals the same
(1079 Ma), suggesting these rutile grains were not formed together, but cooled
through the Pb closure temperature at this time. Zr-in-rutile thermometry in-
dicates all rutile formed above 760 °C, but that the rutile in the scapolite and
albitite otherwise have different trace element chemistries. This indicates that
the metasomatism which altered the chemistry of the rutile occurred at gran-
ulite temperatures prior to 1079 Ma. Rutile grains from the heavily metasoma-
tised rocks indicate a more maﬁc provenance than their precursor metagab-
bro, revealing a weakness in using the Nb/Cr ratio as a provenance indica-Chapter 1 J.K. P ORTER 21
tor. Albitisation after scapolitisation did not alter the trace element or isotopic
chemistries further, suggesting it occurred either contemporaneously with scapo-
lite metasomatism or later at below greenschist-facies conditions. This paper
has been prepared for publication in Chemical Geology .

PAPER 1-RUTILE AS A PATHFINDER FOR
METALS EXPLORATION
Jennifer Karin Portera;b, Neal J. McNaughtona, Noreen J. Evansa, Bradley J.
McDonalda
aJohn de Laeter Centre, Curtin University, Bentley, WA, 6102, Australia
bSchool of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Curtin University, Bentley, WA, 6102, Aus-
tralia50 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.1
ABSTRACT
The use of detrital rutile as an indicator of mineralisation is contingent on the identiﬁ-
cation of trace element signatures that uniquely distinguish rutile grains derived from
mineralisation from those sourced from barren rocks. In order to discriminate rutile
sources, principal component analysis was applied to a total of 3149 LA-ICP-MS anal-
yses of rutile from ore environments (Au, Au-Cu, pegmatites, carbonatites, lampro-
phyres, VHMS) and barren igneous and metamorphic rocks. Hierarchical clustering
of the results of principal component analysis (PCA) determined Sb and Cr exhibit the
most chemical variation in ore-derived rutile. Rutile sourced from Au deposits and
enriched in Sb, can be distinguished from rutile from pegmatites, which are enriched
in Nb, Ta and Sn. Discriminating rutile from barren rocks can be done primarily using
W and Fe contents, which can also provide insight on source rocks based on metamor-
phic grade and degree of crustal input.
Clustering all rutile chemistries based on PCA of 12 elements, identiﬁed nine chem-
ically distinct groups from ore mineralisation, and barren igneous and metamorphic
rocks, primarily using variation in W and Cr contents. Two groups are solely derived
of rutile from Au ores (high versus low Sb rutile). Of the remaining seven groups, one
group is comprised mainly of rutile from pegmatites (high Nb, Ta, Sn), four groups are
comprised solely of rutile from barren rocks and two groups are a mix of ore and non-
ore rutile. Rutile from Au ore, similar to the giant Kalgoorlie and Big Bell Au deposits,
is distinctive compared to rutile from all other rocks and can be distinguished from
other ores and barren environments using multi-element clustering of PCA analysis.
Thus rutile chemistry of detrital rutile grains is a valuable tool in Au exploration.Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 51
2.1. I NTRODUCTION
Rutile, the high temperature TiO 2polymorph, is a common accessory mineral in meta-
morphic and hydrothermally-altered rocks associated with ore mineralisation and it
forms in highly oxidised environments (Dachille et al., 1968; Smith et al., 2009; Hanaor
and Sorrell, 2011). Trace elements incorporated in the rutile structure are primarily
high ﬁeld strength elements (HFSEs) that are similar in ionic size to Ti4+(0.6 ˚A) and
have a high oxidation state (+3 to +6). Therefore, HFSEs are the key trace elements
used to characterise the history of rutile. U-Pb dating of metal-enriched rutile from an
ore paragenesis can be used to determine the age of ore formation, while geochemical
studies of rutile and associated ore minerals can help to identify source and parental
ﬂuid features (Luvizotto et al., 2009a; Meinhold, 2010; Zack et al., 2011).
Incorporation of Zr in rutile is temperature-dependent and has been applied to de-
termining formation temperature (Watson et al., 2006; Ferry and Watson, 2007; Zack
et al., 2004a; Tomkins et al., 2007) and the thermal history of rock packages (Kooijman
et al., 2012; Meyer et al., 2011; Hart et al., 2018). Niobium and Cr in rutile have been
used as indicators of rock source (e.g., felsic vs maﬁc; Meinhold et al., 2008; Zack et al.,
2004b; Triebold et al., 2007; Luvizotto et al., 2009b). Rutile, like zircon, is a refractory
mineral that survives long distance transport and is physically and chemically sta-
ble during weathering (Meinhold, 2010; Morton and Hallsworth, 1994). Furthermore,
detrital rutile is stable within regolith for an extended period of time, retaining its
original chemical signature (Scott and Radford, 2007; Salama et al., 2018). These char-
acteristics can be exploited by developing detrital rutile chemical analysis as an ore
indicator tool for application in mineral exploration within terrains of limited bedrock
exposure.
Previous research has shown that rutile with elevated W, Sn, Sb, Ni, Cu, Cr, Ta,
Nb, V and Pb contents has been linked to known mineralisation events (Scott, 1988;
Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004; Mueller et al., 2012; Urban et al., 1992; Scott and Rad-52 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.1
ford, 2007; Meinhold, 2010; see also Table 2.1). Thus, rutile formed within ore systems
incorporates certain trace elements speciﬁc to the environment of formation, thereby
making it possible to identify rutile from different ore deposit types based on trace
element content. However, these studies show the identiﬁcation of anomalous trace
elements within rutile is not always unique to ore type (Table 2.1). For example, rutile
enriched in Cu may be derived from porphyry, IOCG and PGE ores (Williams and Ces-
bron, 1977; Czamanske et al., 1981; Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004; Scott, 2005; Rabbia
et al., 2009) and W has been identiﬁed as an anomaly in skarns, pegmatites, Au and
VHMS deposits. The non-uniqueness in trace elements contents in rutile highlights
the need for a more robust discriminator.
TABLE 2.1: Summary of trace element enrichments found in rutile from dif-
ferent ore types.

et al. (2008); Malkovets et al. (2016)
Carbonatite Nb, Ta W, Sn, V , Fe Chuktukon, Oka Chebotarev et al. (2017); Mitchell (2015)
To determine if there is a systematic incorporation of certain trace elements into
rutile of speciﬁc ore types, a study was conducted by Clark and Williams-Jones (2004)
on rutile from VHMS and orogenic Au deposits. They compiled electron microprobe
(EMP) compositional data from deposits around the world, and primarily from the
Canadian Shield. For orogenic Au deposits, a ternary diagram was developed whereby
Ti, 100*(Fe+Cr+V) and 1000*W abundances (Figure 2.1) were plotted to highlight ru-
tile with anomalous W contents. Rutile from ore zones and sub-ore zones had elevatedChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 53
W contents, plotting within the dashed area of Figure 2.1. Analyses of WO 3in rutile
from wallrock typically fell below the detection limit of the EMP . A similar ternary
diagram was developed for VHMS deposits using Sn instead of W in the lower right
apex of the diagram.
FIGURE 2.1: Ternary diagram of W content in rutile from ore zones and sub-
ore zones of Au deposits as analysed with electron microprobe (EMP), mod-
iﬁed from Clark and Williams-Jones (2004). Rutile from unaltered wallrock
plots in the stippled zone below the detection limit for WO 3on an EMP .
Beyond this study, there has been little detailed investigation on the incorporation
of trace elements in rutile in different ore deposits or ore types, or quantiﬁcation of
the differences in rutile chemistry within alteration zones, wallrock and ore zones of
the same deposit. Furthermore, it is not known if trace elements are incorporated
into rutile in unique compositional patterns speciﬁc to certain ore systems or whether
similar trace elements patterns are seen in rutile from barren rocks, or rocks not known
to be associated with ore systems. If a consistent pattern related to the detection and
relative enrichment of these elements can be identiﬁed, they can act as tracers for the
formation conditions and types of mineralisation (Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004).54 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.1
2.1.1. R UTILE AS AN ORE PATHFINDER
Rutile is present in many metallic ore deposits, in both the ore and in alteration zones,
often surpassing the ore minerals in frequency and abundance, but still carrying trace
elements that can identify the ore forming conditions under which they formed. Iden-
tifying this rutile away from the ore minerals, either in situ and distal to mineralisa-
tion, or as a post-weathering heavy mineral separate can be key to exploration in areas
of cover.
Although reported as stable at high temperatures and pressures, rutile also forms
at lower greenschist facies conditions (Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004). Generally at
temperatures <420 °C, anatase and possibly brookite, becomes the more stable poly-
morph of TiO 2(Dachille et al., 1968; Smith et al., 2009; Hanaor and Sorrell, 2011). The
phase of TiO 2should be established before trace element assessment can be considered
robust (Triebold et al., 2011; Plavsa et al., 2018). Rutile, anatase and brookite have dif-
ferent crystallographic dimensions and incorporate trace elements differently within
their structure at different formation conditions, therefore the chemistry of anatase
and brookite cannot be used in the same way as that of rutile. Anatase that has formed
from the breakdown of previously formed rutile may, however, retain the trace ele-
ments that were originally incorporated when the rutile formed (Triebold et al., 2011).
The polymorph phase may be determined through electron backscattered diffraction
(EBSD) analysis, Raman spectroscopy or, with lower certainty, by applying the Cr, V ,
Fe and Nb contents in rutile to a linear discriminant analysis algorithm developed by
Triebold et al. (2011).
In order for rutile to be useful to mineral exploration, it has to have a distinct chem-
ical signature related to an ore type and retain that signature through weathering, and
potentially lengthy sediment transport and deposition. Sands and siliciclastic detrital
deposits can naturally concentrate detrital rutile grains and can be targeted as a sam-
pling media for exploration for metallic ores located upstream. Salama et al. (2018)Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 55
identiﬁed rutile concentrated in silcrete duricrust, one of the few resistant minerals
to survive intense weathering as a cap to the Scuddles and Golden Grove VHMS de-
posits. Rutile has kept its characteristic trace element chemistry in the regolith around
the Big Bell Au deposit and in saprolite and soils around porphyry-derived minerali-
sation (Scott, 2005; Scott and Radford, 2007).
This study tested the use of HFSEs as ore discriminants, and ore indicator elements
were correlated with those in rutile from known metallic occurrences and associations
with known mineralisation events. In situ laser ablation inductively coupled plasma
mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) analysis was performed to detect trace elements at
lower limits than other methods; (e.g., EMP) and to allow for thousands of multi-
element analyses to be conducted in a short timeframe. Information on rutile trace el-
ement chemistry was obtained both from known mineralisation and from barren rocks
in order to test for similarities in HFSE chemistry and verify if and/or how anoma-
lous HFSE enrichments can identify ore-derived rutile. This has expanded the ability
to construct statistically signiﬁcant datasets that can be applied to metals exploration.
2.2. M ETHODS
2.2.1. S AMPLE SELECTION
Two main groups of rocks were identiﬁed for rutile sampling: those related to ores
and ore systems, and those from barren or background igneous and metamorphic
rocks. In order to identify elements that are unique to speciﬁc ore systems, rutile was
sourced from as many different ore types as possible in Western Australia including
from known Au, Au-Cu, lamprophyre, carbonatite, pegmatite and VHMS deposits.
Ore-related samples were selected primarily from the University of Western Aus-
tralia’s (UWA’s) museum archives (http://www.earthmuseum.see.uwa.edu.au) and56 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.2
former PhD theses (see references in Tables 2.2 and 2.3). Samples were identiﬁed and
located either as polished thin sections already made from previous research, or as
hand samples curated in the UWA Geology Museum, having already been identiﬁed
as containing rutile. Existing grain mounts containing rutile from known Au deposits
in the Yilgarn, WA (Figure 2.2), were also provided by previous researchers, and explo-
ration and mining companies (see Tables 2.2 and 2.3). A total of 70 different samples
from 28 known ore deposits were collected. A map showing the location of analysed
samples from WA is presented in Figure 2.2 and a summary of their sources and re-
spective references are presented in Tables 2.2 and 2.3.
FIGURE 2.2: General geological map of Western Australia indicating the lo-
cation of studied deposits, their respective ore types and GSWA samples for
background igneous-metamorphic rocks.Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 57
In addition to individual samples, systematic sampling was undertaken at the Lake
View Lode and Golden Pike Lode Au veins by Bartram (1969). Rutile-bearing samples
were taken at consistent intervals away from the mineralised veins in order to char-
acterise rutile chemistry with increasing distance from the ore zone and into different
alteration zones (Table 2.2).
New samples taken for this study come from the Bentley and Nimbus VHMS de-
posits, and the Boddington Au-Cu deposit. At Nimbus, sampling near the massive
ore was not possible due to drill core degradation, so samples were taken close to
the stringer zones and in the dacite wallrock within the deposits (Barrote et al., 2019).
Four samples from Bentley VHMS contained rutile of sufﬁcient size to analyse (e.g., ≥
15m), two samples from the stringer zone and two samples from the disseminated
massive sulphides of the upper ore body (Table 2.3). Four rutile-bearing samples were
identiﬁed in Boddington Au-Cu deposit: two from the mineralisation, one from the
actinolite zone and one from the diorite host rock that is not associated directly with
mineralisation (Table 2.3).
Background and/or barren samples were sourced from the GSWA geochronology
collection (www.dmp.wa.gov.au). Rutile was searched using the TIMA database of
mineral assemblages from heavy mineral separates and their associated zircon frac-
tions (http://portal.auscope.org). Of these, 31 samples were identiﬁed as having ru-
tile large enough and in sufﬁcient quantity to analyse. These data were supplemented
by museum samples, standards and rutile sourced from collaborators outside Aus-
tralia. A complete list of samples from background igneous and metamorphic rocks,
their location and reference is presented in Table 2.4. Although these rutile samples
were collected as background examples away from mineralisation, a few were col-
lected from drillholes made in association with exploration projects. These samples
may carry or be affected by nearby mineralisation or associated alteration. These sam-
ples are identiﬁed in Table 2.4. There is a bias in the barren rock dataset toward rutile
from more felsic or fractionated rocks as rutile is not common in unaltered maﬁc vol-58 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.2
canics, which are more likely to contain ilmenite as their primary Ti-bearing mineral.
Rocks higher in Ca and Si contents, such as calcsilicates, can have titanite as the pri-
mary Ti-bearing mineral. Thus examples of rutile from these rock types are excluded
from this study due to this natural sampling bias. Further complexities related to
sampling are explained in Appendix C.

from clustering the combined datasets (Group C, see Section 2.3.3). Numbers in brackets represent a group
attributed to a minority of analyses within a sample. Sph = sphalerite, feet = ’.

2.2.2. I MAGING
Rutile from ore rocks were made into polished thin sections for in situ analysis, pre-
serving textural relationships between the rutile, ore rock and mineralisation. Barren
samples of igneous and metamorphic origin were made into 25 mm diameter epoxy
grain mounts from heavy mineral separates in order to increase the rutile percentage
within the grain population. The Tescan Mira3 TIMA with four PulsTor SDD X-ray
detectors at the John de Laeter Centre (JdLC), Curtin University, Perth, Australia was
utilised in order to quickly identify mineralogical phases in both epoxy mounts and
polished thin sections. The four different EDX X-ray detectors, in combination with
a YAG scintillator back-scatter electron (BSE) detector, allowed the TIMA to quickly
identify small or rare grains of TiO 2(Figure 2.3A) (Ward et al., 2018). This is impor-
tant for exploration as it replaces more traditional time consuming and less reliable
techniques, such as optical microscopy.
FIGURE 2.3: A. An example of a TIMA phase map of part of a thin section
from the Boddington deposit, Actinolite Zone (Sample AC2). B. An EBSD
image of a heavy mineral separate, detrital grain mount set in epoxy, with
Zr overlay used to distinguish rutile (yellow) from zircon (light green) and
anatase (red). Also shown is quartz (blue), grey grains have not been indexed
and black is the surrounding epoxy.
BSE and EBSD imaging was carried out to assess phase, size and textural relation-
ships, and to identify targets for LA-ICP-MS analysis. Further imaging of rutile grains62 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.2
was done using the scanning electron microscope (SEM) in the Microscopy and Mi-
croanalysis Facility at the JdLC, Curtin University, with the Tescan Mira3 VP-FESEM
with Oxford Instruments X-Max 150 SDD X-ray detector, NordlysNano EBSD detector
and processed using AZtec software.
Further preparation for EBSD analysis included polishing samples for approxi-
mately four hours using 0.1 m colloidal silica in NaOH solution. The ﬁne polish was
required to produce clear diffraction patterns for structural identiﬁcation between the
different polymorph types (rutile, anatase, brookite), as well as to identify the pres-
ence of subgrain boundaries within individual grains. A thin carbon coat (10 nm) was
applied and a 20 kV acceleration voltage was used at a working distance of 20 mm.
A step size of between 3 and 10 m was used depending on sample size. Diffraction
patterns were compared to a catalogue of known minerals and indexed to the mineral
with the lowest mean angular deviation (MAD), typically <1° (Humphreys, 2001;
Schwartz et al., 2009). Noise reduction for single pixel spikes was performed using
Channel 5 software.
To determine polymorph phase, overlays of EDS compositional maps plus EBSD
images were created to ensure any minerals with identical diffraction patterns, such
as zircon and rutile, were not misidentiﬁed (Figure 2.3B).
2.2.3. LA-ICP-MS
LA-ICP-MS rutile trace element analyses were completed at the GeoHistory Facility
in the JdLC, Curtin University, Perth, Australia. Individual rutile grains were ablated
using a Resonetics RESOlution M-50A-LR, incorporating a Compex 102 excimer laser.
The sample cell was ﬂushed with ultra-high purity He (350 mL min-1) and N2(3.8
mL min-1). Isotopic intensities were measured using an Agilent 7700s quadrupole
ICP-MS, with high purity Ar as the plasma gas (ﬂow rate 1 L min-1).
International glasses TiG (Jochum et al., 2010), BCR-2G and BHVO (Jochum et al.,Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 63
2007); and natural rutile standards R10 (Luvizotto et al., 2009a) and Wodgina, WA,
characterised for trace elements (Ewing, 2011) were used as the primary and sec-
ondary standards to calculate elemental concentrations using47Ti as the internal stan-
dard isotope, and to correct for instrument drift and monitor accuracy and precision.
A Ti content of 59.95% in rutile was assumed. Standard blocks were typically run after
20 unknown analyses.
Two cleaning pulses preceded a 30 s period of baseline count acquisition and 40 s
ablations at a 4 Hz repetition rate using a 50, 33, 22 or 15 m beam and laser energy
of 2 Jcm-2. Thirty-four isotopes were monitored for 0.01 s each. The time-resolved
mass spectra were reduced using the Trace Element data reduction scheme in Iolite 3.5
(Paton et al., 2011, and references therein). During the time-resolved analysis, con-
tamination from inclusions was monitored and the inclusion-free part of the signal
was integrated.
Analyses from ore-derived rutile were collected for 70 different samples for a total
of 1074 laser spots. Fifty-two different igneous-metamorphic samples were analysed
for 2075 laser spots. Thirty-four isotopes (24Mg,27Al,28Si,29Si,32S,43Ca,44Ca,45Sc,
47Ti,49Ti,51V ,52Cr,57Fe,60Ni,63Cu,66Zn,89Y,90Zr,93Nb,95Mo,118Sn120Sn,121Sb,178Hf,
181Ta,182W,202Hg,204Pb,206Pb,207Pb,208Pb,209Bi,232Th,238U) were analysed over 23
sessions.
The trace element results for primary and secondary standards indicated that for
the 50 and 33 m spots, accuracy and analytical precision was better than 5% for most
elements. For the 23 m spot size, accuracy was better than 5% for most elements, but
precision decreased to <10%, except for Mo and Sb which were <20%. For the 15
m, precision was <10% for V , Zr, Nb, Ta, W and Cr and <20% for Sn, Sb, and U.64 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.2
2.2.4. S TATISTICAL METHODS
In order to perform multivariate statistical analysis, the null points, or values below
the detection limit for a given element, were removed and replaced either with a num-
ber equal to half the detection limit, or when this value was not calculated, by a value
generated by imputation on nearest neighbours. The k-nearest neighbour method
developed by Hron et al. (2010) and found in the R-Package robCompositions (Templ
et al., 2009) was utilised. In total, 866 missing values were imputed out of 30,072 com-
positional points ( <2% of analyses). Elements with over 40% imputed values were
eliminated from further analysis (e.g., Bi). The data were scaled and centred for each
trace element whereby the content of each analysis was subtracted from the mean of
the total for each element. This equalised all trace element compositions to ensure
those with naturally higher contents (e.g., Fe and W) did not dominate the chemical
variation of the total dataset, and all elements were equally weighted (Grunsky and
Kjarsgaard, 2016).
The trace element chemistry of rutile is reﬂective of the processes that formed the
mineral, including ﬂuid composition and wallrock chemistry, but is also reﬂective of
the stoichiometry and structure of the mineral itself. These processes and stoichiomet-
ric control can be independent, but also entirely or partially correlated (Grunsky and
Kjarsgaard, 2016), and therefore can impose structure on composition; i.e., with cou-
pled substitution to maintain charge. Closure, the natural correlation of elements that
are adopted into a mineral structure in an organised stoichiometric pattern, causes a
natural linear correlation for some elements. For example, elements occupying one
particular site within a crystallographic lattice will total 100% to satisfy the chemi-
cal formula. When analysing multivariate compositional data, in order to identify
elements introduced by geologic processes rather than by structural control, log ra-
tio transformation was used to overcome this problem (Pearce, 1968; Aitchison, 1986,
1999; Egozcue et al., 2003; Grunsky, 2010).Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 65
Principal component analysis (PCA), a process of reducing the dimensionality of
multivariate compositional data was applied to the dataset after centred logratio trans-
formation using the R package robCompositions (Templ et al., 2011). PCA ﬁlters the
noise, random patterns and/or under-sampled processes of a multivariate system and
simpliﬁes and highlights the major processes usually using the ﬁrst few principal com-
ponents (Grunsky, 2010; Grunsky and Kjarsgaard, 2016). The procedure used in this
study to critically assess large geochemical datasets using robust statistical analysis
including PCA was primarily derived from Grunsky (2010) and Grunsky and Kjars-
gaard (2016). PCA ﬁnds a linear combination for each set of variables in a dataset
while maintaining the variance in each of the variables. PCA reduces the dimension-
ality of the dataset by creating weighted linear combinations of the variables that ac-
count for maximum variance. A regression line is ﬁt through the data to minimise
residual error and is assigned as the ﬁrst principal component, PC1, to be parallel to
the direction of the vector with the most variance. Each point is projected onto the
line, the distance of the point from the line is recorded as a component or score. Load-
ings show the magnitude of the effect an element had on the scores for each principal
component. Each successive principal component accounts for a corresponding lesser
amount of variance. The second principal component, PC2, is orthogonal and un-
correlated to PC1 and represents the length of the vector with second most variance.
Associated weights for each variable reﬂect their corresponding variance.
Data were visualised using the scores and loadings of two principal components,
usually the ﬁrst two, which account for the most variation in the dataset. As the ele-
mental loadings represent the effect that each element has on the data, the farther the
element plots from the origin, the more variance is explained for that component. If
two elements have loadings of the same direction and length, e.g., Nb and Ta, they are
correlated outside of the structural bias of untransformed data and explain the same
amount of variance in the data. Here, the scores and loadings for each PC are plotted
separately for better visualisation, due to the large number of analyses. Scores of PC1
and PC2 are plotted in Figures 2.7C, 2.10C and 2.12C, for the ore, barren and com-66 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
bined datasets, respectively. Loadings are plotted in Figures 2.7D, 2.10D and 2.12D.
Scree plots show the amount of variance explained by each PC. These are plotted in
Figures 2.7B, 2.10B and 2.12B.
After PCA, hierarchical clustering, a form of unsupervised machine learning, was
applied to the dataset. Both hierarchical and k-means clustering were assessed and
hierarchical clustering, using the ‘ward.2’ method for compositional data was deter-
mined to be the best in distinguishing rutile from different ores, and igneous and
metamorphic sources. The data were clustered independently using similarities of
chemistry, without predeﬁning groups, in order to identify naturally similar chemical
groups of rutile.
Twelve of the analysed elements were chosen for further evaluation due to their
potential as ore discriminants. The principal components of V , Cr, Fe, Zr, Nb, Mo, Sn,
Sb, Hf, Ta, W and U were clustered for comparison. These elements, predominantly
HFSEs, were considered because analytical precision and accuracy was excellent even
at small laser spot sizes ( >15m). The analytical precision for elements commonly
associated with silicates, such as Mg, Al and Ca, decreased enough at small spot sizes
to affect their variance within the dataset. These trace elements were eliminated from
further processing to avoid artiﬁcially clustering data that were affected by spot size.
2.3. R ESULTS
A preliminary comparison was made between the data collected for this study and
previously compiled data for W anomalies in orogenic Au deposits (Clark and Williams-
Jones, 2004; Figure 2.1). The majority of rutile analyses from the ore samples (Figure
2.4A) have contents of W that plot within the ‘ore to sub-ore and alteration zone’ in the
ternary diagram of Clark and Williams-Jones (2004). Not all of these data are from Au
deposits, but also from pegmatites, Au-Cu and VHMS deposits. Many barren samplesChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 67
also fall within the ore/sub-ore/alteration zones of the orogenic Au ternary diagram
(Figure 2.4B), therefore, barren rutile either carries Au ore signatures, or some Au ore
rutile has a similar signature to igneous or metamorphic rocks. As W is enriched
in several different barren rocks and ore types, this highlights the need to develop
a different method to assess multivariate trace element rutile chemistries in order to
ﬁngerprint chemical patterns.
FIGURE 2.4: Ternary diagram of W contents in rutile from A. Ore deposits and
B. barren igneous-metamorphic rocks. The ternary diagrams are overlain with
the area in which W contents plot from ore and sub-ore zones of Au deposits
(thick dashed line) according to that compiled by Clark and Williams-Jones
(2004). Rutile from unaltered wallrock from Clark and Williams-Jones (2004)
plots in the stippled zone below the detection limit for WO 3on an EMP .
2.3.1. O RES
Selected rutile grains from ore deposits are shown in Figures 2.5 and 2.6 as backscatter
electron (BSE) and secondary electron (SE) images. Figure 2.5 shows rutile grains that
are easily analysed for trace elements. They are large ( >50m), inclusion-free and are
found in carbonatites (Figure 2.5B), Au-Cu ores (Figure 2.5C), pegmatites and higher-
grade ( ≥upper greenschist-facies) Au deposits (Figs. 2.5A, D, E). The rutile grains
are irregular to euhedral in shape and elemental zoning is common. An exception is
shown in Figure 2.5E, where a rutile from a pegmatite is intergrown with columbite-68 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
tantalite.
Figure 2.6 shows BSE images of rutile grains that are typical of Yilgarn craton
Au and VHMS deposits. Many of the Au orebodies in the Kalgoorlie deposits were
formed under greenschist-facies conditions (see references in Tables 2.2 and 2.3). These
rutile grains are typically <50m, very irregular in shape and porous in appearance.
Zonation is common, and includes high trace element contents at grain edges (Figure
2.6D) to irregular patches with enriched trace element contents throughout the grain
(Figs. 2.6B, C). Rutile is commonly retrogressed to titanite (Figs. 2.6B, C) or partially
dissolved or replaced (Figs. 2.6E, F).
One thousand seventy-four (1074) individual spot analyses were carried out on
70 samples from 33 different deposits, separated into six different types (the number
of LA-ICP-MS analysis spots in brackets): Au (557), Au-Cu (153), carbonatite (47),
lamprophyre (59), pegmatite (133) and VHMS (125). A summary of clustered samples
and their respective groups are presented in Tables 2.2 and 2.3. As not all the analyses
from each ore sample cluster into the same group, a complete list of the grouping for
all analyses is given in Table 1 of Appendix C.
Antimony contributes 69% to PC1 of the ores database (Table 2.5). The distance
Sb plots from the origin of Figure 2.7D, or the magnitude of loading, demonstrates
the large effect Sb has on the discrimination of ores based on PC1. For PC1, Sb is
negatively correlated to Nb, Ta, and Sn and the large variance in Sb separates Groups
A1, A6 and A7 (rutile low in Sb), from Groups A4 and A2 (high Sb rutile). Groups A1,
A6 and A7 have low median contents of Sb, but high Nb, Ta and Sn. These opposing
groups are separated along the x-axis of Figure 2.7C. The difference in Sb vs Nb, Ta
and Sn contents and their negative correlation is also evident in the boxplots for each
group (Figure 2.8).
PC2 receives approximately 76% contribution from Cr (Table 2.5), which is nega-
tively correlated with Fe. The variation in these elements separates groups low in Fe
and high in Cr (Groups A1 and A2) from those low in Cr and high in Fe (Groups A6Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 69

from the Poona pegmatite.70 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3

clinopyroxene (cpx) are also present. E. Extremely retrogressed rutile from
the Kanowna Belle Au deposit. The grains are included with muscovite and
quartz. Groundmass is composed of albite (ab) and muscovite and minor
pyrite. F. Retrogressed rutile grain from the Jupiter Au deposit. Grains are
included with quartz and chlorite after cpx.Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 71

gram of the clustering of the principal components (PCs) of the ores dataset
showing the relationships between groups. B. Barplot of how much variance
is explained by each PC of the ores dataset. C. Scores from the ﬁrst two PCs
with colours representing the seven clusters of Group A. D. Loadings for each
