components resulting from PCA for the ores, background igneous and meta-
morphic, and combined datasets. All numbers are in % and numbers in bold
represent the elements contributing the most to each principal component.
and A7) (Figure 2.7C).
The variation of PC3 is predominantly caused by Zr and Hf contents (Table 2.5)
which are negatively correlated to Fe and W (Figs. 2.7E, F). High Zr and low Fe and
W contents separate Group A3 from Groups A5 and A6, which are comparatively low
in Zr and Hf, but have rutile rich in W (Figure 2.8).
An example dendrogram, or classiﬁcation tree, is presented in Figure 2.7A to show
the relationships between each classiﬁed group and how closely each group is related.
The similarities between Groups A1, A6 and A7 is apparent in this diagram as they
are the ﬁrst three to split from the others in the dataset based on high Nb, Ta and Sn
in rutile contents.
Group A1 is comprised of all three Telfer Au-Cu samples and three of the Yinni-
etharra pegmatite samples. This group is deﬁned by rutile with low Sb and Fe con-
tents, and slightly elevated Cr, Nb and Ta contents (Figure 2.8).
Group A6 is also predominantly comprised of non-Au deposits: all four samples
from the Bentley VHMS deposit, the Gifford Creek carbonatite and one of the Yinni-Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 73
FIGURE 2.8: Group A: Boxplots of trace elements in ppm for each of the seven
groups from ore sample clustering. The line in each box represents the me-
dian of each group. The box limits represent the second and third quartiles
of the dataset. The whiskers include the ﬁrst and fourth quartiles and the
dots are outside the 2 sigma distribution of the dataset. The numbers along
the horizontal axis represent the group number. Note Zr and Hf, Nb and Ta;
and Mo and U have similar trends in trace element contents. Note Zr and Hf;
Nb, Ta, Sn and broadly Fe; and Mo and U have similar trends in rutile trace
element contents between clusters.74 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
etharra pegmatite samples. The deﬁning characteristics of this group is rutile with low
V , Zr and Hf contents, and elevated Nb, Ta, Sn and Mo contents.
The pegmatites from Harrison’s Reward, Poona, Yalgoo and those from Madagas-
car exclusively cluster within Group A7. The rutile in these samples contains percent-
age amounts of Nb, Ta and Sn. Combined with high Mo and U, and low Cr contents,
this group is the most chemically distinct.
The next most distinct group on the clustering dendrogram is Group A3 (Figure
2.7A). This group is comprised of both samples from the Speewah carbonatite, all
samples from the Paringa and Kalgoorlie lamprophyres and two samples from the
Nimbus VHMS deposit. The Au deposits included in this group are from Boorara,
Lady Bountiful, Tropicana’s Havana deposit, and most samples from Golden Pike
and Lake View Lode, excluding those proximal to the ore body. Group A3 has rutile
characterised by low Sn, W, Cr and U contents, and relatively high Zr and Hf contents.
Group A4 is comprised solely of rutile from Au deposits and is characterised by
very high Sb, W and V contents and corresponding low Nb and Ta contents. All four
Big Bell samples, Kalgoorlie, Mt Charlotte, the lode zone samples from Golden Pike
and Lake View Lode cluster in this group, which represents some of the largest and
most economically important Au deposits of WA.
Group A2 consists of the Au deposits from Harbour Lights, Tropicana’s Boston
Shaker (high Sb-rutile) and some samples from Hopes Hill. The Nimbus VHMS de-
posit, sampled distal to the main ore, is included in Group A2, along with the Green-
bushes pegmatite. This group has rutile with extremely high Cr contents, elevated Sb,
V and W, and low Ta contents.
Group A5 consists of all samples from the Boddington Au-Cu deposit, one Yinni-
etharra and both Queensland pegmatites, the Shea West lamprophyre and one Nim-
bus VHMS deposit (VB4). The Au deposits included in this group are Hopes Hill, Her-
cules, Royal Standard, Jupiter, Jubilee, Victory-Deﬁance and Kanowna Belle. TheseChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 75
rutile samples have elevated Cr, W and V contents and low in Zr and Hf contents.
2.3.2. I GNEOUS AND METAMORPHIC ROCKS
The majority of the rocks sourced for the igneous- and metamorphic-derived rutile
database were collected by the GSWA through their state-wide sampling program.
Sample numbers and detailed rock descriptions can be found on the GSWA website
(www.dmp.wa.gov.au). The samples from the GSWA collection were considered to
be from background or barren sources, but in some cases they were collected in close
proximity to mineralised occurrences (Table 2.4) which potentially has affected the
rutile trace element contents. SEM images of typical examples of rutile found in barren
rock samples are presented in Figure 2.9.
The clustering methods and elements used for PCA were the same as used with
clustering the ore-derived rutile. Six clusters were chosen to explain the variation in
chemistry of the igneous and metamorphic rocks (Group B). The ﬁrst three principal
components account for 89% of the variance in the barren rocks dataset (Figure 2.10B).
The scores of the ﬁrst two principal components are plotted in Figure 2.10C, with
colours representing each of the clusters also used in the dendrogram of 2.7A. Corre-
sponding loadings for each element are shown in Figure 2.7D. Unlike the ores database
in which Sb and Cr dominate the variation in PC1 (69%) and PC2 (75%), here W ac-
counts for most variation in PC1, but only for 38%, and for PC2, Fe accounts for only
30% of the variation (Table 2.5). The dendrogram of clustering for the barren samples
is shown in Figure 2.10A, where Groups B2 and B5 form the left branch and are sepa-
rated from the remaining groups based mainly on their high Cr and Ta contents, and
relatively low Fe contents. This can also be seen in the loadings of PC1 and PC2 in
Figure 2.10D. PC3 highlights the differences in variation between Cr, and Nb and Ta
in rutile, in which groups higher in Nb and Ta (Group B3) are separated from those
higher in Cr (Group B2).76 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
FIGURE 2.9: Combined BSE and secondary electron images of rutile grains
in epoxy mounts from igneous and metamorphic GSWA rock heavy mineral
and zircon (zrn) separates. A. Sample 112106 of a monzogranite. The rutile (rt)
grains are anhedral, mottled zones. Some are partially retrogressed to anatase
(ant). Titanite (ttn) is the more common Ti-bearing mineral in this sample.
B. Sample 180067 from a microgranite. Rutile varies from subhedral whole
grains to clustered multigrain agglomerates associated with quartz (qtz) and
biotite (bt). C. Sample 178024 from a granodiorite. Anhedral agglomerates
associated with quartz, magnetite (mt) and titanite. D. Sample 178083 from
a metarhyolite. Subhedral clusters found within a matrix of quartz and mus-
covite (ms).Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 77
FIGURE 2.10: Results from PCA of the igneous-metamorphic background
database (Group B). A. Dendrogram of the clustering of the PCs of the
igneous-metamorphic dataset shows the degree of connection between clus-
ters. B. Barplot of how much variance is explained by each PC of the igneous-
metamorphic dataset, with PC1 explaining approximately 49%. C. Scores
from the ﬁrst two PCs with colours representing the six clustered groups. D.
Loadings for each element of PC1 and PC2. E. Scores from PC1 and PC3. F.
Loadings for each element of PC1 and PC3.78 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
FIGURE 2.11: Boxplots of trace elements (in ppm) for each of the six groups
from background igneous-metamorphic rutile sample clustering (Group B).
The line in each box represents the median of each group. The box limits
represent the second and third quartiles of the dataset. The whiskers include
the ﬁrst and fourth quartiles and the dots are outside the 2 sigma distribution
of the dataset. The numbers along the horizontal axis represent the group
number for the background data analysis. Note Zr and Hf, Nb and Ta; and
Mo and U have similar trends in trace element contents.Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 79
The variation of W content in rutile of PC1 separates clusters along the x-axis of
Figure 2.10C. PC1 distinguishes Group B2, which is high in W, from those groups
low in W and high in Zr and Hf (Groups B1 and B6) (Figure 2.10A). The negative
correlation of W and Zr can be seen in the loadings of PC1 (Figure 2.10D). Most of
the variance of PC2 in the igneous-metamorphic dataset is explained by Fe, which
is negatively correlated to the variation of Cr in rutile. This is apparent along the y-
axis of Figures 2.10C and D where Groups B2 and B5, high in Cr, are separated from
Group B3, which is relatively low in Cr and high in Fe. The scores and loadings of
the variation in rutile chemistries of PC1 and PC3 are shown in Figures 2.10E and F,
respectively.
The rocks in the igneous-metamorphic database cluster naturally into six groups.
Table 2.4 summarises how each sample analysis clusters, its rock type and source lo-
cation. The full database, which shows the group into which each sample clusters, is
presented in the Table 1 of Appendix C. Boxplots of each element in each group are
plotted in Figure 2.11 to highlight the overall chemical patterns of elements in each
group.
Groups B2 and B5 are most closely related and distinct from the other groups.
Group B2 contains a very distinctive rutile chemistry with very high Cr, W and Mo
contents. This group consists mainly of analyses from two Wodgina pegmatite sam-
ples and the rutile standard R632 from an anorthosite in Madagascar (Figures 2.10 and
2.11).
Group B5 is comprised of rutile low in Fe, high in Cr and U and includes sam-
ples from garnet-bearing and sheared amphibolites and gneisses, a felsic tuff and all
samples from the Windmill Hill granulite quartzite standard.
Group B3 is comprised of a variety of felsic volcaniclastics and tuffs, monzogran-
ites, rhyolites, metadacite, tonalite and metamorphosed felsic rocks. The chemical
signature of rutile from Group B3 is low in Cr Mo, Zr and Hf and high in Sb, Nb, Ta
and Fe (Figure 2.11).80 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
Group B1 includes rutile from hydrated and strained granulites of western Nor-
way, metagranites, amphibolites, high pressure, garnet-bearing rocks, retro-eclogites
and rutile from garnet inclusions in Brazil. The rutile in this group is distinctly de-
pleted in Sb, Sn, Cr and W contents.
Group B6 is characterised by rutile with high V contents and low W, Nb and Ta
contents. All samples attributed to this group are from ﬁve highly metasomatised
gabbros of southern Norway.
Group B4 is comprised of rutile with intermediate chemistries between Groups B1
and B6. It includes monzogranites, rhyolites, granite and xenoliths from an anorthosite.
2.3.3. C OMBINED ANALYSIS
Clustering of the combined rutile ore and igneous-metamorphic datasets was per-
formed in order to identify if certain, or all, ore-derived rutile can be distinguished
from rutile in barren rock. Rutile chemistries that are unique to only ore sources are
key to targeting in ore exploration.
For the combined ores and igneous-metamorphic rutile chemistry dataset (Group
C), the ﬁrst three principal components explain 79% of the variation in data (Figure
2.12B), with PC1 accounting for 46% of all variance. Similar to the igneous-metamorphic
dataset, W contributes the most to the variance in PC1, at 31% (Table 2.5). Iron ac-
counts for over 30% of the variance in PC2 and Cr makes up over 26% of the variance
in the third principal component.
Clustering of the PC scores produced nine distinct clusters, shown as a dendrogram
in Figure 2.12A, and as the scores of PC1 and PC2 in Figure 2.12C. The number of
clusters chosen was based on distinction of rutile chemistry patterns. Rutile trace
element content summaries are presented as boxplots in Figure 2.13 as a summary
of median contents of each element for each group compared to the overall medianChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 81
FIGURE 2.12: Results from PCA of the combined database (Group C) A. Den-
drogram from clustering of the combined dataset showing the degree of con-
nection between clusters. B. Barplot of how much variance is explained by
each PC of the combined dataset. C. Scores from the ﬁrst two PCs with colours
representing the nine clusters of Group C, as in the dendrogram. D. Loadings
for each element of PC1 and PC2. E. Scores from PC1 and PC3. F. Loadings
for each element of PC1 and PC3 for the combined dataset.82 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
for each element of the entire dataset, to easily identify which clusters are deﬁcient or
elevated in certain trace elements.
From PC1 and PC2 of Figures 2.12C and 2.12D, clusters are distinguished based on
differences in W and from Zr and Fe variations. Groups high in W and Cr (Groups
C4 and C9) are separated from those low in W and Cr (Groups C3 and C8). PC2
distinguishes groups high in Cr (Groups C9 and C7) from those that are negatively
correlated and high in Fe (Groups C5, C2). PC3, shown in Figures 2.12E and F, high-
lights differences in variation of Sb from Nb and Ta (Table 2.5). PC3 separates the
clusters high in Sb (Group C2) from those high in Nb and Ta (Groups C5 and C7)
FIGURE 2.13: Group C: Boxplots of trace elements, in ppm, for each of the
nine clusters from the combined dataset. The line central to each box is the
median content for each group and the bounds of each box represents the
second and third quartiles of the data. The extent of the whiskers delineates
the ﬁrst and fourth quartiles and the dots are outside the 2 sigma distribution
of the dataset. The numbers along the horizontal axis represent the group
number from the combined analysis.Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 83
Two of the 9 clusters of the combined dataset are comprised of primarily of ore-
derived rutile and three of those are exclusively of non-ore rutile. The remaining four
groups are a mix of both ore and non-ore rutile sources. The ore-derived rutile clus-
ters are broadly separated from the non-ore rutile in the dendrogram of Figure 2.7A.
Groups C6 through C9, mostly non-ore rutile, are separated from the right side, ore-
derived rutile of Groups C1 through C5. Groups typical of non-ore rutile generally
have lower Sb, Fe and W contents and higher Nb, Ta, Mo, V and U contents. These
group trends can be seen in Figure 2.13.
The two clusters that are comprised exclusively of ore samples are Groups C2 and
C3. Group C2 is comprised solely of Au-derived rutile and includes all Kalgoorlie
Superpit and Big Bell samples (Table 2.2). Also included in Group C2 are Tropicana’s
Boston Shaker deposit, Harbour Lights, Hopes Hill, Royal Standard, Hercules, Jubilee
and Victory-Deﬁance, nearly all of the signiﬁcant Yilgarn Au deposits. This group has
the highest median Sb and W contents and comparatively low Nb and Ta contents
(Figure 2.13). Of the 425 analyses that have been grouped here, 7 ( <2 %) are not
derived from ore and 27 ( 6 %) are derived from non-Au ores. Most of the non-Au
ore rutile clustered in Group C2 are from sample VB4 of the Nimbus VHMS deposit.
Group C3 is comprised of those samples from the Golden Pike and Lake View
Lode Au deposits most distal from the ore (those closest to the ore are classiﬁed as
Group C2), Boorara, the Paringa lamprophyre and the Nimbus VHMS samples, also
more distal to the ore. The rutile in this group are depleted in U, Sn, Cr and W, and
moderately enriched in Sb.
Group C5 is almost completely comprised of rutile derived from pegmatites. Few
samples of felsic metamorphics and rhyolite cluster with the high Nb-Ta pegmatites
of the Yalgoo, Poona, Harrison’s Reward and Madagascar pegmatites. Also included
in this group are the four Bentley VHMS deposit samples. This group has rutile with
very high Nb, Ta, Fe and Sn, and low Cr contents.
Group C1 is a mix of Telfer and Boddington Au-Cu samples, the Queensland,84 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.3
Yinnietharra and Greenbushes pegmatites, Speewah and Gifford Creek carbonatites,
Lady Bountiful Au, and Shea West and Kalgoorlie lamprophyres. All samples from
Au-Cu ores and carbonatites within this database are included in this group. Many
non ore-derived rutile grains also group here: volcaniclastics, monzogranites, granites
and metadacites. This group has the lowest median U, Mo, V , Zr and Hf contents.
Group C4 is comprised of Tropicana’s Havana deposit and samples VB9 and VB21
of the Nimbus VHMS deposit, which were sampled from dacite wallrock. Analy-
ses from the Jupiter Au and Speewah carbonatite also have chemistry similar that of
this group. Non-ore rutile are from felsic tuffs, volcaniclastics and metarhyolite. This
group has rutile with high Cr, and low Sn and Fe contents.
Group C7 consists of the Windmill Hill quartzite rutile standard, and rutile from
sheared and garnet-pyroxene amphibolites and gneisses. The ore-related rutile within
this cluster was derived exclusively from three Yinnietharra pegmatite samples. Chem-
ically, this cluster is most closely related to Group C9, the Wodgina pegmatite (Figs.
2.7A, C, E). This cluster is characterised by rutile with high Cr and low in Fe and Sb
contents.
The clusters which contain predominantly non ore-related rutile include Groups
C6, C8 and C9. Group C6 consists of monzogranite, tonalite, granite and granodior-
ite, and rutile xenoliths in anorthosite. Group C6 samples are chemically similar to
Group C8, rutile from high grade metamorphic rocks with high Zr and Hf contents,
but Group C6 rutile is higher in Sn and W contents.
Group C8, like Group B6, consists of analyses from metasomatised scapolite fels,
albite and metagabbro from the Bamble district of southern Norway. These samples
are all from a maﬁc orthopyroxene-bearing gabbro precursor but have undergone dif-
ferent types and extents of metasomatism (Porter et al., in review), such that they are
now low in W, Sn, Nb and Ta, and high in Zr, Hf and V . This group also includes high
pressure rutile from Brazil and hydrated and strained rutile from western Norway.Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 85
Group C9, like Group B2, consists exclusively of analyses from the Wodgina peg-
matite, which has rutile that is rich in Cr (average 1.1 %) and W (average 8000 ppm),
and high U, Mo and V contents (Figure 2.13).
2.4. D ISCUSSION
2.4.1. PCA OF RUTILE CHEMISTRY
Principal component analysis of all three datasets demonstrates the consistency with
which rutile incorporates certain trace elements. There are expected associations be-
tween some elements (e.g., Nb and Ta, and Zr and Hf are correlated), and this is high-
lighted by PCA. Other associations are evident in the ores database, as Sn also corre-
lates well with Nb and Ta, and moderately with U and Mo. High U rutile is associated
with relatively high Mo rutile, and they show similar variation to that of Zr and Hf
and, as such, cluster similarly. Therefore conditions that produce rutile that has high
Zr content similarly allow for the incorporation of more Mo and U. As Zr content in
rutile increases with temperature (in equilibrium with zircon and quartz (Zack et al.,
2004a; Watson et al., 2006; Ferry and Watson, 2007)), this may provide evidence for
temperature playing a role in U and Mo incorporation, which may not be obvious
due to the typically low U and Mo contents in rutile ( <100 ppm and <50 ppm, re-
spectively). Other factors such as ﬂuid conditions and wallrock chemistry can play
a role in incorporation into rutile as the correlation of U and Mo to Zr is not strong.
Meinhold (2010) showed felsic granulites contain rutile with the highest U content, in-
dicating both temperature and rock evolution can be contributing factors to increased
incorporation if U in rutile.
The ﬁrst three principal components of the analysed datasets can discriminate: ore
type, metamorphic grade and maﬁc versus felsic source rocks. Antimony negatively86 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.4
correlates with Nb, Ta and Sn such that rutile containing high Sb typically has low
Nb, Ta and Sn contents. This allows PC1 to be used as a discriminant between rutile
sourced from Au deposits enriched in Sb, from rutile in pegmatites which are enriched
in Nb, Ta and Sn. This can be seen in the dendrogram in Figure 2.7A, where most of
the pegmatites, but no Au ores, plot to the left of the main node. This is also evident
in PC1 of Figure 2.7C, in which clusters of rutile from pegmatites are separated from
Sb-rich Au deposits. When the ore and barren datasets are combined, the distinction
between Sb-rich Au ores and Nb-Ta-rich pegmatites can be seen in PC3 (Figs. 2.12E, F).
In Figure 2.12E, Group C2, rutile from Au deposits (dark blue) is separated from the
Nb-pegmatites of Group C5 (light green) along the y-axis of PC3. Barren rutile plots
closer to the origin of Figure 2.12E, thus rutile from barren rocks may be distinguished
from both mineralised groups based on Nb, Ta and Sb contents.
The ﬁrst two principal components of the barren and combined datasets account
for variation in the same elements. PC1 discriminates rutile chemistry partially on
metamorphic grade. Although W accounts for the most variation in the data, and is
negatively correlated to the main metamorphic temperature indicator, Zr, which is in-
corporated into rutile as a function of temperature (Zack et al., 2004a; Watson et al.,
2006; Ferry and Watson, 2007). The negative correlation of Zr with W suggests that
W is incorporated into rutile in greater quantity at lower temperatures. This negative
correlation is highlighted in the boxplot data (Figs. 2.11 and 2.13) as groups high in
Zr are correspondingly low in W contents. The main exception to this is the Wodgina
pegmatite which is high in both W and Zr where the abundance of W in the formation
environment has contributed its abundance in rutile in addition to temperature. Fur-
thermore, Hf has a very strong positive correlation to Zr and therefore is incorporated
into rutile in greater quantity at higher temperatures. The strong positive correlation
of Hf and Zr reﬂects the easy substitution of Hf for Zr in the structure of rutile and is
consequently incorporated in greater abundance at higher temperatures.
The second principal component of the barren and combined datasets, and PC2Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 87
for the ores database is dominated by the variance of Cr and Fe contents. Chromium
has been identiﬁed as an indicator of maﬁc rock source using the ratio of Nb to Cr
(Meinhold et al., 2008; Zack et al., 2002; Triebold et al., 2007). In this way the PC
identifying high Cr contents can point to groups that are more likely of maﬁc or of
mantle source.
2.4.2. O RES
AU DEPOSITS Most Au deposits in the ores dataset are clustered in Groups A4 and
A5, and fewer in Groups A3 and A2. These groups are formed on the basis of their low
relative Sn, Nb, and Ta and high Sb, W and V contents, which form the right branch
of the dendrogram of Figure 2.7C. Group A4, and to a lesser extent Group A2, contain
rutile grains that have chemistry representative of a Au deposit source as previously
deﬁned by Clark and Williams-Jones (2004) (Table 2.1) as high in W and Sb contents.
Group A4 is deﬁned primarily by rutile from Kalgoorlie-style Au and Big Bell Au
deposits and represents the most economically important group with respect to Au-
prospectivity. Of note are the samples from Golden Pike and Lake View Lode, in
which the rutile Sb and W contents increase closer to the lode such that they cluster in
Group A4. Farther from the lodes, rutile clusters into Group A3, which includes rutile
with lower W, Sb and V contents, and similar chemistry to the Havana Au deposit at
Tropicana. Every sample that is clustered within Group A4 is identiﬁed as a Au de-
posit, which has important consequences for identifying Au ore in exploration using
detrital rutile chemistry.
Group A5 is also comprised mainly of rutile from Au deposits, but the rutile has
distinctly lower Sb, V and W contents. The Au deposits in this group do not occur
within the Kalgoorlie area (e.g., Hercules, Hopes Hill, Jupiter, Jubilee, Victory Deﬁance
and Royal Standard; Figure 2.2). These are smaller deposits than those in the Kalgoor-
lie area, so it is possible rutile trace element contents reﬂect the size and temperature88 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.4
of the hydrothermal system and provide evidence that incorporation of Au-associated
trace elements is affected by other factors, such as wallrock composition.
Group A2, like Group A4, contains rutile with similar elevated W, V and Sb levels,
but is distinct in having extremely high Cr and low Fe contents. Rutile from Au ore
at Harbour Lights, some analyses of Hopes Hill and Boston Shaker, the high Sb-rutile
deposit at Tropicana, comprise part of this group. The non-Au ore deposits in this
group are sample VB9 from the Nimbus VHMS deposit, Greenbushes pegmatite and
some analyses from the syn-mineralisation Paringa lamprophyre. The chemistry of
Group A2 is deﬁned by the distinct high Cr content, reﬂective of wall rock source
(maﬁc), and high Sb-rutile from Au mineralisation. The Greenbushes rutile may be
anomalous as this is an historic museum specimen and there is no clear indication as to
where in the deposit it was collected. The Greenbushes rutile is the only pegmatite that
is clustered based on high Cr content in this database. Of the four Nimbus samples,
VB9 is the one closest to mineralisation compared to the other three and has rutile
chemistries most similar to those of rutile from Au deposits.
Included in Group A3 Au deposits are Lady Bountiful, Boorara, Tropicana’s Ha-
vana deposit, some analyses of Jupiter and Kanowna Belle, and the peripheral sam-
ples from Golden Pike and Lake View Lode. There are non-Au deposits in Group
A3, including the Speewah carbonatite, Paringa-Kalgoorlie lamprophyres and sam-
ples VB21 and VB24 from the Nimbus VHMS deposit. For the Golden Pike, Lake
View Lode and Nimbus deposits, rutile most peripheral to the main ores cluster within
Group A3. For Lake View Lode, the samples taken at within 3 feet of the lode cluster
in Group A4, while samples farther than 3 feet from the lode cluster in Group A3. Al-
teration changes 3 feet from the ore at Lake View Lode, from bleached to chloritised.
This indicates that the Au ore-related chemistry in rutile is lost with increasing dis-
tance from the lode and with changing alteration style. A similar pattern is evident
with the Golden Pike samples where rutile sampled within 1 foot of the lode also clus-
ter in Group A4 and the peripheral samples plot in Group A3, having lost the enrichedChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 89
high Sb, V and W signature.
Additionally, Zr content in rutile is lower in Group A4 than in other Au related
groups, indicating generally lower formation temperatures. Thus, the chemistry of
this group may have been impacted by other formation conditions (ﬂuid/rock ratio,
temperature and alteration type) and may not be reﬂective solely of the Au ore associ-
ation. Although this group clusters Au deposits, the presence of carbonatites, lampro-
phyres and VHMS deposits make it difﬁcult to ﬁngerprint this style of mineralisation
based on rutile chemistry.
OTHER MINERALISATION There is a clear distinction between Groups A1, A6 and A7
and other ores (Figs. 2.7 and 2.8), as they contain rutile enriched in Ta, Nb and Sn
contents and are predominantly comprised of rutile from pegmatites, with some sam-
ples from VHMS, Au-Cu ores and carbonatites. The corresponding low Sb contents
of these groups are likely the key in distinguishing these deposits from the typical
Au deposits of Groups A2 and A4. No Au samples cluster within these three groups,
so this method of clustering ore deposits does provide a way of distinguishing rutile
associated with Au from non-Au deposits.
The most distinct group is Group A7, which is comprised solely of rutile from peg-
matites with high Nb, Ta and Sn contents (10–75%, 9–30% and 0.4–8.4%, respectively).
However, some of the rutile grains may have been contaminated and have mixed
rutile and columbite-tantalite analyses. Columbite-tantalite was recognised using the
SEM and EBSD prior to analysis, however, despite the attempted targeting, the % level
Nb, Ta and Sn indicate these analyses may have been contaminated by inclusions.
Other researchers (Cern ´y et al., 1999; Klementov ´a and Rieder, 2004) have identiﬁed
percent enrichments of Nb (5–19%) and Ta (3–16%) in niobian rutile from pegmatites,
so some Group A7 rutile may be reﬂecting uncontaminated signatures. These results
are relevant and included within the database as it is likely these rutile grains came
from the economic part of a Nb-pegmatite, are easy to identify and can be used for90 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.4
exploration targeting. The high Sn, Nb and Ta contents create a chemical ﬁngerprint
that make these pegmatites identiﬁable with high certainty.
Three Yinnietharra pegmatites and the Telfer Au-Cu samples comprise Group A1,
which also have rutile high in Nb, Ta and Sn, but the group is distinguished from the
other pegmatites by their low Fe and Sb, and high Cr contents. The higher Cr content
may be reﬂective of increased input from ﬂuid interaction with more maﬁc wallrock.
Group A6 is mainly comprised of the four Bentley VHMS samples, the Gifford Creek
carbonatite and a Yinnietharra pegmatite sample. This group is intermediate in com-
position between Groups A1 and A7, and is representative of a fractionated and felsic
source rock.
2.4.3. I GNEOUS AND METAMORPHIC ROCKS
Rutile from the igneous-metamorphic rocks is distinguished, in-part, by metamorphic
grade; e.g., temperature (Zack et al., 2004a; Watson et al., 2006; Tomkins et al., 2007),
and the degree of rock source evolution; i.e., maﬁc versus felsic source (Meinhold et al.,
2008; Zack et al., 2004b; Triebold et al., 2007).
For the igneous-metamorphic database, PC1 highlights variation in Zr, a geother-
mometer, by distinguishing groups high in Zr from those low in Zr contents. For
example, Groups B1 and B6, which cluster at the positive end of PC1 (Figure 2.10C)
are predicted to have been formed at high temperatures. Accordingly, both Groups
B1 and B6 are comprised of rutile from granulitic anorthosites (Moore et al., 2019,
Porter and Austrheim, 2017) and metasomatised gabbros that experienced granulite
temperatures. Conversely, those with low Zr and high W contents (which correlate
negatively), in Groups B3 and B4, formed at lower temperatures and are comprised of
felsic to intermediate volcanic and crystalline rocks.
PC2 highlights groups of rutile with differing Cr and Fe contents, and distinguishes
rock types based on source, as rutile from maﬁc or mantle sources incorporate moreChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 91
Cr (Meinhold et al., 2008; Zack et al., 2004b). Groups B3 and B4 plot on the higher,
positive Cr side of PC2 and PC3, indicating low Cr content (Figs. 2.10C and E). Both
these groups are comprised of felsic volcanics, volcaniclastics, intrusives and quartz-
rich metamorphic rocks. Group B5, with rutile high in Cr content, may reﬂect a less
evolved source. The difference between rutile from maﬁc and felsic sources is accentu-
ated when using PC3. This highlights Cr versus Nb variations, which are negatively
correlated, and are used in discriminating pelitic versus mantle sources (Meinhold
et al., 2008; Zack et al., 2004b). This suggests Group B3 is felsic in origin and Groups
B5 and B6 are of more maﬁc origins.
Using PCA with the igneous-metamorphic database can distinguish rutile formed
under high temperature conditions (Groups B1, B5, B6) from those formed at lower
temperatures (Group B3). This approach broadly separates those rutile grains formed
under granulite and amphibolite conditions from those that are volcanic or under-
went low-grade metamorphism (Groups B3, B4). These broad groups are separated
further by source rock conditions. For example, most rutile from rocks described as
containing biotite, volcanic rocks or those that experienced low-grade metamorphism
are included in Group B3. Those in Group B4 are of similar chemistries, but experi-
enced higher grade metamorphism.
Groups B5 and B6 have high Cr, and were originally maﬁc rocks from gabbros
of southern Norway (Porter et al., in review) and maﬁc volcanics from the Narryer
Terrane of WA (Muhling, 1990). Group B5, however, also includes the Windmill Hill
quartzite rutile standard, which contains abundant chromite and experienced high
temperature metamorphism, thus is unusually high in Cr for a quartz-rich, siliciclastic
rock. Also included in Group B5 are two more felsic rocks, the migmatitic granitic
gneiss from near the Big Red Prospect and bedded felsic tuff of the Anaconda Cu
mine district. This suggests that rutile in felsic rocks can incorporate Cr during high-
grade metamorphism. However, the Anaconda felsic tuff was collected in a thin lens
between komatiite ﬂows (Nelson, 2005a), and the high Cr content may be a result of92 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.4
rutile incorporating elements from of the surrounding ultra-maﬁc rocks.
2.4.4. C OMBINED DATASET
Combining the ore and barren datasets can provide tools for distinguishing rutile from
ore deposits and rutile from barren igneous or metamorphic rocks. Two groups cluster
primarily on rutile related to Au ore bodies (Groups C2, C3), Group C5 clusters Nb-
pegmatites, and Groups C1 and C4 cluster the remaining non-Au ore deposits with
some barren felsic rocks. The remaining ﬁve clusters are primarily non ore-related
groups separated mainly on metamorphic grade and wall rock source.
The group of particular interest is Group C2 in which the rutile chemistry has a
98% likelihood of being derived from a Au ore, and an 92% likelihood that the ore is a
Kalgoorlie or Big Bell-style Au deposit. Group C2 is equivalent to Groups A4 and A5
of the ores dataset, which combines all rutile analyses from Big Bell, Kalgoorlie and
Mt Charlotte with most of the remaining Yilgarn Au deposits, including the Boston
Shaker Au deposit of Tropicana and some analyses of the Nimbus VHMS deposit.
Two percent of the analyses are false negatives; i.e., samples that cluster as a rutile
derived from Au ore, but are from a non ore-related rock. Rutile chemistries within
Group C2, with high W and Sb contents, have the greatest potential to provided a
ﬁngerprint for Au exploration. If rutile exhibits chemical characteristics typical of this
group, it is likely sourced from Au ore similar to that of a Yilgarn Au deposit.
Similarly, Group C3 is comprised mainly of Au ores from the Yilgarn, but those
with rutile of lower Sb, W and U contents. Many of the analyses within this group
are from the same deposits as in Group C2, but distal to the ore, including Golden
Pike, Lake View Lode and the Nimbus VHMS deposit. Analyses from the Paringa
lamprophyre, Speewah carbonatite and Boorara Au are also included in this group
suggesting they have chemistries similar to distal Au deposits. Of the 171 analyses in
Group C2, 62% are Au-ore derived, 33% are from non-Au ores and 5% are false posi-Chapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 93
tives and not related to mineralisation. This indicates a rutile with chemical properties
similar to this group can be of interest to metals exploration.
Group C5 encompasses the Nb pegmatites and rutile from all Bentley VHMS de-
posits. Rutile that clusters in this group and contains percentage levels Sn, Ta and Nb
are likely to be derived from a Nb-pegmatite. Lower levels of Ta and/ore Sn may dis-
tinguish VHMS origins from Nb-pegmatites, but there is chemical overlap with barren
felsic rocks, such as rhyolite and felsic granofels. The host rock of the Bentley VHMS
deposit is rhyolite (Belford et al., 2015), which may explain the chemical similarities of
rutile in this VHMS deposit to rutile from barren rhyolite. The Bentley VHMS rutile
may be distinguished from the others in this group based on lower Ta contents. The
pegmatites and other felsics generally have Ta contents over 1000 ppm, whereas Bent-
ley rutile grains have <600 ppm Ta (Appendix C, Table 1). The barren rocks in this
group have rutile with anomalously high Nb, Ta and Sn contents that are more akin to
pegmatite chemistry, and both samples 91591 and 195673 are described as felsic ﬂow-
banded rhyolites (Nelson, 1995b; Kirkland et al., 2014b). Rutile similar in chemistry to
this group is likely sourced from a non-Au ore, and if rutile contains over percentage
level Nb, Ta and Sn contents, it is likely from a Nb-pegmatite.
Groups C1 and C4 are the two least chemically distinct groups of the clustered data.
Rutile chemistries for Group C1 are reﬂective mainly of volcaniclastics and felsic vol-
canics of the barren ore dataset, but also of the Telfer and Boddington Au-Cu deposits,
Gifford Creek and Speewah carbonatites, Greenbushes, Queensland pegmatites and
the Paringa, Kalgoorlie and Shea West lamprophyres. Thus, rutile originating from
ores that are not Au, Nb-pegmatites or VHMS deposits, carry a chemical ﬁngerprint
indistinguishable from those of felsic volcanics and volcaniclastics. This may be re-
ﬂective of similar formation conditions, or indicate that rutile is inﬂuenced by felsic
rock chemistries that are host rocks to ores.
Group C4 has a similar chemical signature to Group C1 in that the barren rocks in
this group are also felsic volcaniclastics, rhyolites and metamorphics. The chemical94 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.4
signature is higher in Cr and lower in Sn, Ta and Nb. The main ores attributed to
this group are the Tropicana’s Havana Au deposit and two of the samples from the
Nimbus VHMS deposit. A few analyses from Jupiter Au, Boddington Au-Cu and
Speewah carbonatite also cluster here and therefore may not be distinguishable from
barren felsic rocks by chemical analysis of rutile.
Groups C6 through C9 are comprised primarily of barren or non ore-associated
rocks. They are distinguished broadly on metamorphic grade from granulite (Group
C8) to amphibolite (Group C6) to weakly metamorphosed crystalline igneous rocks
(Group C7). Groups C6 is comprised predominantly of barren rocks, intermediate
crystalline rocks such as granites, monzogranites, tonalites, granodiorites and rhyo-
lites equivalent to Groups B4 and B1 of the barren dataset.
Group C7 is comprised primarily of granulite and amphibolite-grade metamor-
phic rocks (equivalent to Group B5) that are not ore-related and are grouped based
on metamorphic grade and host rock origin. They contain rutile of similar chemistry
and metamorphic grade to that of Group C8, but the rutile is higher in Nb, Cr, Ta and
Sn and lower in Fe contents. This may suggest a less maﬁc origin, except that some
of these samples also have high Cr contents. This group also includes three samples
from the Yinnietharra pegmatite.
Group C8, comprised of granulites and eclogites from Norway and Brazil, is formed
on the basis of high-grade metamorphic chemistry, with high Zr content. This group
is not associated with ore and is comprised of rocks derived originally from gabbros
and anorthosites; rocks considered to be more maﬁc than the samples of Group C7
(Porter and Austrheim, 2017; Moore et al., 2019). Rutile that clusters within this group
likely originates from maﬁc rock that has experienced high-grade metamorphic tem-
peratures.
The Wodgina pegmatite, Group C9, for both the barren database and combined
database stands out as having a distinct chemical signature. It is anomalous due to its
percentage level Cr and W contents. Unfortunately, even though it is classiﬁed as aChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 95
pegmatite as the crystal is approximately 2.5 cm in width, it is a detrital crystal and its
rock source is assumed to be a pegmatite, but is technically not known.
2.4.5. P RACTICAL CONSIDERATIONS
The chemical grouping based on PCA only takes into consideration the trace element
chemistry of the rutile grain. Other considerations, such as rutile size and texture may
provide better, or complimentary, insight into the rutile source during exploration.
Size and texture will also dictate which deposits and rock types can be assessed geo-
chemically, as rutile grains must be of a certain size and quality to be assessed using
in situ analytical techniques such as LA-ICP-MS.
Many of the rutile grains sourced from the Au deposits of the central Yilgarn, in-
cluding for the Kalgoorlie area, are small ( <20m) and highly irregular in shape, with
extensive alteration (Figure 2.6). Grains <20m in size have an increased chance of
containing mineral inclusions or becoming contaminated by adjacent minerals during
analysis. This may substantially degrade the accuracy of trace element content as-
sessment. During heavy mineral separation of exploration samples, rutile grains from
these deposits may be excluded during routine sample preparation via the loss of ﬁner
grain fractions. Reﬁned heavy mineral concentration and careful identiﬁcation tech-
niques may be required to identify rutile from a Kalgoorlie-type Au ore. Rutile from
ﬁner-grained intrusives (Figs. 2.9A through 2.9C) and volcaniclastics and tuffs (Fig-
ure 2.9D) are also likely to be excluded from a normal heavy mineral separation due
to size and textural biases.
Grain size, shape and texture that are best for trace element analysis originate
from deposits that have experienced upper-greenschist to amphibolite temperatures
or higher. Deposits that have undergone lower grade metamorphism can have rutile
grains that are partially retrogressed to anatase or brookite (Figure 2.9A) and should
be excluded from comparison with rutile chemistry. Rutile textures at low metamor-96 J.K. P ORTER Section 2.5
phic temperatures are typically no longer single domain grains with smooth surfaces,
but are often porous or spongy and anhedral in morphology (Figures 2.5E and F).
For this study, the best rutile grains from ores that are large enough to be transported
and preserved in the heavy sediment record and recovered during standard heavy
mineral separation (e.g., >50m) are those from pegmatites, the Tropicana, Big Bell
and Hopes Hill Au deposits, the Telfer Au-Cu deposit and Gifford Creek carbonatite
(Figure 2.5).
2.5. C ONCLUSIONS
Rutile chemistry can be used in exploration to identify ore deposits. In addition to
identifying rutile originating from ore-related versus barren rock, the chemistry can
also provide insight as to source rock composition and metamorphic grade. The re-
sults of this study can form a basis upon which a supervised machine learning algor-
thim can be used to predict formation environments, such as ore association, lithology
and metamorphic grade of detrital or unknown rutile, which is beneﬁcial to mineral
exploration.
Through PCA of the three databases, PC1 of the ore dataset, and PC3 of the com-
bined ore, igneous and metamorphic rutile datasets, discriminate between Sb-rich Au
and Nb-rich pegmatite deposits by using the variance in Sb in comparison to that of
Nb, Ta and Sn. PC1 of the igneous-metamorphic and combined datasets, and PC3 of
the ores dataset identiﬁes, in-part, metamorphic grade through variation in Zr content.
PC2 of all datasets can help identify source rock through variation in Cr content.
Yilgarn Au ores, including Kalgoorlie-style and Big Bell-style Au deposits are iden-
tiﬁed with high certainty when trace element chemistry of rutile grains are compared
with those from different ore types and background or barren rutile chemistries us-
ing hierarchical clustering of PCA. Rutile from the ore zones of Nb-Ta pegmatites areChapter 2 J.K. P ORTER 97
also distinct and can be identiﬁed with conﬁdence. Rutile from barren sources can be
discriminated from rutile from Au sources with equally high conﬁdence.
Rutile from carbonatites, VHMS, lamprophyres and Au-Cu deposits may not have
as distinct chemical signatures from rutile of low-metamorphic grade barren, felsic
volcanic rocks, and may not be reliably distinguished with conﬁdence.
Barren igneous and metamorphic rocks can be distinguished based on a combina-
tion of metamorphic grade and degree of maﬁc vs felsic input from their source rock.

PAPER 2-METALS EXPLORATION IN
SEDIMENTARY BASINS OF WESTERN
AUSTRALIA :INSIGHTS FROM DETRITAL
RUTILE TRACE ELEMENT GEOCHEMISTRY
Jennifer Karin Portera;b, Neal J. McNaughtona, Noreen J. Evansa, Bradley J. McDonalda
aJohn de Laeter Centre, Curtin University, Bentley, WA, 6102, Australia
bSchool of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Curtin University, Bentley, WA, 6102, Aus-
tralia116 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.1
ABSTRACT
Rutile, a mineral common to metamorphic and hydrothermally altered rocks, retains
high ﬁeld strength elements within its structure in trace concentrations. When rutile
forms in association with ores, aspects of the rutile trace element signature unique to
that ore environment are retained. Detrital rutile chemistry can elucidate information
on the type and amount of sediment sources in a sedimentary basin, the formation
temperature of each source, their provenance with regard to host rock composition,
and their proximity to, and their likelihood of being associated with ore systems. Iden-
tifying a chemical signature as a ﬁngerprint of a unique ore environment is key to the
use of rutile as an exploration tool and geochemical vector to ores.
Rutile is refractory during weathering, erosion and sedimentary transport, allow-
ing it to survive transport long distances, preserving and concentrating it in the sed-
imentary record. Thus, sands, sandstones and quartzites represent viable sampling
mediums for metals exploration using detrital rutile. Here, Au- and base metal prospec-
tive basins of Western Australia are identiﬁed by comparing detrital rutile trace ele-
ment chemistries to rutile from ore and barren rock rutile using the Random Forests
method of supervised machine learning. Detrital rutile grains are classiﬁed into Au-
related and barren rock groups with a >95% accuracy. From samples obtained in
Western Australia, the Amadeus Basin represents the area with the highest potential
for Au exploration. Sample 199418 contains 9% rutile grains that have trace element
chemistries similar to Kalgoorlie- and Big Bell-style Au ore.
3.1. I NTRODUCTION
Decoding the geological history of central Australia is a work in progress; deep cover
and extensive weathering prevent the use of traditional mapping and explorationChapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 117
techniques. The use of detrital accessory minerals, through trace element and isotopic
analysis, has contributed to knowledge of the history of sedimentary basins. Rutile,
an accessory mineral common to metamorphic terranes, incorporates trace elements
that can capture a snapshot of the conditions (e.g., ﬂuid composition, temperature)
through the formation history of a particular metamorphic rock. Therefore detrital
rutile may reveal multiple source rock histories in a sedimentary basin.
Detrital rutile grains are sufﬁciently robust to survive long transport, weathering,
burial time, diagenesis and low grade metamorphism (Salama et al., 2018; Meinhold,
2010; Zack et al., 2004b). Sedimentary processes concentrate rutile, allowing for anal-
ysis of the chemical characteristics of each grain. Attainable information from rutile
chemistry includes Zr-in-rutile thermometry (ZiRGy) which can determine the forma-
tion temperature range of a rutile population. Knowledge of formation temperatures
of entire grain populations can provide insight as to whether grains formed after de-
position or whether they are detrital and have retained their original trace element
signatures (Luvizotto et al., 2009b; Triebold et al., 2007; Zack et al., 2004b). Other key
trace elements that are incorporated in rutile and may be exploited include U and Pb
for age dating, Nb and Cr for provenance information, and Sn, Sb and W for potential
ore associations.
3.1.1. T RACE ELEMENTS IN RUTILE
In equilibrium with silica and zircon, the Zr content in rutile can be used as a ther-
mometer, recording the conditions at the time of formation of the rutile grain (Triebold
et al., 2007; Zack et al., 2004a; Watson et al., 2006; Ferry and Watson, 2007). ZiRGy pro-
vides a direct way to estimate the formation temperature of detrital rutile grains in
siliciclastic sedimentary rocks that otherwise do not contain minerals typically used
for geothermometry (e.g., quartzites). If the sedimentary sample contains minerals
typical of siliciclastics (i.e., rutile, zircon, quartz) analysis of rutile formed after deposi-
tion may yield ZiRGy formation temperatures. However, when estimating formation118 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.1
temperatures of detrital rutile in many sedimentary rocks, it is not possible to conﬁrm
whether rutile was in equilibrium with zircon and quartz in the original rocks and any
temperature obtained using ZiRGy for a detrital grain should be treated with caution.
The ratio of Nb to Cr in rutile has been developed as a rock source identiﬁer (Mein-
hold et al., 2008; Zack et al., 2004b; Triebold et al., 2007), and the relationship between
the elements has been reﬁned for detrital rutile studies (Triebold et al., 2012). Gener-
ally, a Cr/Nb ratio ≥1 is indicative of a source that is maﬁc or mantle related and ≤
1 is indicative of a crustal or more felsic source. Identifying rutile source as felsic can
also help to identify rutile with a sufﬁciently high U content for U–Pb dating (R ¨osel
et al., 2018; Meinhold, 2010), although discrepancies have been identiﬁed in speciﬁc
environments and the approach must be treated with care as rutile grains have been
misclassiﬁed (Meyer et al., 2011; Kooijman et al., 2012).
3.1.2. R UTILE IN ORE SYSTEMS
Rutile primarily incorporates high ﬁeld strength elements (HFSEs), that are of sim-
ilar size and valence state to Ti4+, especially V3+;4+, Cr3+, Fe3+, Nb4+;5+and W6+.
Trace element contents in rutile have been assessed by various researchers in order
to identify a connection between elemental concentrations and type of mineralised oc-
currence, thus providing a ﬁngerprint of speciﬁc ores (Agangi et al., 2019; Plavsa et al.,
2018; Clark and Williams-Jones, 2004; Scott and Radford, 2007; Scott, 2005; Porter et al.,
2020). The most comprehensive study on trace elements in rutile and their connection
to ore deposits was conducted by Clark and Williams-Jones (2004), who identiﬁed
W as an indicator of Au deposits and Sn as an indicator of volcanic hosted massive
sulphide (VHMS) deposits. They developed ternary diagrams to use W and Sn con-
centrations compared to Ti and Fe+Cr+V concentrations to identify rutile grains that
formed in connection with Au (Figure 3.1) and VHMS deposits, respectively.
Other researchers have conﬁrmed that high W can be associated with Au mineral-Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 119
FIGURE 3.1: Ternary diagram showing where rutile chemical analyses plot if
they are associated with a Au deposit. From Clark and Williams-Jones (2004).
EMP - electron microprobe.
isation (Harris, 1989; Urban et al., 1992; Rice et al., 1998), but also pegmatites (Scott,
1988; Cern ´y et al., 1999) and VHMS deposits (Petersen, 1986; Salama et al., 2018). Fur-
thermore, Sb has become known as an important indicator of orogenic Au deposits
(Scott and Radford, 2007; Scott et al., 2011; Plavsa et al., 2018; Agangi et al., 2019;
Porter et al., 2020). In addition to Sn, Nb has also been identiﬁed associated with
VHMS deposits. High amounts of Nb and Ta in rutile are known to be associated with
carbonatites (Chebotarev et al., 2017; Mitchell, 2015) and pegmatites (Cern ´y et al., 1999;
Klementov ´a and Rieder, 2004). Anomalously high Sn contents have also been identi-
ﬁed in rutile from Sn-granites (Scott, 1988).
The lack of unique identiﬁers to ﬁngerprint ore mineralisation highlights the need
to use more than one or two elements in rutile for ore ﬁngerprinting purposes. The
use of bivariate or ternary diagrams to identify combinations of elements and their
differing concentrations in order to distinguish ore types may be insufﬁcient and a
more robust method using multi-element analysis should be applied to chemical ﬁn-
gerprinting of rutile for ore exploration (Porter et al., 2020).
Trace element discriminants have been reassessed using unsupervised, hierarchi-120 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.1
cal clustering of principal component analysis (PCA) using 12 elements in rutile to
discriminate between different ore types and rutile from barren igneous and meta-
morphic rocks (Porter et al., 2020). Nine groups were identiﬁed as chemically distinct.
Four were predominantly non-ore related and were identiﬁed primarily using meta-
morphic grade (Zr contents) and source (Nb and Cr contents) of the rutile grains.
Two groups were identiﬁed as having Au-related rutile, distinguished by their high
and low Sb contents. The rutile with high Sb contents in this group are similar to
those from Kalgoorlie- and Big Bell-type Au ores. Another distinct rutile chemical
group was derived from a source similar to Nb-pegmatites or VHMS deposits. The
remaining two groups were comprised of a mixture of ore and non-ore rutile, derived
mainly from felsic volcaniclastics and meta-volcanics with pegmatites, carbonatites,
felsic rock-hosted VHMS deposits and lamprophyres. These groups are described in
detail in Porter et al. (2020) and are summarised in Table 3.1.
TABLE 3.1: List of nine groups identiﬁed through clustering rutile chemistries
from Porter et al. (2020). The number of detrital grains classiﬁed in each group
using Random Forest modelling, the symbol used in chemical diagrams and
the mineralisation type or rock type that are characteristic of each group are
indicated. N/A – no grains were attributed to this group
Group Total Symbol Ore characteristics summary Non-ore characteristics
C1 835G Au-Cu, pegmatite, carbonatite,
lamprophyrebiotite monzogranite + granite, dacite,
volcaniclastic
C2 24 Au – Kalgoorlie-, Big Bell-style,
Yilgarn AuN/A
C3 57  Au – Tropicana (Havana), distal
Kalgoorlie-style Au, lamprophyreN/A
C4 442H VHMS - Nimbus, carbonatite -
Speewahmeta-felsic volcanic/volcaniclastic
C5 192  Nb-pegmatite, VHMS - Bentley quartz granophyre/granofels, rhyolite

anorthosite, xenolith

granulite quartzite

eclogite
C9 13 N/A Wodgina pegmatite
Total 2443
The results of PCA conﬁrm the importance of Sb in rutile, and to a lesser extent
Cr, in distinguishing Au from base metal ore sources, and W, Cr, Fe and Zr as the
main discriminants in identifying barren rutile sources (Porter et al., 2020). In thisChapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 121
work, these results are used to identify and classify rutile grains of unknown source
using a supervised machine learning algorithm. The aims are to test the trace element
group classiﬁcations by assessing the use of rutile geochemistry machine learning as
a metals exploration tool and to determine if this approach can become a resource for
providing insights into the geologic history of a sedimentary basin.
3.2. M ETHODS
3.2.1. S AMPLE SELECTION
Rutile grain samples were selected from a database created by the Geological Sur-
vey of Western Australia (GSWA), that had originally been collected for zircon U–Pb
geochronology studies (www.dmp.wa.gov.au). Heavy mineral separates and their zir-
con fractions were made into 2.5 cm diameter epoxy grain mounts and scanned using
TIMA in order to quickly identify rutile abundance and size. As rutile is not abundant
in all rock types, sample selection was limited to grains of sufﬁcient abundance and
size for 50m laser spot sizes, with no visible inclusions. From all samples taken from
Western Australia, 28 were identiﬁed to have sufﬁcient size and abundance for further
analysis (Table 3.2).
Samples include detrital rutile from basins associated with orogens in central West-
ern Australia (Figure 3.2). The Mesoproterozoic Musgrave Province, Neoproterozoic
Aileron (1860–1700 Ma) and Warumpi (1690–1600 Ma) Provinces are unconformably
overlain by the Neoproterozoic Amadeus and Murraba Basins (Hollis et al., 2013) in
Western Australia. The majority of the rutile-rich detrital samples, meta-sandstones,
were derived from this central region, primarily from the western Amadeus Basin.
Six samples, mostly psammitic gneisses, originate from basins associated with Meso-
proterozoic rocks of the Albany-Fraser Orogen (Kirkland et al., 2011b). Two Paleozoic122 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.2

194875 psammitic schist A-F Orogen, Ragged Basin, Mt Ragged Fm, Mt Ragged Kirkland et al., 2014d
195237 sandstone Musgrave Province
199404 sandstone Amadeus Basin, Dean Quartzite, Robert Range Wingate et al., 2015b
199408 sandstone Amadeus Basin, Dixon Range beds, Dixon Range Wingate et al., 2015c
199414 sandstone Amadeus Basin, Maurice Fm, Sir Frederick Range Wingate et al., 2014a

199419 siltstone/sandstone Amadeus Basin, Mu Hills Wingate et al., 2014c
