206172 sandstone Kimberley region
206184 meta-siliciclastic Halls Creek Gp, Olympio Fm, Lamboo Province Wingate et al., 2015a
sandstone samples from the same drillhole in the Ofﬁcer Basin were also analysed
(Haines et al., 2013).
3.2.2. TIMA
The TESCAN Integrated Mineral Analyser (TIMA) was used to identify TiO 2within
detrital samples as most chemical phases can be quickly identiﬁed using energy dis-
persive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). This technique replaces more traditional and time
consuming mineral identiﬁcation techniques, such as optical microscopy. Morphol-
ogy, abundance, grain association and size distribution of a grain mount or thin sec-
tion can be assessed in one TIMA session. The Tescan Mira3 TIMA at the John de
Laeter Centre (JdLC), Curtin University was used to analyse multiple thin sections
and 25 mm epoxy grain mounts, using four different EDX X-ray detectors in combi-
nation with a YAG scintillator back-scatter electron (BSE) detector in order to identify
multiple small or rare grains (see Figure 3.3A).Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 123
FIGURE 3.2: The simpliﬁed geology of Western Australia, including sedimen-
tary basins and location of the analysed samples, shown as red dots. From the
Geological Survey of Western Australia (www.dmp.wa.gov.au).124 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.2
FIGURE 3.3: TIMA and EBSD images of GSWA epoxy mount sample
184341M, heavy minerals separate. A. TIMA image of all mineral phases iden-
tiﬁed. TiO 2has been identiﬁed as rutile (red) but may be any polymorph of
TiO2. The black box is the area in B. The epoxy mount is 2.5 cm in diameter
and is represented by the circle. B. EBSD phase image with EDS overlay of Zr.
The TiO2polymorphs are distinguished by unique diffraction patterns: ru-
tile (yellow), anatase (red), brookite (green) and zircon is distinguished from
rutile with the Zr overlay (orange). The white box is the area in C. C. An
example of a TiO 2grain comprised of two polymorphs, anatase and rutile.
LA-ICP-MS analysis (50 m spot) was performed following the identiﬁcation
of the rutile phase (in yellow).Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 125
3.2.3. SEM AND EBSD
Rutile grains identiﬁed as TiO 2using the TIMA were imaged more thoroughly using
scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and back-scatter electron (BSE) analysis for size
and textural relationships, and suitability for further laser ablation inductively cou-
pled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). As the TIMA identiﬁes minerals based
on chemical differences, the electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) analyser was used
to discriminate TiO 2polymorphs. Knowledge of which TiO 2polymorphs are present
is essential as trace elements are incorporated differently into the structures of rutile,
anatase and brookite due to differing unit cell sizes and formation environments.
Imaging was done using the SEM, Tescan Mira3 VP-FESEM with Oxford Instru-
ments X-Max 150 SDD X-ray detector, NordlysNano EBSD detector and AZtec soft-
ware (ARC LE130100053) in the Microscopy and Microanalysis Facility at the JdLC,
Curtin University. Preparation for EBSD analysis included polishing the mounts for
approximately four hours using 0.1 m colloidal silica in NaOH solution. The ﬁne
polish was required to produce the clear diffraction patterns for structural identiﬁca-
tion between the different polymorphs. A thin carbon coat (10 nm) was applied to the
samples and a 20 kV acceleration voltage was used at a working distance of 20 mm. A
step size between 3 and 10 m was used depending on grain size to obtain multiple
readings across a grain in order to identify subgrain boundaries. Diffraction patterns
were compared to a catalogue of known minerals and indexed to the mineral with the
lowest mean angular deviation (MAD), typically <1° (Humphreys, 2001; Schwartz
et al., 2009). Noise reduction for single pixel spikes was performed using Channel 5
software.
An overlay of EDS compositional maps and EBSD images were created to accu-
rately determine polymorph phase, as minerals with identical diffraction patterns to
rutile, such as zircon, can otherwise be misidentiﬁed (see Figs 3.3B, 3.3C).126 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.2
3.2.4. LA-ICP-MS
LA-ICP-MS rutile trace element measurements were made at the GeoHistory Facility
in the JdLC, Curtin University, Perth, Australia. Individual rutile grains were ablated
using a Resonetics RESOlution M-50A-LR, incorporating a Compex 102 excimer laser.
The sample cell was ﬂushed with ultra-high purity He (350 mL min-1) and N2(3.8
mL min-1). Isotopic intensities were measured using an Agilent 7700s quadrupole
ICP-MS, with high purity Ar as the plasma gas (ﬂow rate 1 L min-1).
Two cleaning pulses preceded a 30 s period of baseline count acquisition and 40 s
ablations at a 4 Hz repetition rate using a 50 m beam and laser energy of 2 Jcm-2.
Thirty-four isotopes (24Mg,27Al,28Si,29Si,32S,43Ca,44Ca,45Sc,47Ti,49Ti,51V ,52Cr,
57Fe,60Ni,63Cu,66Zn,89Y,90Zr,93Nb,95Mo,118Sn120Sn,121Sb,178Hf,181Ta,182W,202Hg,
204Pb,206Pb,207Pb,208Pb,209Bi,232Th,238U) were monitored for 0.01 s each. Interna-
tional glasses TiG (Jochum et al., 2010), BCR-2G and BHVO (Jochum et al., 2007); and
natural rutile standards R10 (Luvizotto et al., 2009a) and Wodgina (Ewing, 2011) were
used as the primary and secondary standards to calculate elemental concentrations
(using47Ti as the internal standard isotope and an assumed 59.95% Ti content in ru-
tile) and to correct for instrument drift, and monitor accuracy and precision. Standard
blocks were typically run after 20 unknown analyses. During the time-resolved anal-
ysis, contamination from inclusions was monitored and the inclusion-free part of the
signal was integrated.
The trace element results for primary and secondary standards indicate that the
accuracy was better than 5% for Mg, V , Cr, Fe, Zr, Nb, Sn, Ta, W and U. Accuracy
was better than 10% for Al, Sc, Sb, Hf and Pb. Accuracies for Mo, Zn and Cu were
under 15%. The time-resolved mass spectra were reduced using the Trace Element
data reduction scheme in Iolite 3.5 (Paton et al., 2011, and references therein).Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 127
3.2.5. R ANDOM FOREST CLASSIFICATION
The detrital rutile data were preprocessed using the same methods as the ore and back-
ground rutile samples, as described in more detail in Porter et al. (2020). Missing data
points were imputed with values at 50% of the level of detection for each analysis.
Fifty missing values were imputed using the R package robCompositions impKNNa
command (Templ et al., 2009) using k-means clustering and six nearest neighbours
and Aitchison distance method (Aitchison, 1986) when the detection limit could not
be determined. Extreme values were removed from the dataset if they were indica-
tive of foreign mineral contamination. All analyses from GSWA sample 206172 were
removed for this reason. Elements were standardised and centred by subtracting the
mean of each element from their value in order to equalise elemental concentrations
and avoid those with naturally higher occurrence within rutile from overwhelming
the dataset (Grunsky and Kjarsgaard, 2016). In order to identify elements introduced
by geologic processes rather than by structural control, log-ratio transformation was
used to minimise the problem of closure, the false correlation of components in a
closed system that can cause elements to sum to 100% (Pearce, 1968; Aitchison, 1986,
1999; Grunsky, 2010). Centred log-ratio (CLR) transformation was performed using
therobCompositions package (Templ et al., 2009), followed by principal component
analysis (PCA) in order to treat the detrital and training datasets consistently. The re-
sultant dataset was used in classiﬁcation prediction using the Random Forest method.
Detrital rutile chemistries were compared to rutile trace element chemistries from
the known ore and barren rocks, as discussed in Porter et al. (2020). These ore and
barren dataset,s and the assigned nine group labels form the training database onto
which the detrital rutile were classiﬁed using the machine learning algorithm.
The Random Forest method of machine learning, an ensemble method using tree
classiﬁers, was chosen to classify rutile chemistries because the algorithm is not sensi-
tive to the number of variables, is robust with respect to noise and overtraining, and128 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.2
can give internal estimates on error and variable importance (Breiman, 2001; Gislason
et al., 2006). The Random Forests method is considered one of the most robust general
classiﬁers and yields better accuracies relative to other classiﬁer types (Fern ´andez-
Delgado et al., 2014; B ´erub ´e et al., 2018). Trees were formed using a random subset
of samples, and variables were selected at each node, or branch, such that each tree
made predictions on them at different distances down the tree. In this way, the trees
were de-coupled, were independent of each other and each tree voted on rutile clas-
siﬁcation. The votes were combined by making a forest with a large number of trees
such that the variance within the models was reduced. This improved the test set
performance and avoided overﬁtting the model (Breiman, 2001).
Accuracy was calculated by totalling the true positives and true negatives and di-
viding by all predictions. Accuracy was estimated using the training set samples that
were not used in making a particular tree, or out of bag (OOB) samples, through cross-
validation, by combining the majority votes and comparing the change in classiﬁca-
tion error to the actual classiﬁcation labels.
Estimations of the importance of each element was made through random permu-
tation of the OOB samples. Information gained from the elimination of an element
was obtained by comparing the differences in OOB error. If the OOB error increased
with the elimination of an element, more importance was attributed to that element.
Figure 3.4A shows the importance of each element in the classiﬁcation predictions of
this model.
The R package randomForest (Breiman, 2001), combined with the caret package (Kuhn,
2008) was used to model the data and perform statistical analysis. The combined
dataset from Porter et al. (2020) was used as the training data for model creation and
the group number assigned during clustering was used as the predictor variable. The
training set was divided into a train and test set in a ratio of 70:30, whereby 2074 sam-
ples were assigned to the train set and 945 samples were assigned to independently
test the model. Six variables (elements) were tested at each node, as this consistentlyChapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 129
FIGURE 3.4: Statistics on the Random Forest model of predictive classiﬁca-
tion. A. The importance of each element in classiﬁcation of rutile chemistries.
W and Sb are most important to predicting rutile class and minimising the
classiﬁcation error of the model. B. Confusion matrix comparing the true clas-
siﬁcation of groups to the predicted classiﬁcation. Overall OOB error is 3.68%.
Group C9 is predicted with 100% accuracy, with no false negatives. Group C4
has the highest error at 17.6%. C. Change in classiﬁcation error of each group
(from Group C, Porter et al., 2020) for each tree in the forest up to 500 trees.
Numbers indicate the group, OOB = out of box error. Groups C3 and C4 have
the highest classiﬁcation errors for this model, and overall the model has a >
95% accuracy.130 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.3
gave the highest prediction accuracies, and 500 trees were used to make the forest for
the Random Forest model. The OOB error for the trained data averaged 3.68%. Figure
3.4B shows a confusion matrix comparing predicted classiﬁcations to actual classiﬁ-
cations. Figure 3.4C shows how the error for each group and the OOB of the models
change, as the number of trees in the forest increases to 500.
3.3. R ESULTS
The database of detrital rutile analyses was examined prior to group classiﬁcation in
order to assess chemistry for ore prospectivity based on the ternary diagram devel-
oped by Clark and Williams-Jones (2004). This allowed comparison of detrital rutile
to those with known Au and VHMS ore association. Figures 3.5A and B compare the
detrital rutile W and Sn contents with those from known orogenic Au deposits and
VHMS deposits, respectively. In Figure 3.5A, the majority of W analyses falls within
the Au ore related zone. In Figure 3.5B, fewer analyses have high Sn contents, but
the majority of samples plot within the ore and alteration zones. As many researchers
have also identiﬁed an association of Sb with Au ore (Plavsa et al., 2018; Agangi et al.,
2019; Scott and Radford, 2007), the same ternary diagram is shown in Figure 3.5C,
with Sb at the lower right apex to test for Au prospectivity. Evident within this plot
are very distinct Sb anomalies from very few samples, mainly from the Albany-Fraser
district, which may indicate Au association.
To test these potential mineralisation associations, samples with distinct anomalies
for each of the three possible indicator elements were identiﬁed for further assessment.
Sample 184341 was identiﬁed as a potential Au ore source as it exhibits a strong, linear
W anomaly. Sample 184341 is from a quartzite at the northern boundary of the Arunta
Orogen in the Aileron Province (Figure 3.2). Figure 3.6A shows, in orange, a linear ar-
ray of analyses with a consistent Ti to Fe+Cr+V ratio and variable to high W contents
extending towards the W apex of the diagram. This sample does not exhibit similar SnChapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 131
FIGURE 3.5: Ternary diagrams showing rutile analyses for detrital samples
of Western Australia, as calculated in Clark and Williams-Jones (2004). A.
Tungsten; the dashed line indicates where analyses of W from orogenic Au
deposits plot in Clark and Williams-Jones (2004). B. Tin; the dashed line indi-
cates where analyses of Sn from VHMS deposits plot and C. Antimony. Sam-
ple colours are as in Figure 3.8.
or Sb anomalies (Figs. 3.6B and C). Sample 199418, a pebbly sandstone from the west-
ern Amadeus Basin (Figure 3.2), has a strong Sn anomaly and therefore, a potential
association with VHMS mineralisation (Figure 3.6B). This sample also exhibits anoma-
lously high W and Sb contents (Figs. 3.6A and C). Three samples, psammitic schists
from the southern part of the Albany-Fraser Orogen (194866, 194874 and 194875) ex-
hibit very distinct, linear anomalies in Sb contents. They also exhibit variably high W
contents (Figs. 3.6A and C).
FIGURE 3.6: Ternary diagrams, from Clark and Williams-Jones (2004), show-
ing analyses in ppm of W, Sn and Sb for detrital rutile in samples with anoma-
lous concentrations of each element.
For a more detailed analysis of each of these ternary diagrams, the samples with the
most distinct anomalies for each of the trace elements W, Sn, and Sb have been isolated
and plotted using shapes that identify their predicted group using the Random Forest132 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.3
model (Figure 3.6). The rutile chemistries from the detrital samples were classiﬁed
into one of nine groups, deﬁned in Porter et al. (2020) and these group characteristics
are summarised in Table 3.1 with a description of the rock type typical of each group,
whether or not it is more representative of having a mineralised or barren source, and
the number of detrital rutile grains that have been classiﬁed into each group using the
Random Forest model.
FIGURE 3.7: List of detrital samples showing the amount and proportion of
rutile grains classiﬁed to each group. Group characteristics are summarised
in Table 3.1 and discussed in greater detail in Porter et al. (2020).
Figure 3.7 shows proportions of rutile grains classiﬁed in each group for each sam-
ple. Samples predominantly comprised of one type of rutile are evident (177910,
194714). Samples that contain rutile grains with similar chemistries in similar ratios in
each group can also be identiﬁed (199423 and 199424).
Groups only known to be associated with Au mineralisation, are Groups C2 and
C3. These two groups have the fewest rutile grains attributed to them through the
Random Forest model, with 24 grains assigned to Group C2 and 57 grains attributed
to Group C3. Samples 143800 and 199418 have the most grains assigned to Group C2
and are from the Amadeus Basin (Figure 3.7 and Supplementary Data).
Samples with the most rutile grains attributed to Group C3 are 182416 (5%), 194866Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 133
(41%) and 194875 (48%), all associated with the Albany-Fraser Orogen. Samples 199414,
199418 and 199420 of the Amadeus Basin also contain grains with chemistry similar
to Group C3, but to a lesser extent (1–3%) (Figure 3.7 and Supplementary data). These
samples have the most rutile grains with chemistry similar to those from known Au-
ore mineralisation.
The Albany-Fraser samples have the highest percentage of rutile grains assigned
to Group C5. This group can represent rutile exhibiting chemistries associated with
barren and mineralised sources, however, this group includes Nb-rich pegmatites and
VHMS deposits, which is reﬂected in the high Nb, Ta and Sn contents of the rutile.
Over 75% of grains from samples 185415 and 194874 are classiﬁed in Group C5, as well
as approximately 20% of the samples 199408, 199414 and 143783 from the Amadeus
basin.
The groups associated with both barren and mineralised rocks are Groups C1 and
C4, into which most rutile grains have been assigned. These two groups represent
a variety of sources including barren felsic volcanics, volcaniclastics and crystalline
rocks. The mineralised sources are primarily non-Au-related deposits, including car-
bonatites, pegmatites, Au-Cu and VHMS-related ores. All detrital samples contain
at least one rutile that classiﬁes as Group C1. Most samples also contain rutile from
Group C4, but samples from the Amadeus Basin account for the highest percentage of
these rutile.
The groups primarily associated with barren rocks or rocks not associated with
mineralisation are Groups C6 through C9. Group C6, mainly from felsic to interme-
diate meta-crystalline rocks, are found to the greatest extent in samples 143783 (28
grains), 182416 (12 grains), 184341 (21 grains) and 194714 (14 grains). Group C7, repre-
senting pegmatites and metamorphosed amphibolites and gneisses, are also found in
greatest quantity within samples 184341 (73%) and 194714 (79%). Group C8 represents
rutile grains that underwent the highest grade metamorphism or metasomatism, and
comprise nearly 100% of sample 177910 and 60% of sample 182416. Only one grain has134 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.4
been attributed to Group C9, the Wodgina pegmatite. This grain is in sample 184341.
Rutile formation temperatures were calculated based on the Zr-in-rutile thermome-
ter developed by Tomkins et al. (2007) at 5 kbars, as recommended by Triebold et al.
(2007) for studying detrital samples of unknown provenance. Figure 3.8 shows the
temperature distribution of rutile grains for each sample. Unrealistic temperatures >
1300 °C were eliminated as ablations were likely contaminated by zircon inclusions.
Formation temperatures of detrital grains are accurate if rutile formed in equilibrium
with zircon and quartz, but this can not be determined with certainty for all detri-
tal grains and so data should be treated with caution. However, zircon and quartz are
common minerals within most of the sandstone and quartzite heavy mineral separates
containing rutile (see for example Figure 3.3). Equilibrium can be attained between the
three mineral phases for rutile that formed after deposition and may be distinguished
from rutile that retains thermal information acquired prior to deposition. For exam-
ple, rutile grown or re-crystallised post-deposition forms a population with similar
formation temperatures, i.e., have similar Zr contents.
The range of formation temperatures within a sample can provide insight into the
thermal history of a sedimentary rock. Figure 3.8 presents boxplots of the calculated
temperatures for each sample. Those samples that have a constrained temperature
distribution, in which most grains formed at the same temperature, may represent
samples that formed rutile during post-depositional metamorphic events (e.g., 199408,
194874). Those samples with a wide range of formation temperatures may contain
detrital rutile that have retained Zr inherited from a variety of sources (e.g., 182416,
143784), as discussed in more detail in Section 3.4.2.Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 135
FIGURE 3.8: Boxplots showing calculated formation temperatures for each
detrital sample using the thermometer developed by Tomkins et al. (2007)
at 5 kbars. Lines central to each box represent the median temperature, the
edges of the box represent the extents of the ﬁrst and third quartiles of the
data, whiskers represent extreme values that are not outliers. Circles are 1.5
times the middle 50% of the data (Q3-Q1), triangles are 3 times the middle
50% of the data.
3.4. D ISCUSSION
3.4.1. O RE POTENTIAL OF BASIN SOURCE REGIONS
Rutile Group C2 represents the highest Au mineralisation potential and has trace
element chemistries representative of the Kalgoorlie or Big Bell Au deposits. The
Amadeus basin contains the greatest number of samples and rutile grains that classify
as Group C2, especially sample 199418 with 13 grains, or 9% of the population, that are
likely Au-related (Figure 3.7). This sample was identiﬁed in the ternary diagram for
Sn in Figures 3.6A and B as containing rutile with potential Au and VHMS signatures.
Sample 199418 is classiﬁed as a pebbly sandstone/conglomerate with detrital grains
that are sub-rounded to angular (Figure 3.9C), and contains multiple detrital zircon
sources with a maximum depositional age of 1097 ±22 Ma (Wingate et al., 2014b). Ru-
tile varies widely in grain size ( 300m–30m), but all are rounded to sub-rounded,
which supports a detrital grain origin. A rutile population of almost 10% associated
with Au-ore mineralisation is signiﬁcant, suggesting deposition may have occurred
close to the rutile source.136 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.4
FIGURE 3.9: BSE and SE images of detrital rutile (rt) grains in epoxy mounts
of A. Sample 177910, with euhedral grains of rutile, rounded zircon (zrn) and
quartz (qtz). B. Sample 194874, with sub-angular grains of rutile and rounded
zircon. C. Sample 199418 with sub-rounded to rounded rutile, bimodal in
size distribution. Rutile grains are smooth to pitted in texture. Pitted anatase
(ant) and rounded zircon are also present. Laser holes in rutile are 50 m in
diameter. D) Sample 199424, with rounded rutile, anatase and zircon.Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 137
Sample 143800, in the Amadeus basin, 55 km SW of 199418, contains four grains
(4%) that classify into Group C2. Grains are rounded to sub-angular, indicative of a
detrital source. This is also evident in the trace element chemistry as rutile grains are
classiﬁed into several different groups, primarily Groups C1 and C4. Additional to
the four grains that classify as Kalgoorlie-style Au ore, there are also ﬁve grains that
classify in Group C5, indicative of a source similar to rutile found in Nb-pegmatites
or VHMS mineralisation. If these grains were sourced from mineralised bodies, the
rounded to sub-rounded shape of the grains and their relative scarcity indicate that
the ore body may be more distal from the depositional site than those grains related
to Au mineralisation described above.
The three samples from the Albany-Fraser terrane (194866, 194874 and 194875)
stood out as having anomalous W and Sb contents on the ternary plots (Figures 3.6A
and C). Despite this, only one grain classiﬁes into Group C2, the Kalgoorlie-style Au
ore type. All three samples contain grains that classify as Group C3, similar to distal
Au and VHMS ores, including 48% of the grains in 194875. Seventy-seven percent
of rutile grains in sample 194874 classiﬁes as Group C5, indicative of Nb-pegmatites
and VHMS ores. The rutile chemistries of this group may also be representative of
rhyolites and felsic metamorphic rocks. All three samples are from quartz-rich psam-
mitic schists, and rutile grains with high Nb and Ta contents may be reﬂective of the
felsic nature of the rocks, and not their association with Nb-pegmatite ores. How-
ever, among all groups, Group C5 is the most likely to contain rutile associated with
Nb-pegmatites or VHMS. The basin sources of these samples are discussed further in
Section 3.4.2.
The samples in which the majority of rutile classiﬁes as barren and unlikely to
be associated with any mineralisation are 177910 and 194714 from the Albany-Fraser
Orogen, 184341 of the Arunta Orogen, and 199423 and 199424 from the Ofﬁcer Basin.
These samples group primarily in the barren rock groups C6, C7 and C8, which were
typically formed at higher temperatures and are highly metamorphosed rutile. These138 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.4
are discussed in greater detail in Section 3.4.2.
Rutile from sample 184341 stood out as having a distinct W anomaly when plotted
in the ternary diagram in Figure 3.6A, which indicated a possible association with
Au mineralisation. When classiﬁed using the Random Forests algorithm, the 184341
rutile grains cluster primarily in Group C7, a barren rock group, typical of rutile from
high-grade metamorphosed rocks (Table 3.1). Grains plotted as open circles in Figure
3.6A represent rutile with chemistries that classify as Group C7. Fewer grains in this
sample cluster within Groups C1 and C4, felsic volcanics, and may represent relict
grains that were sourced from low-grade metamorphic rocks or felsic volcanics. Two
grains classify as Group C5 rutile, representing chemistries similar to those associated
with Nb-pegmatites and VHMS deposits. If the grains were sourced from these styles
of mineralisation, the source was either distal to the sample, small or deﬁcient in rutile.
The high percentage of rutile grains in Group C7 (73%) and the relatively con-
strained temperature distribution of sample 184341 (Figure 3.8) could suggest that
many of the rutile grains either formed or had their chemistries reset, during a post-
depositional thermal event, which may be expected in a quartzite. The rutile with
chemistry reﬂective of other rock types could retain relict signatures of original source
rocks, however, the grains are sub-rounded and there is a large grain size distribution
in the sample (Figure 3.3), which is more reﬂective of a multi-source detrital rock.
Sample 184341 is an example of how a false positive signature of an orogenic Au
deposit can be determined if only high W content is considered as a Au-ore discrim-
inant. This highlights the importance of using multi-element discriminants to assess
the potential of rutile chemistry as a ﬁngerprint of mineralisation.
3.4.2. B ASIN INFORMATION
Three samples contained rutile populations with >70% of analyses classiﬁed into only
one chemical group. This could suggest that (i) the rutile grains had a limited numberChapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 139
of sources, (ii) the rutile grains formed together within close proximity to the deposi-
tional basin, or (iii) the rutile formed together during post-depositional thermal meta-
morphism. Sample 177910 from the Albany-Fraser Orogen, is comprised of angular,
tabular rutile (Figure 3.9A) between 50 m and 500m in size. This sample has the
highest mean formation temperature, calculated using ZiRGy at 5 kbars (825–915 °C;
Figure 3.8). Most of the rutile grains are classiﬁed in Group C8, typical of rutile formed
in granulites and eclogites. The tight clustering and similarity of chemistry, combined
with the euhedral grain faces, suggest that the rutile in this rock either had one source,
proximal to the site of deposition or, more likely, formed or re-crystallised during high
grade metamorphism, possibly into the stability ﬁeld of kyanite (a mineral with the
chemistry and habit of kyanite was identiﬁed in the grain mount). This sample is
classiﬁed as a metamorphosed quartz sandstone and younger zircon that formed par-
allel to foliation after basin deposition has been identiﬁed, along with detrital zircon
(Wingate and Bodorkos, 2007).
Sample 194714, from the Albany-Fraser Orogen, also contains rutile grains that ap-
pear to be chemically from one source. The rutile grains are classiﬁed in Group C7,
formed in a high grade metamorphic rock, amphibolite or gneiss, and have chem-
istry reﬂective of low Nb-rutile from a pegmatite. Kirkland et al. (2011a) classify this
as a psammitic gneiss and many zircon grains in the sample are a product of high-
grade metamorphism, which supports the classiﬁcation of rutile grains into Group
C7, a high-grade metamorphic source. According to TIMA analysis, corundum is also
present in the heavy mineral separates and rutile grains are euhedral to subhedral
with similar size ( 100m), also consistent with a high grade, proximal source. There
are a few large, >200m, rounded grains that may represent relict detrital rutile as
discussed further in Section 3.4.2.
Sample 185415, from the Musgrave Province, was originally classiﬁed as a felsic
volcaniclastic sandstone, but has also been classiﬁed as a dacite (Kirkland et al., 2013).
Sample 185415 contains sub-angular rutile grains (typically 60m), and rutile is as-140 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.4
sociated with titanite, the most common Ti-bearing mineral in this sample. The forma-
tion temperature of the rutile grains is between 800 and 880 °C at 5 kbars, according to
ZiRGy (Figure 3.8). This sample likely has a single, proximal rock source, supported
by the classiﬁcation of 79% of rutile analyses into one group, Group C5. The rutile
chemistry of this group is representative of a felsic crystalline rock, which supports
the hand sample classiﬁcation as a dacite (Kirkland et al., 2013). The remaining 21%
of rutile is classiﬁed into Group C1, with chemistry typical of a granite, dacite or vol-
caniclastic (Table 3.1).
AMADEUS BASIN Sample 199408 is the only sample from the Amadeus Basin for
which the rutile trace element chemistry points to a single source. Other samples
show a wide spread in most trace element contents and rutile grains are attributed
to several groups. Seventy percent of the rutile analyses in sample 199408, from the
western Amadeus basin, classify into Group C1 and the remaining 22% are Group C5.
The rutile formed at a relatively restricted temperature range (between 430 and 440°C
at 5 kbars), close to the lower temperature limit of rutile stability (Dachille et al., 1968;
Smith et al., 2009; Hanaor and Sorrell, 2011). The sub-angular grains are variable in
size, with the largest being over 200 m, though many are approximately 60 m in
size. This sample is described as a sandstone and zircon grains have a wide age distri-
bution (Wingate et al., 2015c), suggesting that the zircon grains are detrital. However,
the rutile grains are similar in chemistry, and anomalous for their consistently high Mo
contents and low formation temperatures (lower greenschist conditions). These rutile
grains likely grew, or were recrystallised, as the result of low grade metamorphism
after deposition, incorporating the chemistry typical of a granite, dacite or volcani-
clastic.
The remaining Amadeus Basin samples are similar in that a large proportion of
grains from each sample ( 80%) are classiﬁed into Groups C1 and C4, felsic volcanics
and volcaniclastics, with a few grains attributed to higher-grade grade barren rocks
(Groups C6 through C9). Samples 199408 and 199414 have a larger proportion ( 20%)Chapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 141
of grains in Group C5, and may also be indicative of Nb-pegmatites, VHMS ores,
or rhyolite sources. The trace element content of these grains is variable, suggesting
that sediment in this part of the Amadeus basin had several sources. Furthermore,
the rutile have retained their detrital signatures, suggesting little post-depositional
reworking of the rocks.
RAGGED BASIN , A LBANY -FRASER OROGEN In sample 194784, from the southern
Albany-Fraser Orogen (Kirkland et al., 2014c), 77% of the rutile grains belong to Group
C5, and 21% are C1, indicative of felsic volcanics or crystalline rocks and/or a possi-
ble Nb-pegmatite source (Figure 3.7). Both Groups C5 and C1 have trace element
chemistries indicative of both mineralised and barren rocks. However, 5% of the
grains in this sample classify as Group C3, representative of distal Au ore chemistries.
Grain size is consistent at approximately 50m and grains are euhedral to subhe-
dral (Figure 3.9B). This supports proximal rutile formation under similar conditions.
This sample is a psammitic schist that underwent metamorphism to between 620 and
630 °C, calculated from ZiRGy. The small range in formation temperatures and col-
lectively similar chemistry and morphology suggest the rutile were either formed, or
were recrystallised, during metamorphism after deposition, at upper greenschist to
amphibolite facies conditions.
The two other samples in the southern Albany-Fraser area of the Mount Ragged
Formation are 194875 and 194866 (Kirkland et al., 2014d,b). They are also classiﬁed
as psammitic schists, and according to ZiRGy, they formed at temperatures between
600–623 °C, similar to sample 194784. The rutile in 194866 is most chemically similar
to rutile from sample 194874 with 41 and 48% of rutile classiﬁed in Group C3, re-
spectively, and 41 and 37% of rutile in Group C1, respectively. Grain size distribution
for 194866 is broadly bimodal with one cluster around 50 m, and the other at ap-
proximately 20 m. Sample 194875, has a similar grain size distribution to 194874, at
approximately 60 m, but fewer rutile grains are present in the sample. Rutile grains
in samples 194866 and 194875 are more commonly euhedral and tabular shape, unlike142 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.4
those in sample 194874.
The three samples from the Rugged Basin (194866, 194874, 194875) have similar
formation temperatures, between 600 and 630 °C, suggestive of a common history,
however, there is enough variation in rutile grain chemistries to suggest they were
derived from different sediment sources. These three samples are of interest because
they have extremely high Sb contents, which can be indicative of an association with
Au ore. Random Forest classiﬁcation is more ambiguous as many grains are classiﬁed
into Groups C1 or C5, which is indicative of felsic volcanics or non-Au mineralisation,
such as pegmatites, carbonatites or VHMS ores. Importantly, many rutile grains from
samples 194874 and 194866 are classiﬁed into Group C3, with chemistries indicative
of Au mineralisation. One 194866 grain is classiﬁed into Group C2, with a chemistry
equivalent to those of rutile from the Kalgoorlie- or Big Bell-style Au deposits. If these
grains are indicative of a Au mineralisation, of the three Ragged Basin samples, 194866
has a source most proximal to the deposit, and 194874 is most distal.
OFFICER BASIN Samples 199423 and 199424 were collected at different horizons of the
same drillhole in the western Ofﬁcer Basin (Wingate et al., 2013g,f) and classiﬁed as
sandstones that may be from different formations in the basin; the Wanna Formation
and the Lewis Sandstone, respectively (Wingate et al., 2013g). Sample 199423 has sub-
rounded to sub-tabular rutile grains with a broad size distribution ranging from 20
to 200m. Sample 199424 has a similar size distribution, but with a larger number
of grains in the smaller fraction at around 15–20 m, and a similar rounded to sub-
rounded and sub-tabular shape (Figure 3.9D). The rutile trace element chemistries of
these two samples are similar in that both are comprised of rutile grains that classify
into several groups. The similarity in rutile classiﬁcation ratio stands out as similar,
however, as each group contains the same proportions of grains (Figure 3.7). This
suggests that these samples had the same basin sources and were the same distance
from each source. This may provide evidence that samples 199423 and 199424 were
derived from the same rock formation. This highlights the ability of using machineChapter 3 J.K. P ORTER 143
learning with rutile chemistry to conﬁrm or refute more subjective classiﬁcations of
samples into geological formations.
3.5. C ONCLUSIONS
Rutile is a physically and chemically robust indicator mineral that can be used for Au
exploration via sampling detrital grains and regolith, akin to well-known indicator
minerals utilised in diamond exploration.
More than one element should be assessed to determine whether detrital rutile
is associated with ore mineralisation. Anomalous W and/or Sb contents may be in-
dicative of Au or VHMS mineralisation, but may also represent a different style of
mineralisation or, more likely, a barren rock source.
The Random Forests method of machine learning can classify multi-variate rutile
chemistry from unknown sources into predeﬁned groups associated with speciﬁc ore
and rock types with >95% accuracy.
Sample 199418 from the Amadeus Basin represents the highest potential for Au
exploration, with 9% of its rutile having trace element chemistry similar to Kalgoorlie-
and Big Bell-style Au ore.
The chemistry of detrital rutile grains from a sedimentary basin sample can eluci-
date the type of source(s) and proportion of material derived from each source in a
sedimentary basin, the formation temperature of each source, their provenance with
regard to a pelitic or maﬁc origin, and their proximity to and their likelihood of being
associated with ore systems.144 J.K. P ORTER Section 3.7

cSchool of Geosciences, University of Edinburgh, The King’s Building, James Hutton
Rd, Edinburgh, UK
dThe NJORD Centre, Physics of Geological Processes, Department of Geosciences,
University of Oslo, Norway154 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.1
ABSTRACT
The Bamble Sector of southern Norway experienced extensive scapolite and albite
metasomatism, thought to be related to the Sveconorwegian Orogeny. Trace element
and isotope geochemistry of rutile from highly metasomatised albite and scapolite
dominant rocks, scapolite-bearing metagabbro and albite-bearing metagabbro from
the Ringsjø area was studied. The geochemical signatures in rutile occurring across
metasomatic contacts between scapolite and albite rocks are compared with those of
rutile from less metasomatised gabbros.
Zr-in-rutile geothermometry indicates that all rutile formed at temperatures above
760 °C, suggesting formation at granulite-facies conditions. Rutile grains from all rock
types have statistically identical U-Pb ages (1079.3 ±4.0 Ma). This date reﬂects the
cooling through the Pb closure temperature in rutile during the later stages of the
Sveconorwegian Orogeny in the Bamble Sector. This also indicates metasomatism
formed rutile prior to this age (i.e., 630 °C) and constrains the timing of scapolite
metasomatism at granulite-facies temperatures prior to 1079 Ma.
Rutile trace element signatures are similar in both the albite-bearing metagabbro
and scapolite-bearing metagabbro, but some elements have been remobilised in more
strongly metasomatised scapolite and albite dominant rocks. Rutile Cr and V contents
increase with progressive scapolite metasomatism and remain unchanged during sub-
sequent albitisation. It is inferred Cr and V were released from the metagabbro during
amphibole, biotite and Fe-oxide breakdown during intense scapolite metasomatism
and were incorporated into rutile. The rutile Nb/Cr ratio is affected by extreme meta-
somatism in these rocks which has implications for Nb/Cr signatures being used in
detrital rutile provenance studies. These trace element data, combined with textural
relationships, suggest rutile formed during scapolitisation and may be relict within
albitite. Albite metasomatism is post-scapolite and may have occurred during the
Sveconorwegian Orogeny or as late as the Permian as a low-grade event associatedChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 155
with the Oslo Rift.
4.1. I NTRODUCTION
Rutile is an accessory mineral commonly formed under high-grade metamorphic con-
ditions. The use of trace element signatures in rutile to ﬁngerprint geological processes
in source rocks has grown over the past decade (Zack et al., 2004b; Triebold et al., 2007;
Meinhold et al., 2008; Meinhold, 2010; R ¨osel et al., 2014). The incorporation of differ-
ent trace elements within rutile at the time of crystallisation can reﬂect changes in
wallrock composition, ﬂuids and temperature. Speciﬁc trace elements in rutile are
key to decoding provenance and formation conditions. For example, ratios and con-
centrations of Nb and Cr can point to a pelitic or maﬁc host rock source (Zack et al.,
2002, 2004a; Triebold et al., 2012). Additionally, incorporation of Zr within rutile cor-
relates positively with increasing crystallisation temperature, making the Zr-in-rutile
geothermometer particularly useful in rocks containing at minimum rutile, zircon and
quartz together at equilibrium (Zack et al., 2004a; Watson et al., 2006; Tomkins et al.,
2007). Rutile has an intermediate Pb closure temperature of up to 630 °C (Cherniak,
2000; Vry and Baker, 2006), and can record the timing of metamorphic processes up
to upper amphibolite-facies conditions. Furthermore, rutile ranks with zircon as one
mineral that can incorporate the elements required to characterise age, formation tem-
perature and provenance, allowing better understanding of the geological processes
acting on a rock package.
Changes in rutile trace element chemistry in rocks that have experienced intense
metasomatism is less well documented. Metasomatism, the alteration of rocks through
the introduction and/or removal of ionic species, can dramatically alter the composi-
tion of constituent minerals, including rutile. The Bamble Sector of southern Norway
is an area of intense high-grade metamorphism with associated regional scale scapo-
lite and albite metasomatism. The inﬁltration of rocks by Ca- and Mg-rich ﬂuids began156 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.2
large-scale scapolite metasomatism, followed by the inﬂux a Na-rich ﬂuid, responsible
for albitisation. The timing of these events, and ﬂuid source and evolution have been
studied but is still not fully understood (e.g., Harlov et al., 2002; Bingen et al., 2008a;
Engvik et al., 2011; Nijland et al., 2014).
This paper investigates the change in rutile chemistry during scapolite and albite
metasomatism in the Bamble Sector. Rutile from strongly metasomatised samples are
compared to those from metamorphosed, but less altered protoliths. Changes in rutile
trace element chemistry are also assessed with U-Pb geochronology in order to im-
prove our understanding of the tectonic history of the Bamble region and constrain
the timing of metasomatic events.
4.2. G EOLOGICAL SETTING AND GEOLOGY
Southern Norway was affected by the Sveconorwegian orogenic event in the Paleo- to
Mesoproterozoic era. The Sveconorwegian Orogeny has been described as four sepa-
rate events (Bingen et al., 2008b) affecting all of southern Norway, beginning in the east
and younging to the west. The Arendal event, the eastern-most and oldest event of
this orogenic series in southern Norway, is responsible for the metamorphism, meta-
somatism and deformation of the Bamble and Kongsberg Sectors (Figure 4.1A). The
Bamble and Kongsberg Sectors, now separated by igneous intrusions and volcanics
associated with Permian rifting in the Oslo Fjord, are considered to be part of an up-
thrust crustal rock package resulting from the early collision of the Idefjorden and
Telemarkia Terranes (Bingen et al., 2008b) (Figure 4.1A).
The Bamble Sector is dominated by northeast-southwest trending packages of high
grade Mesoproterozoic para- and orthogneisses (Figure 4.1B). These rocks experienced
granulite to amphibolite-facies metamorphic events during the emplacement of a tec-
tonic slice which caused metamorphism in two stages between 1140–1125 Ma andChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 157
FIGURE 4.1: A. Regional lithotectonic map of Scandinavia highlighting the
Kragerø area as a blue rectangle. Different lithotectonic units of the Sveconor-
wegian Orogeny are indicated. Modiﬁed from Engvik et al. (2016). B. Geolog-
ical map of the Kragerø area showing the main sampling locality at Ringsjø,
as well as Ødeg ˚arden Verk and Valberg Quarry. Modiﬁed from the Geological
Survey of Norway (NGU) map database.158 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.2
1110–1080 Ma (Bingen et al., 2008a). Most of the exposed rocks in the Kragerø area are
reﬂective of upper amphibolite-facies conditions; however, many areas of granulite-
facies mineral assemblages showing intense migmatisation have been identiﬁed in
discontinuous ’windows’ (Engvik et al., 2016; Nijland et al., 1998, 2014). The granulite
rocks show a complex relationship with the amphibolitised rocks as contacts are irreg-
ular and reﬂect pervasive retrogression to amphibolite-facies mineral assemblages.
Several episodes of ﬂuid inﬁltration and veining, causing both scapolite and albite
metasomatism affected these rocks in a NE-SW direction along structurally controlled
slices. In areas where the metasomatism occurred, the original mineralogy has been
completely replaced with a rock composed almost entirely of the Cl-endmember of
scapolite (marialite) or near endmember composition albite (Engvik et al., 2008). The
chemical characteristics of the ﬂuid source during these events are partially attributed
to remobilisation of an evaporite sequence or a mix of crustally derived rocks and
magmatic ﬂuids (Engvik et al., 2011, 2017). It is as yet unclear as to whether the scapo-
lite and albite metasomatising ﬂuids evolved from the same or different sources. The
Permian Oslo rift event closely borders the intensely metasomatised rocks and may
represent another source of heat and ﬂuid that subsequently affected these rocks.
The main rock types in the Kragerø area consist of gabbro, tonalite, scapolite-
metagabbro and metatonalite, amphibolites, nodular gneisses and orthoamphibole–
cordierite schists. The metagabbros have been variably to locally altered from weakly
scapolitised to completely metasomatised to scapolite or albite-dominant lithologies.
Scapolite-bearing metagabbro, originally called ødeg ˚arite by Brøgger (1934), is a Ca-
amphibole and marialite-rich rock. Scapolitisation began as veining following frac-
tures or weakness in rock fabric, and in some areas was more pervasive, extending
for kilometres in areas such is on Langøy and Ødeg ˚arden Verk (Figure 4.1B). Albiti-
sation often follows veins previously exploited by the scapolite and occurs texturally
after scapolitisation. Gabbro, amphibolitised metagabbro, scapolitised metagabbro,
and scapolite and albite metasomatised rocks (all deﬁned in greater detail in SectionChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 159
4.5) were studied from three main areas of the Kragerø area – the Valberg Quarry,
Ringsjø and Ødeg ˚arden Verk (Figure 4.1B).
4.3. P REVIOUS WORK
4.3.1. G EOCHRONOLOGY
Protoliths of the Bamble Sector formed prior to and during uplift and deformation
of the Arendal event between 1545 and 1149 Ma (Figure 4.2). Protoliths of migmatic
gneisses underlying an area 10 km northeast of Ringsjø have been dated using zircon
U-Pb to between 1545 and 1542 Ma (Engvik et al., 2016). Tonalite intrusions, closer
to Ringsjø, were dated to 1294 ±38 Ma and gabbro emplacement was at 1149 ±7 Ma
(Engvik et al., 2011). Furthermore zircon from albitite shows a protolith age of 1272
Ma ±16 (Engvik et al., 2017).
The Arendal granulite event in the Bamble Sector began at approximately 1145 Ma
(Engvik et al., 2016). Granulite-facies metamorphism is thought to have ended by 1098
±7 based on Sm-Nd dating (Kullerud and Dahlgren, 1993). Granulite metamorphism
is dated to 1139 ±11 Ma using metamorphic zircon (Engvik et al., 2016) and using
monazite U-Pb dating to between 1137 and 1127 Ma (Bingen et al., 2008b).
Albitisation is constrained by two groups of titanite U-Pb ages as occurring be-
tween 1104–1100 Ma and 1094–1093 Ma (Engvik et al., 2017). Monazite U-Pb ages
have also suggested two generations at 1101 ±5 and 1078 Ma (Engvik et al., 2017). Ru-
tile from scapolite metagabbro and albitite has yielded ages between 1090–1084 Ma
(Engvik et al., 2011) and 1110–1070 Ma, although these ages were reported as impre-
cise (Engvik et al., 2017).
Phlogopite associated with the formation of scapolite metagabbro was dated us-
ing Rb/Sr and gave slightly younger ages (1070 and 1040 Ma; Engvik et al. (2011)),160 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.3
though this may be due the lower closure temperature of Sr diffusion in mica and is
more likely a cooling age. From these earlier studies, the metamorphic processes that
occurred at Bamble were protracted and complex, extending over 50 million years at
the end of a multi-stage metamorphic event at the beginning of the Sveconorwegian
orogeny (Engvik et al., 2017). A summary of age data for the Kragerø area is given
in Figure 4.2. Not included in this summary is the Permian (265 Ma) Ar-Ar age ob-
tained from K-feldspar associated with low grade prehnite-pumpellyite assemblages
(unpublished Master’s thesis; Velo, 2014).
FIGURE 4.2: A summary of the U-Pb ages of rocks in the Kragerø area, di-
vided into those dating protolith rocks, granulite metamorphism, and albite
and scapolite metasomatism. The dated mineral is shown next to the age. Zrn
- zircon, mz - monazite, ttn - titanite, phl - phlogopite, rt - rutile. References
are as in the text.
4.3.2. P-T ESTIMATES AND FLUID CONDITIONS
Granulite-facies metamorphic rocks exist in irregular and sporadic locations along the
length of the Bamble Sector (Engvik et al., 2016), reﬂecting a more pervasive event
that has since been largely overprinted and retrogressed. Modelling granulite-facies
mineral paragenesis by Engvik et al. (2016) gives P-T conditions as high as 11.5 kbarsChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 161
at>850 °C. However, other studies indicate the pressure may be lower (e.g., 7 kbars;
Bingen et al., 2008b; 7.0 kbars at 795 °C; Harlov, 2000). Fluid inclusion studies indi-
cate granulite-facies rocks have low water fugacities, likely due to an increase in CO 2
(Nijland et al., 1993).
Regional scapolitisation of the gabbro to form scapolite metagabbro is estimated at
approximately 600–700 °C at mid-crustal levels (at or above 5 kbars) (Lieftink et al.,
1994). Fluids attributed to scapolitisation are rich in Cl and Mg (Engvik et al., 2011)
and are associated with elevated Br and P contents, inferred from the abundance of
apatite mines at Ødeg ˚arden Verk (Figure 4.1B; Engvik et al., 2009; Lieftink et al., 1994).
The albitites are formed from Na-rich solutions (Engvik et al., 2008) at lower grade
conditions than those estimated for scapolitisation. Equilibrium of cpx-bearing albitite
assemblages has been estimated at much lower temperatures (410–420 °C) and upper-
to mid-crustal levels (Engvik et al., 2017), and from 350–450 °C at 2–4 kbar (Nijland
and Touret, 2001) as estimated from metasomatised gabbro in the central Bamble dis-
trict. Further studies by Engvik et al. (2017) conﬁrm albitisation occurred at <550 °C.
However, there is a mineral assemblage including prehnite, pumpellyite and analcime
associated with albitite that points to an even lower temperature of formation of <350
°C (Engvik et al., 2018).
Stable O, C and H isotope studies on Bamble area rocks indicate a magma-derived
ﬂuid with a heterogeneous sea water or evaporite-derived inﬁltration metasomatic
ﬂuid source (Engvik et al., 2018). However, these studies, in conjunction with halo-
gens in ﬂuid studies (Nijland et al., 1993) conﬁrm that ﬂuid inﬁltration, although wide
spread, is localised effect. Scapolite is a volatile-bearing mineral and its marialite
endmember contains Cl and CO 2. These species are released when scapolite breaks
down during albitisation. Scapolite metasomatism also mobilises Fe and other met-
als through breakdown of maﬁc minerals (Engvik et al., 2018). Thus, Fe is removed
through scapolitisation, but not albitisation. The high Ti and V contents in albitite
were inherited from the original scapolite metasomatism (Engvik et al., 2018). Albiti-162 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.4
sation had the effect of removing Cl, P and Br, which may have complexed metals,
contributing to metal transport and concentration elsewhere. Therefore, one effect of
scapolitisation followed by albitisation is the mobilisation, transport and concentra-
tion of Fe, resulting in Fe-ore mines found on Langøy. Concentration of Ti during
metasomatism also occurred as Ti remained in the original rocks in the form of either
rutile or titanite (Austrheim et al., 2008). Rutile was also concentrated in economic
quantities within the apatite mines at Ødeg ˚aden Verk.
4.4. A NALYTICAL METHODS
4.4.1. E LECTRON MICROPROBE MICRO -ANALYSIS (EMPA)
Polished thin sections were analysed using a Cameca SX 100 Electron Microprobe at
the University of Oslo. For most wave dispersive spectrometer readings, a current of
15 nA and an accelerating voltage of 15 kV was employed with 10 second integration
times. For trace element analysis, the current was increased to 200 nA, the accelerating
voltage remained at 15 kV and total reading time was increased to 8 minutes for each
point. Different major element compositions were used for matrix corrections for each
analysed mineral grain.
4.4.2. SHRIMP
Five rock types were chosen for Sensitive High-Resolution Ion Microprobe (SHRIMP)
analysis: metagabbro, scapolite metagabbro, scapolite fels, albitite and albitite after
scapolite fels. Rutile grains (30 m–500m) from each rock type were drilled from
polished thin sections and set in 25 mm epoxy mounts. The grains were imaged us-
ing the Tescan Mira3 VP-FESEM with Oxford scanning electron microscopy (SEM) In-
struments Inca X-Max 150 SDD X-ray detector at the John de Laeter Centre (JdLC) atChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 163
Curtin University to assess petrographic relationships and identify areas for analysis
which were free of inclusions and mineral lamellae.
For U-Pb dating, the mounts were analysed in two separate sessions over ﬁve days
using the SHRIMP II B in the JdLC at Curtin University. The method used in rutile
analysis employed an O-beam in order to minimize orientation effects as described in
Taylor et al. (2012). Natural rutile grains with multiple orientations from the Windmill
Hill Quartzite (mount 08-03,207Pb/206Pb age 2633 ±1.1 Ma, assessed in house), were
used as a standard and analysed regularly using a 20 m spot size. For all sessions,
the207Pb/206Pb age of the Windmill Hill rutile standard were within the analytical
uncertainty of this value (population uncertainties of 1.9 to 3.2 Ma, 95 % c.l.) and no
fractionation correction was applied. SHRIMP data were reduced and analysed using
Squid and Isoplot 3.75 (Ludwig, 2001). As the Th content in rutile was <1 ppm,208Pb
was used for the common Pb correction (see Tables 2a through 2e of Appendix E).
4.4.3. LA-ICP-MS
LA-ICP-MS rutile trace element measurements were made at the GeoHistory Facility
in the JdLC, Curtin University, Perth, Australia. Individual rutile grains were ablated
using a Resonetics RESOlution M-50A-LR, incorporating a Compex 102 excimer laser.
The sample cell was ﬂushed with ultrahigh purity He (350 mL min-1) and N2(3.8
mL min-1). Isotopic intensities were measured using an Agilent 7700s quadrupole
ICP-MS, with high purity Ar as the plasma gas (ﬂow rate 1 L min-1).
Two cleaning pulses preceded a 30 s period of baseline count acquisition and 40
s ablations at a 4 Hz repetition rate using a 22 or 33 m beam and laser energy of
2 Jcm-2. Thirty-ﬁve isotopes were monitored for 0.01 s each (see Appendix E, Ta-
ble 3). International glasses TiG (Jochum et al., 2010), BCR-2G and BHVO (Jochum
et al., 2007); and natural rutile standards R10 (Luvizotto et al., 2009) and Wodgina
(large crystal from Wodgina, Western Australia, characterised for trace elements in164 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.5
house and from Ewing, 2011) were used as the primary and secondary standards to
calculate elemental concentrations (using47Ti as the internal standard isotope and an
assumed 59.95 % Ti content in rutile) and to correct for instrument drift, and monitor
accuracy and precision. Standard blocks were typically run after 20 unknown analy-
ses. During the time-resolved analysis, contamination resulting from inclusions and
compositional zoning were monitored and only the relevant part of the signal was in-
tegrated. The trace element results for primary and secondary standards indicate that
the accuracy was better than 5 % for most elements. The analytical precision was be-
tween than 2 and 6 % from most elements, except for Mo and Fe, which were between
10 and 11 %. The time-resolved mass spectra were reduced using the Trace Element
data reduction scheme in Iolite 3.5 (Paton et al., 2011, and references therein).
4.5. P ETROGRAPHY
Five different rock types were identiﬁed and sampled from the Ringsjø area. Two
metagabbro samples were collected: one predominantly comprised of amphibole al-
tered to chlorite and albite (Sample RI-1b, Section 4.5.1), and one of scapolite-bearing
metagabbro (Sample RI07-09-A, Section 4.5.2). Three highly metasomatised samples
were chosen: an albitite, formally albite-bearing metagabbro (Sample RI-1a, Section
4.5.4), an albitite, formerly scapolite fels (Sample B14-17A, Section 4.5.4), and scapolite
fels, formerly scapolite metagabbro (Sample RI06-09BI, Section 4.5.3). Here the term
fels is used to refer to a metamorphic rock exhibiting a granoblastic texture without
preferred orientation or foliation.
Samples RI-1a (albitite) and RI-1b (metagabbro) were taken from one polished thin
section cut from an outcrop at Ringsjø (Figure 4.5c). The main rock type of this outcrop
is scapolite metagabbro (ødeg ˚arite) which has zones of albitite alteration. At the con-
tact between the albitite (RI-1a) and scapolite metagabbro is a zone of albite-bearing
metagabbro (RI-1b) that contains no scapolite but likely was a scapolite metagabbroChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 165
that has undergone incipient albitisation.
The protolith of these samples is a hyperite gabbro that, due to alteration, no longer
remains at the main sample location, Ringsjø. Therefore, samples of the original gab-
bro were collected at the Valberg Quarry. The hyperite is a coarse-grained olivine and
plagioclase-dominant rock, with a distinctive corona texture of olivine, progressively
reacted to form concentric haloes of orthopyroxene then clinopyroxene and plagio-
clase with intergrown amphibole and spinel (Figure 4.3a), plus accessory biotite and
opaques, including ilmenite.
Progressive breakdown of gabbro during retrogression amphibolitised the olivine
and pyroxene. Ilmenite abundance was reduced through removal of Fe, with the re-
maining Ti incorporated into retrogressive biotite and amphibole (see Appendix E,
Table 1). Chains of micron-sized zircon grains, formed around ilmenite at or near
the time of retrogression and are retained within the amphibolite (Austrheim et al.,
2008). These chains delineate the original ilmenite grain boundaries and were pre-
served during amphibolitisation. The area demarcated by the zircon grains can be
used to estimate the amount lost of Fe lost during retrogression (Figure 4.3b, see also
Austrheim et al. (2008)).
4.5.1. M ETAGABBRO
Albite, amphibole and chlorite are the main constituents of the retrogressed metagab-
bro. The matrix also includes K-feldspar, titanite veining and rutile. Titanite exists as
feathery, discontinuous veinlets and also occurs as a constituent of the rock matrix.
Other minor minerals include apatite and zircon.
Rutile in the metagabbro exists as <100m, yellow-brown translucent, subhedral
grains with Fe-exsolution lamellae and amphibole inclusions. Rutile is altered to titan-
ite along grain boundaries and titanite retrogression is more pervasive in the central
area of smaller grains (Figure 4.4a). Rutile grains under 100 m in size have been166 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.5
(A)
 (B)
FIGURE 4.3: (a) Cross-polarised photo micrograph of the hyperite gabbro of
olivine (olv) with coronas of orthopyroxene (opx) and clinopyroxene (cpx) in
plagioclase (plag). (b) BSE image of the remnants of an ilmenite (ilm) grain
replaced by amphibole (amp). Strings of micron-scale zircon (zrn) grains de-
lineate the original ilmenite grain boundary.
nearly completely retrogressed to titanite. Calcite veinlets cut across titanitised rutile
grains and calcite blebs co-exist with titanite along rutile grain boundaries.
4.5.2. S CAPOLITE METAGABBRO
The scapolite metagabbro is primarily an amphibole- and Cl-scapolite-rich rock ﬁrst
described by Brøgger (1934) as ødeg ˚arite (Figure 4.5a) with minor rutile, biotite, Fe-
oxides and F- and V-bearing hydrogarnet. The amphibole is a moss green, Ti-bearing,
Ca-rich pargasite (Appendix E, Table 1). Scapolite grain boundaries are commonly
sharp, exhibiting the 120° angle granoblastic texture. Along a few grain boundaries,
scapolite has begun to break down to veinlets of titanite and chlorite. Clinopyroxene
from the original gabbro has also broken down to titanite, amphibole and chlorite,
though it is likely the chlorite is secondary after amphibole. Amphibole and biotite
also show incipient breakdown to chlorite and titanite, two minerals that are associ-
ated with albitite paragenesis and may reﬂect the onset of albitisation in the scapoliteChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 167
metagabbro.
Rutile grains are euhedral with sharp grain boundaries, also exhibiting a granoblas-
tic texture (Figure 4.4c). Iron exsolution is common along cleavage planes. Trace
amounts of rounded, porous apatite and micron-sized zircon also occur.
4.5.3. S CAPOLITE FELS
The scapolite fels is comprised nearly completely of 100 % marialite (Figure 4.5b).
Scapolite crystals exhibit textures of recrystallisation, with 120° granoblastic grain
boundaries (Figure 4.4d). Scapolite grain boundaries are often chloritised. There are
sparse, rounded, pink hydrogarnet. and pleochroic blue tourmaline grains. Tourma-
line is zoned with greater concentrations of V and Ti in the rim and Fe in the core.
Thin calcite veinlets are present, and zircon, apatite, V-bearing Fe-oxides and quartz
occur as trace minerals. Small, opaque blebs of Fe-oxides are extant within the larger
chlorite grains around scapolite. The chlorite is likely secondary after amphibole or
biotite, formed during a lower temperature event.
The rutile in scapolite fels is large, subhedral, yellow-brown translucent with sharp
grain boundaries, amphibole and zircon inclusions, and occasional titanite ‘ﬂames’
perpendicular to the rutile grain (Figure 4.4d). Iron exsolution lamellae are found
along rutile cleavage planes. Individual rutile grains are cut and have been broken
down to titanite and Fe oxides. Scapolite has, in part, been chloritised along grain
boundaries. In those areas, the rutile with ilmenite has broken down to titanite and Fe
oxides (occasionally V-bearing). In non-hydrated regions, the rutile grains are euhe-
dral with sharp grain boundaries. Quartz and calcite found as veins and in the matrix,
were produced from the breakdown of scapolite.
The main differences in mineralogy between scapolite fels and the scapolite metagab-
bro is the increase in scapolite and quartz contents and the lack of amphibole within168 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.5
