metagabbro remains the same; a high Cl marialite.
4.5.4. A LBITITE
The contact between the albitite with metagabbro is sharp and distinct (Figure 4.5c).
The albitite after metagabbro and scapolite fels has a feathery appearance and contains
ﬁbrous chlorite, K-feldspar and calcite in the rock matrix. The mineralogy is cut by car-
bonate veining and one grain-width quartz veining. The rock matrix is porous, with
intergrown albite and calcite, chlorite and ﬁne, irregular titanite veins. The porous
texture of the matrix (Figure 4.6a) is indicative of dissolution-reprecipitation (Putnis
and Austrheim, 2010) and is not seen within rutile grains. Other low grade minerals
within the albite mineralogy include prehnite (Figure 4.6b), pumpellyite, analcime,
epidote and chlorite. Trace minerals include up to 20 m rounded apatite grains and
V-bearing Fe-oxides.
Rutile within albitite after metagabbro is a translucent red-brown colour, coarse-
grained (over 200 m) with common Fe exsolution along cleavage and twin planes.
Grain boundaries vary from sharp to partially altered to titanite (Figure 4.4b). Retro-
gression to titanite and Cr-V-bearing ilmenite is also apparent within the rutile along
cracks and grain weaknesses. Fe-Cr-V-oxides and zircon are included within rutile
grains.
The albitite mineralogy that has replaced scapolite fels retains the original out-
line of the statically recrystallised, granoblastic scapolite grains, despite scapolite no
longer existing within the albitite mineral assemblage (Figure 4.5d). The rutile grains
of the albitite after scapolite fels are pitted (Figure 4.6a) and subhedral with Fe- and
Cr-bearing titanite alteration at grain boundaries. Titanite and K-feldspar veins cut
through rutile grains and follow cleavage and twin planes. Inclusions are rounded
zircon grains, Cr-bearing chlorite and titanite. Remains of the Ca- and Fe-rich ( ±V ,Chapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 171
(A)
 (B)
FIGURE 4.6: BSE images of (a) rutile (rt) in the albitite after scapolite fels.
Grains are of similar size to those in the scapolite fels and scapolite metagab-
bro, however the surfaces are irregular and pitted. Zircon (zrn) is included
in the rutile grains, which exhibit some retrogression to titanite (ttn) along
grain boundaries. Remnants of hydrogarnet (grt) from the scapolite fels are
present. The albitite groundmass is primarily porous albite with pockets of
calcite (cc). (b) Albitite replacing prehnite (prh). Prehnite laths and titanite
ﬂames, products of biotite instability at low grade conditions, were replaced
by albite (ab).172 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.6
Cr) hydrogarnet from the scapolite fels are found in trace quantities. The hydrogarnet
has broken down to titanite and Cr- and V-bearing Fe-oxides.
4.6. R ESULTS
4.6.1. U-P B GEOCHRONOLOGY
Rutile grains (50 and 500 m) were analysed in situ with SHRIMP over ﬁve days in
two analytical sessions. Rutile grains were imaged by SEM to avoid inclusions, other
mineral contaminants and lamellae during analytical targeting.The rutile age data are
summarised in Table 4.1. Only207Pb/206Pb ages which are within 5 % of concordancy
and have<2 % common Pb were used in age calculations. Statistical assessment of the
data for each sample is also presented in Table 4.1. All near-concordant data for each
sample form a single age population (i.e.: MSWD near 1.0). Analytical uncertainty
in pooled age measurements are largely controlled by the U-content and number of
analyses. Tables 2a through 2e of Appendix E summarise all data collected for each
sample.
Concordia plots of the near-concordant data are presented in Figures 4.7A through
4.7E, along with an age probability plot with all near-concordant data combined (Fig-
ure 4.7F). The age probability plot is symmetrical with an MSWD of 1.01 for all 78
near-concordant analyses. With no data rejection and no evidence of older or younger
outliers, the data are interpreted to conform to a single age for all samples at 1079.3
±3.8 Ma. Given the variable older history of the rocks, this is interpreted as a cool-
ing age at which time the terrane cooled through the inferred blocking temperature of
Pb-diffusion in rutile of 630 °C (Cherniak, 2000; Vry and Baker, 2006).Chapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 173
FIGURE 4.7: Concordia diagrams of all concordant data (within 5%) from: A.
N17-13, albitite B. N17-14, metagabbro C. N17-33, scapolite fels D. N17-34,
scapolite metagabbro and E. N17-35, albitite after scapolite. All concordant
analyses of all samples have a combined weighted mean age of 1079.3 ±3.8
Ma. F. A probability distribution plot of all concordant ages, showing a sym-
metric curve of 1079 Ma (MSWD = 1.01), indicating one age for the entire
data set.174 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.6
TABLE 4.1: Summary of all near-concordant ages for each analysed rock type,
the number (n) of samples analysed, the number of grains analysed and the
average and range of U concentration of each sample in ppm. This data set is
interpreted to conform to a single age at 1079.3 ±3.8 Ma.
4.6.2. T RACE ELEMENT CHEMISTRY
In total, 195 in situ rutile analyses from ﬁve different rock types were obtained over
two sessions including 32 spots for the metagabbro, 38 for the scapolite metagabbro,
62 for the scapolite fels, 27 for the albitite after scapolite fels and 36 for the albitite
(Appendix E, Table 3).
Rutile grains sourced from the metagabbro contain low concentrations of V and
low Cr yielding a high Nb/Cr ratio compared to the more metasomatised equivalents
(Figure 4.8a). Conversely, the most metasomatised rock types, the albitites, contain
Cr and V concentrations approximately 2000 ppm to 3000 ppm greater, respectively,
than that of their precursor rock. There is a corresponding increase in Cr content from
an average of 110 ppm to 2050 ppm, and V from 1220 ppm to 4135 ppm, which
correlates to a general increase in Nb from 415 ppm to 595 ppm; and Sc from 7 to 46
ppm and a decrease in U from 60 to 50 ppm (Figures 4.8c, 4.8d; Appendix E, Table 3).
Iron decreases from a median value of 1090 ppm to 535 ppm. However, some of the
very high Fe results may be due to inadvertent analysis of Fe-exsolution lamellae and
may not accurately reﬂect the true concentration of Fe within the rutile structure.Chapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 175
Similarly, the chemical changes in rutile from those in scapolite-bearing metagab-
bro to those in scapolite fels and albitite are similar to those in rutile from the non-
scapolite bearing samples. For example, the V and Cr contents increase from an aver-
age of 180 ppm to 1660 and 2630 ppm for Cr, respectively; and from 930 ppm to 2500
and 2100 ppm for V , respectively. In the scapolite-bearing rocks, the Sc content in the
metagabbro averages 3 ppm and increases in the scapolite fels to 19 ppm and to 40
ppm in the albitite. There are similar decreases in U contents from an average of 105
ppm in metagabbro to 67 ppm in scapolite fels and 76 ppm in albitite; and decreases
in Mo contents from 35 ppm to 12 ppm in scapolite fels and 8 ppm in albitite after
scapolite fels (see Figs. 4.8a through 4.8d; Appendix E, Table 3).
Ratios of Zr/Hf are systematically higher in the metagabbro rutile grains (median
49) than those of the albitite (median 30). Additionally Nb/Ta ratios, with signiﬁcant
overlap, are generally lower in the metagabbro grains (median 25) compared to the
albitite rutile (median 56) (see Figure 4.8b). These changes in Zr/Hf and Nb/Ta ra-
tios are mirrored in the changes from scapolite metagabbro through scapolite fels and
albitite after scapolite fels as Zr/Hf ratios decrease from a median of 37 to 25 and 24,
respectively. Similarly, Nb/Ta values increase from 36 in the scapolite metagabbro to
44 in the scapolite fels and albitite after scapolite fels. Notably, there is no signiﬁcant
change in the rutile chemistry from the scapolite fels to the albitite after scapolite fels.
The progressive albitisation of the scapolite fels rocks did not produce further change
in the rutile chemistry.
4.6.3. Z R-IN-RUTILE GEOTHERMOMETRY
For each rock type, temperature of formation was determined using pressure de-
pendent Zr-in-rutile geothermometry (ZiRGy) developed by Tomkins et al. (2007).
Pressures of approximately 7–9 kbars were determined independently using Al-in-
calcic amphibole geobarometry (see Appendix E, Table 1) (Hollister et al., 1987; Ham-
marstrom and Zen, 1986; Schmidt, 1992; Johnson and Rutherford, 1989). These pres-176 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.6
(A)
 (B)
(C)
(D)
FIGURE 4.8: (a) Plot comparing the pelitic versus maﬁc source discriminant
developed by Triebold et al. (2012) where data with a Nb/Cr ratio >1 are con-
sidered to be from a pelitic source. Both metagabbros (green) have lower con-
centrations of Cr and V , which are typically elevated in maﬁc rocks, whereas
the scapolite and albite metasomatic rocks show elevated Cr and V concentra-
tions and fall within the maﬁc source zone. The colour legend in this ﬁgure
is applicable to all in this section. (b) Plot showing the Zr/Hf versus Nb/Ta
ratios of the metagabbros and more metasomatic albitites and scapolites. Both
metagabbro samples show consistently higher Zr/Hf ratios compared to their
more metasomatic counterparts. Dashed lines showing chondritic values of
19.9 for Nb/Ta and 34.3 for Zr/Hf are plotted for reference. (c) Correlation
between U and Mo concentrations in rutile, both elements decreasing with
progressive scapolitisation and albitisation. (d) A plot showing the increase in
Sc concentration in the albitite and scapolite fels rocks. There is also a general
decrease in Fe content in the more metasomatised rocks. This is not consistent
as higher Fe concentrations may indicate some incorporation of Fe-exsolution
lamellae within some analyses.Chapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 177
sures are indicative of mid-crustal depths, similar to pressures calculated by Bin-
gen et al. (2008b) and Harlov (2000) of 7 kbars during granulite metamorphism, al-
though higher pressures of 11.5 kbars were calculated by Engvik et al. (2016). Pres-
sure estimates using Al-in-Ca amphibole geobarometry during albitisation are higher
(7 kbars) than 2–5 kbars, calculated by Nijland and Touret (2001) and Lieftink et al.
(1994). The geobarometers were developed using amphibole formed during igneous
crystallisation, not during metamorphic processes, so may not be applicable. There-
fore ZiRGy temperature estimates were calculated using pressures between 11.5 kbars
(Engvik et al., 2016) and 5 kbars to show and compare all possible temperatures in
which the rutile may have formed.
FIGURE 4.9: Box-plots of formation temperatures using ZiRGy from Tomkins
et al. (2007) at 7 kbars. Taking the upper limits of the interquartile range, rutile
from all rock types formed within granulite-facies conditions. Dots within
boxes are average, lines are median, circles and triangles are outliers 1.5 and
3 times the interquartile range, respectively. Number of analyses for albitite,
albitite after scapolite fels, scapolite fels and scapolite metagabbro is 36, 26,
27, 38 and 38, respectively. Legend is the same as in Fig. 4.8a.
No grain proﬁles were performed to ﬁnd maximum Zr concentration as suggested
by Taylor-Jones and Powell (2015). However, the upper limit of the interquartile range
of a box plot (Tukey, 1977) using all analysed spots for each sample was used (Tomkins
et al., 2007) and is considered the conservative best temperature estimate. Rutile grains
considered to be on the boundary between rock types were excluded from ZiRGy cal-
culations. Using the calculated pressure from Bingen et al. (2008b) of 7 kbars, the178 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.7
median of all P estimates, the calculated rutile formation temperatures are between
785 and 795 °C for both the metagabbro and associated albitite rutile (Figure 4.9). Ap-
plying a pressure correction, the formation temperatures would increase by approxi-
mately 20 °C at 11.5 kbars, and would be 10 °C lower at 5 kbars. At mid-crust level
pressures, all calculated temperatures from data at the upper limit of the interquar-
tile box plot range lie within the granulite-facies range. For the scapolite-bearing
counterparts, the temperatures of formation are statistically similar and still at upper-
amphibolite to granulite-facies conditions. The rutile in albitite and scapolite fels has
nearly identical formation temperatures at approximately 760–765 °C, while the scapo-
lite metagabbro rutile yields 770 to 775 °C as the best conservative estimate for tem-
perature of formation. It is likely the actual formation temperatures were higher due
to Zr mobility during retrogression and zircon nucleation (Taylor-Jones and Powell,
2015).
4.7. D ISCUSSION
4.7.1. M ETASOMATISM
METAGABBRO TO ALBITITE Pyroxene, olivine and plagioclase in gabbro are replaced
by amphibole, chlorite and biotite during hydration and retrogression to form metagab-
bro. This metamorphic assemblage was replaced during albitisation to albite, chlorite,
calcite and prehnite. The distinct change in rock mineralogy is mirrored in the change
in rutile chemistry. Rutile formed during hydration of the gabbro, incorporating el-
ements reﬂective of the source rock, mineralogy and ﬂuid. Titanium was sourced
mainly from the breakdown of ilmenite, and the trace elements incorporated into ru-
tile were also obtained from the unstable minerals and source ﬂuids during hydration.
Low Nb and Cr in rutile from the metagabbro indicates a more pelitic source according
to the Nb/Cr ratio discriminant (Figure 4.8a) and the one developed by Triebold et al.Chapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 179
(2012), however this rutile formed from a gabbro protolith. It is more likely that the
maﬁc elements such as Cr and V were scavenged by abundant amphibole and lesser
biotite during retrogression and were not available for uptake into the rutile grains,
giving the rutile a lower Cr-V content and a higher Nb/Cr ratio than expected.
Albitisation changed rutile morphology by increasing the size and abundance of
grains, and changing their colour from yellow-brown to red-brown (Figure 4.5c), as
well as altering the trace element geochemistry. Texturally, rutile in albitite has euhe-
dral to subhedral crystal faces and the pervasive titanite retrogression at grain bound-
aries found in the metagabbro is absent. During metasomatism, there was an order of
magnitude increase in Cr content, a more than doubling of V and Sc concentrations, an
increase in approximately 200 ppm Nb; and a general decrease of Mo and U contents
(Figure 4.8a through Figure 4.8c, see also supplementary information, Table 2).
The complete alteration of rutile from the metagabbro to the albitite, less than a mil-
limetre apart (Figure 4.5c), suggests a complete breakdown of rutile in the metagabbro
followed by renucleation/reconstitution of rutile grains during metasomatism. There
is no indication of partially altered relicts or zoned grains from the trace element con-
tents as would be expected from diffusion. The new rutile grains have taken in the
available constituents of the original rock that were not partitioned into the new min-
eralogy. The source of Ti is the high-Ti amphibole and biotite (Appendix E, Table 1)
as well as rutile and remaining ilmenite already formed in the metagabbro. The in-
crease in size and number of rutile grains reﬂects: (a) the relative immobility of Ti,
even during extreme metasomatism, and (b) the conservation of Ti, originally within
the oxides, biotite and pyroxene of the gabbro, and incorporated within the amphibole
and biotite (see Appendix E, Table 1) of the metagabbro. Rutile is the only Ti-bearing
mineral in the albitite paragenesis and likely contains all the Ti-compatible trace high
ﬁeld strength elements remaining in the rock.
Rutile-compatible trace elements, such as Cr and V , were likely sourced from il-
menite and amphibole from the metagabbro. The incorporation of typically maﬁc ele-180 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.7
ments (i.e.: V , Cr) within the albitite rutile grains has important implications for using
rutile in provenance studies (Triebold et al., 2007, 2012; Zack et al., 2004b). The Nb/Cr
ratio has been used to evaluate felsic versus maﬁc source rocks. The metagabbro ru-
tile Nb/Cr ratio is notionally indicative of a more felsic origin than that of the albitite
(Figure 4.8a), though they ultimately have the same origin. Moreover, the ﬂuids from
which the metasomatic albitite rutile formed are thought to have been derived from a
mixed magmatic and crustal source (Engvik et al., 2018), not a mantle source that low
Nb/Cr values in rutile would typically indicate.
SCAPOLITE -BEARING ROCK SEQUENCE Texturally, albitite replaces scapolite-rich rocks
with ﬂuids either evolved from previous ﬂuids of the same event or from a later Na-
rich ﬂuid inﬂux. The scapolite metagabbro to scapolite fels to albitite metasomatic
sequence exhibits similar changes in rutile trace element geochemistry to that of the
non-scapolite-bearing metagabbro and albitite. Rutile geochemistry in the metagab-
bro compared with scapolite metagabbro is slightly different with regard to a few trace
elements, such as U and Mo (Figure 4.8c), but is similar in Nb, Cr and V contents (Fig-
ure 4.8a). Any original differences in trace element chemistry of rutile in metagabbro
may be due to heterogeneous amphibolitisation and ﬂuid inﬂux during the amphiboli-
tisation event (Engvik et al., 2018) or a change during scapolitisation. In general, the
geochemical changes in rutile of the scapolite metagabbro mirror those of the normal
metagabbro. Their chemistries are similar and distinct from both their more altered
counterparts, the scapolite fels and albitites. For example, V content doubles and Cr
increases by a factor of 10 in the scapolite fels and albitite after scapolite fels compared
to the scapolite metagabbro. Increases in Sc and decreases in Mo and U content are
also detected, just as with the non-scapolite rocks.
The change in rutile chemistry from the scapolite-bearing metagabbro to the scapo-
lite fels indicates that scapolitisation was a progressive process. Initially, scapolite
formed together with Ca-rich amphibole, pargasite, creating the ødeg ˚arite rock type.
With progression, the amphibole was destabilised which left marialite as the dominantChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 181
rock-forming mineral, creating the scapolite fels rock type. The creation of scapolite
fels during the latter phase released Cr and V to be incorporated into newly formed
rutile, as well as V- and Cr-bearing Fe-oxides. The scapolite fels event led to signif-
icant changes in rutile trace element chemistry, similar to those found in the albitite
of the non-scapolite bearing rocks. There was no detected zonation to the chemical
changes and no relict grains remain in the scapolite fels. This suggests a complete
breakdown and recrystallisation of rutile during the scapolite fels phase of scapoliti-
sation. Subsequent albitisation did not result in further signiﬁcant changes to rutile
chemistry, which may indicate conditions required to alter the rutile grains were not
attained and they may be relict in the albitite.
Changes in rutile chemistry after the scapolite fels event are minimal, therefore
either the rutile was preserved during the albitisation event or was destroyed and re-
constituted with similar chemistry if the same species were available for uptake into
the rutile crystal structure. Rutile retains its calculated granulite-facies ZiRGy tem-
perature of formation, which is considered higher than temperatures calculated dur-
ing albitisation, from 350 °C to 550 °C (Nijland and Touret, 2001; Engvik et al., 2011,
2017). This could indicate that the albitite after the non-scapolite bearing metagabbro
may have experienced a cryptic scapolitisation event at granulite temperatures that
changed the rutile chemistry but was subsequently albitised. This removed all trace of
scapolite metasomatised mineralogy in the albitite except relict rutile, which retained
the granulite-facies temperature of formation and trace element chemistry produced
during the scapolite fels event.
Evidence supporting the preservation of rutile through albitisation includes the pit-
ted and cracked textures of the rutile in albitite suggesting the integrity of the crystal
was weakened through an event, but not to a degree that changed its chemistry. The
morphology of rutile is similar to that of grains that crystallised at conditions preva-
lent during scapolite formation. Rutile grains are large and subhedral to euhedral
which differs signiﬁcantly from the mineralogy associated with the albitisation event.182 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.7
The albite, calcite and prehnite are porous which is indicative of coupled dissolution-
reprecipitation reactions (Putnis and Austrheim, 2010) that are not evident within the
rutile grains.
From examples of both the scapolite metagabbro and scapolite fels in this study, the
scapolitisation not only occurs prior to the albitisation, but under differing differential
stress conditions. Both scapolite-bearing rock types are granoblastic, with euhedral
scapolite and rutile exhibiting 120° angle grain boundaries. Albitisation occurs by
inﬁltration of ﬂuids that appear as irregular ’ﬁngers’ that locally replace host rock
mineralogy (Figure 4.10a). The ﬂuid reacts to form albite-dominant rock and leaves
porous albite and titanite ’ﬂames’; minerals without distinct mineral grain boundaries
at this scale. The replacement mineralogy appears to have been formed solely through
localised ﬂuid inﬁltration that became more pervasive with increased ﬂuid interaction
and material inﬂux. Albite mineralogy near the reaction interface is anhedral and
porous. Titanite morphology appears affected by how fast inﬁltrating ﬂuids reacted,
appearing elongated and stretched where reactions were fast and otherwise resemble
ﬂames (Figure 4.10b). This shows a clear difference between the formation mechanism
and/or timing of the scapolite and albitite metasomatism. Scapolite formed prior to
or during a time of non-differential stress, thus forming a granoblastic texture. The
albitite appears to be ﬂuid driven, with irregular inﬁltration and crystallisation of a
lower temperature mineral assemblage by a Na-rich ﬂuid.
4.7.2. T IMING OF SCAPOLITE AND ALBITE METASOMATISM
Rutile dates from all rock types at Ringsjø are indistinguishable and occur at the end
of the Arendal event at 1079 Ma. This is consistent with previous monazite and ti-
tanite ages (end of the Sveconorwegian Orogeny in the Bamble Sector) (Engvik et al.,
2017) (Figure 4.2). This suggests that either rutile in all samples formed at the same
time, within analytical uncertainty, despite their signiﬁcant differences in trace ele-
ment chemistry, or that the rutile U-Pb age records a common event, such as the timeChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 183
(A)
 (B)
FIGURE 4.10: (a) A BSE image showing incipient albitisation of scapolite
metagabbro where scapolite (scp) and amphibole (amp) are replaced by albite
(ab) and titanite (ttn), although titanite may also be a replacement product of
biotite. (b) Albitite replacement of scapolite showing the ﬂow structures of
titanite ‘ﬂames’. Titanite is elongated in areas of faster ‘ﬂow’ or ﬂuid inﬂux.
Neither albite nor titanite has distinct grain boundaries.184 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.7
rutile cooled through its closure temperature of Pb diffusion at 630 °C (Cherniak,
2000; Vry and Baker, 2006). Despite this apparent homogenisation of the U-Pb system-
atics, any differences in compatible trace element chemistry were preserved because
compatible elements were less mobile at temperatures below granulite conditions.
ZiRGy derived formation temperatures (Figure 4.9) provide evidence that all ru-
tile grains formed at granulite-facies conditions, well above the Pb-diffusion blocking
temperature for rutile. Moreover, other isolated packages of rocks within the Bam-
ble Sector have been found to also exhibit granulite-facies formation temperatures
(Engvik et al., 2017). Scapolite is stable at granulite-facies conditions, and is associ-
ated with other Ca, Mg-bearing, high-grade, orthopyroxene, cordierite and sapphirine
rocks also found in the Ringsjø area (Engvik and Austrheim, 2010). These observations
indicate rutile in all studied rock types formed at or following peak metamorphism
that began at 1145 Ma (Engvik et al., 2016) and before the measured rutile U-Pb age of
1079 Ma.
There is an inconsistency between the ZiRGy temperature estimates for the albitite
rutile (>760 °C) and previous estimations of albitisation formation temperatures,
which vary from 350–450 °C (Nijland and Touret, 2001) to 410 – 420 °C (Engvik et al.,
2017) based on pseudosection modelling and plagioclase content. The coexistence of
prehnite, pumpellyite and albite indicates formation temperatures under 250 – 350 °C.
However, the rutile temperatures calculated using ZiRGy at mid-crustal pressures (7
kbars) (Tomkins et al., 2007; Harlov, 2000) indicate the rutile grains formed at much
higher, granulite temperatures. ZiRGy is only applicable where zircon, SiO 2and ru-
tile are in equilibrium (Zack et al., 2004a; Watson et al., 2006). Without saturation of
SiO2, Zr content would be increased in rutile, giving an artiﬁcially elevated formation
temperature. However, quartz was identiﬁed in the ﬁeld and in thin section, so the
ZiRGy estimates are applicable and minimum formation temperatures were 760 °C
and likely higher.
The high-grade rutile grains may have survived the albitisation process and theirChapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 185
trace element geochemistry may reﬂect the granulite conditions of scapolite forma-
tion. Scapolite fels formation changed the rutile composition drastically relative to the
metagabbro and scapolite metagabbro composition, but the rutile chemistry was not
changed during albitisation. The rutile is therefore not part of the albitite metasoma-
tism paragenesis and does not reﬂect the formation conditions or age of the albitite.
There may be a cryptic low-grade event that occurred after 1079 Ma and below 630 °C
that changed the overall rock mineralogy to reﬂect much lower formation conditions,
but this event was not at high enough temperature to affect rutile chemistry.
Prehnite, pumpellyite and analcime are found in, and close to, veins at the Valberg
Quarry. These low grade minerals are associated with K-feldspar that has been dated
to the Permian Oslo Rift event (Velo, 2014). During albitisation of biotite, albite and
prehnite have formed together on planes in biotite laths. This suggests albitisation, at
least in part, was associated and coeval with a low temperature event that occurred
after scapolitisation. This low temperature paragenesis has also been identiﬁed in the
Ringsjø area (Jamtveit and Austrheim (2010), Fig. 1). Magmatism associated with the
Permian Oslo Rift event is found approximately 10 km from Ringsjø and represents a
signiﬁcant source of heat and large ﬂuid reservoir that could have affected susceptible
mineralogy to reﬂect a low grade resetting.
4.8. C ONCLUSIONS
Scapolitisation occurred in the Bamble Sector with the production of scapolite metagab-
bro that progressed to an advanced stage whereby amphibole destabilised to create
scapolite fels, a granoblastic scapolite-dominant rock (Figure 4.11). Both phases con-
tain rutile as a main accessory mineral, but incorporated signiﬁcantly different trace
element chemistries.
Albitisation occurred after scapolitisation, possibly as a related, progressive part of186 J.K. P ORTER Section 4.8
FIGURE 4.11: Summary sketch of the chemical evolution of rock and rutile
from the hyperite gabbro through metagabbro formation and scapolite and
albite metasomatism. Rutile is formed during the creation of metagabbro
and incorporation of Ti from pyroxene and Fe-oxide breakdown at granulite-
facies temperatures. Despite forming from a gabbro, rutile did not incorpo-
rate much Cr and V , which are typically indicative of a maﬁc source. These
trace elements were retained within the formed amphibole or remaining titan-
ite and Fe-oxides. Rutile chemistry within both metagabbros is similar. The
scapolitisation event did not initially change the metagabbro rutile chemistry
signiﬁcantly. Progressive scapolitisation destabilised amphibole, biotite and
rutile, changing the rutile chemistry signiﬁcantly by increasing the Cr, V and
Sc contents and decreasing Fe, U and Mo. The subsequent albitisation event
did not change the chemistry further. The question mark reﬂects the possi-
bility that a cryptic scapolitisation event may have occurred that signiﬁcantly
changed the rutile chemistry prior to albitisation, but is no longer present in
the rock.Chapter 4 J.K. P ORTER 187
the Arendal event. However, its timing is not well constrained and may have occurred
as late as during the Permian Oslo Rift event.
Rutile cannot be used to individually discriminate the timing of scapolitisation and
albitisation events at the end of the Sveconorwegian as all rutile ages record cooling
through Pb closure temperature at 1079 Ma. Subsequent thermal events, including
the Permian Oslo Rift, did not reach temperatures high enough to affect the rutile U-
Pb system, though they may have changed the albitite mineral paragenesis locally to
include prehnite, chlorite, analcime and pumpellyite.
The inconsistency in Nb/Cr ratio within this package of rocks reveals weakness in
the reliability of this ratio as a provenance indicator within terranes that have been
intensely metasomatised. Certainly this ratio cannot be relied upon indiscriminately
and careful evaluation is recommended when considering rutile of detrital origin.
4.9. A CKNOWLEDGEMENTS

THESIS CONCLUSIONS
Rutile chemistry can be used in exploration to identify ore mineralisation. In addition
to identifying rutile originating from an ore-related rock versus barren rock, the chem-
istry can also provide insight as to source rock composition and metamorphic grade.
Rutile is a physically and chemically robust indicator mineral that can be used for Au
exploration via sampling detrital grains and regolith, akin to well-known indicator
minerals utilised in diamond exploration.
Through PCA of the three databases, PC1 of the ore dataset, and PC3 of the com-
bined ore, igneous and metamorphic rutile datasets, discriminate between Sb-rich Au
and Nb-rich pegmatite deposits using the variance in Sb in comparison to that of Nb,
Ta and Sn. Kalgoorlie-style and Big Bell-style Au ore can be identiﬁed with high cer-
tainty when the trace element chemistry of rutile grains from six different ore-types
and barren rutile chemistries are compared using hierarchical clustering of PCA. Ru-
tile from the ore zone of pegmatites are equally distinct. Rutile from carbonatites,
VHMS and Au-Cu deposits can be distinguished from non-ore rutile, but may not
necessarily be identiﬁable from each other or from low-grade barren, felsic volcanic
rocks.196 J.K. P ORTER Section 5.0
Additionally, barren igneous and metamorphic rocks can be distinguished based
on a combination of metamorphic grade and degree of crustal input from source rock;
i.e., felsic versus maﬁc source. PC1 of the barren rock and combined datasets, and
PC3 of the ores dataset identiﬁes, in-part, metamorphic grade through variation in
Zr content. PC2 of all datasets can help identify source rock through variation in Cr
content.
More than one element should be assessed to determine whether detrital rutile is
associated with ore mineralisation. Anomalous W and/or Sb contents may not be only
indicative of Au or VHMS mineralisation, but may also represent a different style of
mineralisation or, more likely, a barren rock source.
The Random Forests method of machine learning can classify multi-variate rutile
chemistries of unknown sources into predeﬁned groups associated with speciﬁc ore
and rock types with >95% accuracy.
Sample 199418 from the Amadeus Basin has the highest potential for Au explo-
ration, with 9% of its rutile having trace element chemistries similar to Kalgoorlie-
and Big Bell-style Au ore. Basins with samples of rutile chemistry most similar to that
of Nb-pegmatites are within the Amadeus Basin (199408, 199414, 143783) and Albany-
Fraser Orogen (194874).
The chemistry of detrital rutile grains from a sedimentary basin sample can eluci-
date the type and amount of sources in a sedimentary basin, the formation tempera-
ture of each source, their provenance with regard to a pelitic or maﬁc origin, and their
proximity to and their likelihood of being associated with ore systems.
With regard Nb–Cr systematics in rutile, caution must be used with rutile from
areas that have undergone intense metasomatism. The inconsistency in Nb–Cr ratio
within rocks of the same gabbroic origin of the Bamble Sector of southern Norway,
reveals weakness in the reliability of this ratio as a provenance indicator within ter-
ranes that have been intensely metasomatised. This ratio cannot be relied upon indis-Chapter 5 J.K. P ORTER 197
criminately and careful evaluation is recommended when considering rutile of detrital
origin.
Rutile chemistry in rocks that have undergone metasomatism can provide informa-
tion on the relative timing of metasomatic events. The scapolitised rock, albitite and
precursor metagabbro contain rutile as a main accessory mineral, but the rutile has
signiﬁcantly different trace element chemistries in each. From this it can be concluded
that scapolitisation of the metagabbro progressed to an advanced stage whereby am-
phibole destabilised to create scapolite fels. Albitisation occurred after scapolitisation,
however the rutile chemistry was not signiﬁcantly altered, which provides evidence
that the rutile grains are relict within the albite. Albitisation occurred after scapolitisa-
tion at conditions that did not alter the trace element and isotopic chemistries of rutile
(≤lower greenschist facies).
Rutile cannot be used to individually discriminate the absolute timing of scapoliti-
sation and albitisation events at the end of the Sveconorwegian as all rutile ages record
cooling through the Pb closure temperature at 1079 Ma. Subsequent thermal events,
including the Permian Oslo Rift, did not occur at temperatures high enough to affect
the rutile U-Pb system, though they may have changed the albitite mineral paragene-
sis locally to include prehnite, chlorite, analcime and pumpellyite.
5.1. F UTURE WORK
The amalgamated database that was used to cluster rutile chemistries and identify
rock types and sources, although large, is deﬁcient in many ore types and rock types.
Future work that could build upon this foundation would include all missing ore and
rock types in which rutile forms. The more data used in hierarchical clustering, the
better these groups can represent speciﬁc sources.
Decoding the history of rutile based on its chemistry is complex, requires multi-198 J.K. P ORTER Section 5.1
variate trace element analysis and an understanding of how and why each element
was incorporated. This means taking into consideration the degree of fractionation of
wallrock, temperature of metamorphism, history of metamorphic events of the host
rock, and the temperature at which each trace element can be incorporated into, or dif-
fused out of, the rutile crystal. The individual groups clustered here can have many of
these factors in common, resulting in similar, complex chemistries. Knowing the gen-
eral history and source of each rutile group can help elucidate the histories of detrital
rutile from unknown sources that have similar trace element contents. Improving the
databases created herein by adding rutile from more types of rock types and ore types
will improve the classiﬁcation algorithms for both known and unknown samples, and
provide a comprehensive tool to improve exploration targeting.APPENDIX A

B.2. CONFERENCE ABSTRACT A-RUTILE U/P B GEO -
CHRONOLOGY AND GEOCHEMISTRY BY SHRIMP:
SOME OBSERVATIONS
McNaughton, N.J., Talavera, C., Porter, J.K., Evans, N.J., McInnes, B.I.A.
Presented at the VIII International SHRIMP Workshop, Grenada, Spain. 6–10 September,
2016.
Abstract published in the proceedings of the VIII International SHRIMP Workshop,
pages 54–56.VIII International SHRIMP Workshop, Granada, Spain, 6-10 September 2016 [7] Cordier et al. (2011) GCA 75, 5203-5218.  [8] Cordier et al. (2012) GCA 77, 515-529.  [9] McKibbin et al. (2013) GCA 110, 216-228.  [10] Ireland et al. (2014) Int. J. Mass. Spec. 359, 26-37.  [11] McKibbin et al. (2016) Meteoritical Society Meeting.  [12] Clayton (2008). Reviews in Mineralogy. 68, 5–14.  Rutile U/Pb geochronology and geochemistry by SHRIMP: some observations McNaughton, NJ1, Talavera, C1, Porter, JK12, Evans, NJ12 and McInnes, BIA1 1: John de Laeter Centre for Isotope Research, Curtin University, Australia 2: Department of Applied Geology, Curtin University, Australia Introduction Rutile generally contains less U than other minerals traditionally used for SHRIMP U/Pb geochronology and yields poorer age precision as a result. However, rutile also carries trace elements, some of which reflect their environment of formation, including during ore genesis (e.g. Clark & Williams-Jones, 2004). Rutile, along with zircon, garnet and ilmenite, is a robust mineral during sediment transport and typically accumulates in more mature sedimentary rocks. Combining these attributes, detrital rutiles in siliciclastic sediments and sedimentary rocks provide a complementary source of information to zircon about sediment provenance. Given the increasing emphasis of zircon “chemical and isotopic fingerprints” in provenance studies, we are considering the same application in rutile. Rutile standards There are few suitable rutile standards available for SHRIMP studies. The earliest SHRIMP work by Clark et al. (2000) used a multigrain rutile standard (Windmill Hill - WH) separated from a granulite facies quartzite. Zircons from the same sample gave much older ages than the rutile, reflecting provenance ages, and indicated that the rutiles were either reset detrital or were metamorphic in origin. Nonetheless, with few exceptions, the SHRIMP U/Pb and Pb-Pb ages of analyses from multiple grains of WH are consistent. Luvizotto et al. (2009) and Zack et al. (2011) assessed a number of potential rutile standards and via collaboration we have confirmed that R10 appears to be the most homogeneous in age and U-content, and has sufficient U-content for our geochronology purposes.  SHRIMP methodology The procedures for SHRIMP analysis of rutile have been previously published (Clark et al., 2000; Taylor et al., 2012). One key observation is that rutile excludes Th from its structure, allowing common Pb corrections by the 208-correction method with far greater precision than the more commonly used 204-correction method. However, rutile analysis by SHRIMP suffers from crystal orientation effects, which not only perturbs U/Pb calibrations (Taylor et al., 2012) but also makes measurements of U-contents uncertain as the count-rate on the reference peak (Ti3O3+ at mass 192) varies by >4, depending on orientation alone.  The SHRIMP community generally uses an O2- primary beam for routine U/Pb geochronology, which is thought to give more consistent data for standards and unknowns, compared to O-. All previous SHRIMP studies of rutile utilise a primary beam of O2-. Our preliminary studies of rutile analysis by SHRIMP using both a O2- and O- primary beam, on the same grains during the same analytical session, show much less variation in the 192 reference peak count-rate per nanoamp for the O- primary beam compared to O2- (Fig. 1). Further, the uncertainty in the U/Pb calibration for the O-  beam data is comparable to O2- beam data, suggesting the orientation effect observed in data collected with a O- primary beam is minimal or absent. We further note that the 208-corrected 207Pb/206Pb age for the O2- and O- data collected on WH during the same session are indistinguishable in accuracy and precision, suggesting there is no apparent advantage using the O2- primary beam, as uniformly done with zircons.  abstracts, pag. "54218 J.K. P ORTERVIII International SHRIMP Workshop, Granada, Spain, 6-10 September 2016 
% Figure 1. Ti3O3+ (at mass 192) counts per second, per nanoamp of primary beam, for data collected with an O2- and O- primary beam from the same grains of the Windmill Hill rutile standard. The grains are in random orientation.  However, as O2- primary beam-derived data is entrenched in routine SHRIMP U/Pb geochronology and trace element analyses in rutile are referenced to the mass 192 peak which varies by >4, we seek to address the problem of correcting for the rutile orientation effect from O2--derived data. To do this, it is necessary to have a rutile standard which is homogeneous in a trace element of interest. The multigrain WH standard is unlikely to be completely homogeneous in trace elements, but initial LA-ICPMS data shows only 7.5% variation (2σ; n=28 out of 28) from the reference value for U (Clark et al., 2000). There is similarly a coherent correlation between the apparent U-content and Ti3O3+ from SHRIMP data (Fig. 2) confirming that the U-content of WH grains is reasonably constant and the apparent variation (in SHRIMP data) may be due to orientation effects alone.  Trace elements in rutile Tungsten and Sn are trace elements in rutile that appear to be reliable fingerprints of mineralisation (Clark & Williams-Jones, 2004; Meinhold 2010). Hence an exploration strategy for gold is: (i) stream sediment sampling, (ii) rutile separation, and (iii) analysis for W without Sn, whereas Sn+W enrichment may reflect base metal mineralisation. As rutiles that formed during mineralisation also preserve the age of mineralisation, it is desirable to measure both age and W-Sn-contents during the same analysis. Tungsten can be measured in a rutile SHRIMP run table at both mass 200 (WO+) and 216 (WO2+), where it is normally sufficiently abundant to peak centre. However, as with U, the orientation effect from using the O2- primary beam must be corrected for. The count-rate for the most abundant Sn species at mass 252 (Sn2O+) is too low for peak-centring measurements in all but Sn-rich rutiles. Conclusions Protocols for rutile geochronology and geochemical analyses by SHRIMP may have to be reconsidered in the light of observations presented herein.

Contributions to Mineralogy and Petrology 162, 515-530. The δ18O zircon isotope composition & U-Pb geochronology on SHRIMP IIe/MC - An example from the foreland of the Variscan orogenic belt (S Poland) Mikulski, SZ1, Krzemińska, E1 and Czupyt, Z1 1. Polish Geological Institute- National Research Institute, Warszawa, Poland  U-Pb age analyses combined with oxygen isotopic ratios on dated zircons grains becomes high effective analytical routine being increasingly used in regional geological investigations. The microanalytical study of zircon oxygen isotopic composition expresses as δ18O, allows discriminating among possible sources of magma origin in terms of possible contributions of mantle and crustal components and detecting the roles of assimilation and magma mixing and potential hydrothermal influence (Bindeman, 2008). In this study we used a narrow range of δ18O = 5.3±0.3‰, characteristic for mantle crystallized zircons (Valley, 2003), as a reference of relative mantle vs. crustal melt interactions. Every incorporation of higher δ18O material (e.g. supracrustal rocks) that is crustal contamination can strongly affect oxygen isotopes in igneous rocks resulted in modification of diagnostic values towards higher δ18O in magmatic zircon. Typical Phanerozoic I-type granitoids, which were formed by melting of igneous rocks derived from an arc processes tend to, have δ18O values below 9‰. In contrast S-type granitoids derived by melting of clay- rich sedimentary rocks have higher values of δ 18O up to 15 ‰. The U-Pb dating’s of igneous rocks associated with orogenic processes, and studies of their petrogenesis on the basis of δ18O isotopic composition measured on the exactly the same spot may provide valuable information on the magma genesis, as well as the overall evolution of a crustal blocks. We present a new set of integrated U-Pb and O isotope data of zircon samples derived from the Małopolska Block (MB) of Variscan Foreland, from the area known as one of the Baltica’s proximal terrane. Although U-Pb zircon age results achieved on SHRIMP II were recently published (Żelażniewicz et al., 2008), but U-Pb & O isotope investigation in the considering area of the MB remains unique. Along the SW margin of the (MB) in the vicinity of the Krakow–Lubliniec Fault Zone (KLFZ), silicic calc-alkaline igneous plutons intruded from c.a. 310 Ma to 290 Ma (206Pb/238U, mean age 300.3 ±3.2 Ma for n=18), with no record of inherited components. The presence of euhedral to subhedral cores in some zircon grains compared with particular patterns of the U-Pb results  has been interpreted as two stages of zircon growth at 304 ±2 Ma and then  at  294 ±3 Ma. In general the MB magmatism was coeval with post-collisional granite intrusions in the Central European Variscides (op cit.). In the considering area of the KLFZ, especially on the MB occurs porphyry Mo-Cu-W mineralization. abstracts, pag. "56220 J.K. P ORTERB.3. CONFERENCE ABSTRACT B-RUTILE GEOCHEM -
ISTRY IN ORE SYSTEMS –CONSIDERATIONS FOR
METAL EXPLORATION
Porter, J.K., Evans, N.J., McDonald, B., Talavera, C., McNaughton, N.J., Kirkland, C.L.,
Jourdan, F. and McInnes, B.I.
Presented at the Goldschmidt 2017 Conference, Paris, France, 13–18 August, 2017.
Abstract available online in the Goldschmidt 2017 Archive.Goldschmidt2017 Abstract  
 
Rutile geochemistry  in ore systems – 
considerations for  metal exploration  
J. K. PORTER1*, N. J. EVANS1, B. MCDONALD1, C. 
TALAVERA1, N. J. MCNAUGHTON1, C. L. KIRKLAND1, F. 
JOURDAN1 AND B.I.  MCINNES1 
1Curtin University, Bentley, W A, 6102, Australia 
(*jennifer.k.porter@postgrad.curtin.edu.au ,) 
 
Rutile is an important indicator mineral  for some ore 
types , retaining  trace element geochemistry and U-Pb 
isotopes related to its  formation environment. Fo rmed in 
hydrothermal environments, rutile is commonly associated 
with metal deposition and may ‘fingerprint’ ore-types 
through incorporation of a unique  set of  trace element s 
including U which allows age determination . 
Like zircon, rutile is mechanically a nd chemically robust, 
surviving sediment transport and weathe ring, potentially 
preserving ore f ormation information  in distal sediments . 
Hence, r utile may serve as a means to extend the footprint 
for metals exploration through analysis of detri tal sediment s 
and their lithified and metamorphosed equivalents , 
potentially exposing traces of mineral deposits that are 
currently undetectable at the current surface . 
In a cas e study of the utility of r utile, siliciclastic rocks  
(mainly meta -sandstones and quartzite s) from basins in  
Western Australia  have been a nalyse d and compared with 
rutiles sourced from known Au deposits. While some detrital 
rutiles can be >  1 mm in size, many rutiles found in Au 
deposits are commonly < 25 µm and may not be preserved  in 
the detrital rock record. Increased frequency of other TiO 2 
polymorphs  (anatase and brookite)  in detri tal samples  are 
distinguish ed using EBSD  (electron backscatter diffra ction) 
and likely reflect burial, diagenesis, weathering and/or metamorphism in the history of  detrital samples. In addit ion 
to trace element fingerprint ing of the formation environment, 
other internal structures can also be identified  using EBSD , 
provid ing further information on grain and/or host rock 
history . 
Rutile trace element signatures were  determined in situ 
using  LA-ICPMS, calibrated to  glasses and natural rutile 
standards.  Trace elements concentrations of W ± Sb are 
assessed as the most reliable Au  ore indicators . Combined 
with Zr -in-rutile geothermometry , U-Pb ages derived from 
LA-ICPMS a nd SHRIMP , and the geological context of the 
sample , the trace elements in rutiles provide important 
information on the prove nance, history and metal  
association s of detrital  rutile -bearing siliciclastic rocks. 
 Appendix B J.K. P ORTER 223B.4. CONFERENCE ABSTRACT C-RUTILE ISOTOPE
AND TRACE ELEMENT GEOCHEMISTRY THROUGH
ALBITITE METASOMATISM OF META -GABBRO ,
BAMBLE REGION ,SOUTHERN NORWAY
Porter, J.K., McNaughton, N.J., Evans, N.J., Talavera, C., McDonald, B., Austrheim, H.
Presented at the 2017 TIGeR Conference, Timescales of Geological Processes, Perth, Australia,
13–15 September, 2017.
Abstract published in the proceedings of the 2017 TIGeR Conference, Timescales of
Geological Processes, pp. 66–67. 66 Rutile isotope and trace element geochemistry through albitite 
metasomatism of meta -gabbro, Bamble region, southern Norway  
 
J. K. Porter1*, N. J. McNaughton1, N. J. Evans1, B. McDonald1, C. Talavera1, and H. 
Austrheim2 
1Curtin University, Bentley, WA, 6102, Australia  
2University of Oslo, P.O. Box 1048, Blindern, 0316, Norway  
 (*jennifer.k.porter@p ostgrad.curtin.edu.au ,) 
 
 
Rutile is an accessory mineral commonly formed at high -grade metamorphic conditions. The 
incorporation of different trace elements within rutile at the time of formation gives insights 
into provenance. Ratios and concentrations of  Nb and Cr typically indicate felsic vs mafic 
hostrock source (Zack et al., 2002; Zack et al., 2004a; Triebold et al., 2012) , while Zr -in-rutile 
content is used as a geothermometer (Zack et a l., 2004b; Watson et al., 2006; Tomkins et al., 
2007) . Rutile is also a useful U -Pb geochronometer and has an intermediate closure 
temperature of approximately 500 -600 °C (Cherniak, 2000; Vry and Baker, 2006) . Rutile 
potentially has unique properties to characterise the t imeframe of geological processes.  
 
The Bamble sector of southern Norway is dominated by northeast -southwest trending 
packages of Mesoproterozoic para - and orthogneisses. These rocks underwent granulite to 
amphibolite -facies metamorphic events caused by the  Sveconorwegian orogeny (1.25 – 0.9 
Ga). Several episodes of fluid infiltration and veining cross -cut these rocks, causing both 
scapolitic and albititic metasomatism. In areas where the albitite replacement occurred, the 
mineralogy is almost entirely of ne ar-endmember composition albite (Engvik et al., 2008) . 
The chemical characteristics of the source fluids during these event s are partially attributed to 
fluid mobilisation through an evaporite sequence (Engvik et al., 2011) . 
 
The ages and trace element geochemistry of rutile across a sharp boundary between a meta -
gabbro and a completely replaced albitite were studied using SHRIMP and LA -ICPMS. The 
U-Pb ages for rutile (SHRIMP) in the meta -gabbro and the albitite are statistically the same, 
at 1079 ± 4 Ma. As rutile underwent significant geochemical change during metas omatism, 
this implies that metasomatism occurred before 1079 Ma and that the age reflects cooling of 
the rutile during the later stages of the Sveconorwegian orogeny.  
 
Zr-in-rutile geothermometry (Tomkins et al., 2007)  suggests that the rutile formed in the 
meta -gabbro and the albitite at temperatures above 750 °C. Therefore, it is interpreted the 
rutile formed or recrystallised in both the meta -gabbro and albitite durin g granulite -facies 
conditions. Compatible trace elements were also incorporated under these conditions, prior to 
cooling below the rutile closure temperature for Pb diffusion.  
 
However, the rutile Cr and V contents differ, with the albitite showing an orde r of magnitude 
higher Cr and V contents over its meta -gabbro precursor. The Cr and V source is explained by 
the breakdown of ilmenite and magnetite in the meta -gabbro, which is absent in the albitite. 
Some traditional interpretations of rock provenance use  the Nb/Cr ratio (Zack et al., 2004a; 
Meinhold, 2010; Trieb old et al., 2012) , as high Cr content typically indicates a more mafic 
source. Given the observed effects of metasomatism, this method should be questioned as it 
may provide a chemical indicator of metasomatism rather than provenance source.  
 
References

GEOCHEMISTRY IN AU EXPLORATION
Porter, J.K., McNaughton, N.J., Evans, N.J., Talavera, C., McDonald, B.
Presented at the Resources for Future Generations (RFG) Conference, Vancouver, B.C., Canada,
June 16–21, 2018.
Abstract available online on the RFG (Resources for Future Generations) 2018 web-
site.

-
 
Detrital rutile geochemistry in Au exploration
 
 
Jennifer Karin Porter 
-
 
Curtin University
 
Neal McNaughton 
-
 
Curtin University
 
Noreen Evans 
-
 
Curtin University
 
Cristina Talavera 
-
 
Curtin University
 
Brad McDonald 
-
 
Curtin University
 
 
Rutile 
–
 
a polymorph of TiO
2
 
–
 
retains high field strength elements within its structure in trace 
concentrations. The concentration of each trace 
element reflects formation conditions such as 
original lithology, mineralogy, formation temperature and fluid composition. Rutile typically forms in 
metamorphic and hydrothermal environments, but when it forms in association with certain types of 
hydrother
mal ores, some aspects of the rutile trace element signature are unique to that ore 
environment. Additionally, rutile can contain sufficient U for U
-
Pb dating, so rutile associated with 
some ore deposits can be used as an age and chemical ‘fingerprinting’ 
exploration tool.
 
 
Rutile is refractory during weathering, erosion and sedimentary transport, allowing it to be 
transported long distances, preserved in the sedimentary record, and concentrated in medium
-
 
to 
coarse
-
grained clastic sediments and rocks. Thus
 
sands, sandstones and quartzites represent 
viable sampling mediums for Au exploration using detrital rutile.
 
 
This study seeks to identify Au
-
prospective basins within Western Australia by analysing rutile 
grains in metasandstones/quartzites using in situ
 
LA
-
ICPMS. The geochemical fingerprints of 
detrital rutile are compared to those of rutile from various types of known ore deposits in Western 
Australia. Gold
-
related rutile can be distinguished from rutile formed in other environments using 
their W
-
Sb
-
Sn 
characteristics. This chemical fingerprint, along with provenance, age and formation 
temperature information allow for a reconnaissance assessment of Au
-
prospectivity in the 
sedimentary basins of Western Australia.
 
230 J.K. P ORTERB.6. CONFERENCE ABSTRACT E-RUTILE GEOCHEM -
ISTRY IN GOLD EXPLORATION .
Porter, J.K., Talavera, C., McNaughton, N.J., Evans, N.J., McDonald, B., McInnes, B.
Presented as part of the D.C. Pear McPhail Memorial Symposium at the XXII Meeting of the
International Mineralogical Association, Melbourne, Australia, August 13–17, 2018.
Abstract published in the proceedings of the XXII Meeting of the International Min-
eralogical Association, pg 43.ORAL PRESENTATIONS   |  CONCURRENT SESSION PRESENTATIONSD.C. Bear McPhail Memorial Symposium – a celebration of Bear’s legacy as a scientist and mentor
Rutile geochemistry in gold exploration 
Jennifer Porter1, Cristina Talavera1, Neal McNaughton1, Noreen Evans1, Bradley McDonald1, Brent McInnes1
1John de Laeter Centre for Isotope Research, Curtin University, Bentley, Australia
Rutile	inherits	trace	element	geochemistry	that	reflects	its	natural	formation	environment.	This	allows	geochemical	distinction	between	metamorphic,	
igneous and ore-related rutile grains. Rutile is also a physically and chemically robust mineral that survives erosion and sediment transport, often concentrating	as	placer	deposits	in	streams,	rivers	and	beaches.	It	also	survives	in	the	regolith.	Importantly,	the	geochemical	“fingerprint”	of	its	formation is faithfully transported to the sedimentary depositional environment and, for the most part, survives subsequent burial, diagenesis and metamorphism until medium-high grade.
Detrital	rutile	grains	can	survive	transport	of	>	100	kms	and,	as	such,	potentially	provide	a	distal	footprint	to	metalliferous	ores	which	is	far	larger	than	
that	of	any	other	mineral;	akin	to	the	scale	of	transport	of	some	diamond	indicator	minerals.	As	such,	rutile	may	be	the	optimal	detrital	mineral	for	both	greenfields	and	brownfields	metals	exploration,	and	exploration	through	surficial	cover	and	regolith.	To	test	this	supposition,	the	geochemical	characteristics of rutile from a range of formation environments have been determined by in situ LA-ICPMS analyses, and U/Pb ages determined by SHRIMP.
Many hydrothermal gold deposits have rutile as an ore-associated mineral. Most gold deposits (so far studied) have rutile grains less than 50 microns 
in size, which limit their transport potential. However, some major deposits in medium-high metamorphic grade settings have coarser (i.e. > 100-200 microns) rutile grains. Coarser, gold-related rutile are characterised by high W and lower Sn vs Sb/W and Nb-Ta characteristics than pegmatitic rutile. Only rutile from gold ores and pegmatites consistently has W-contents greater than about 5,000 ppm.
The temperature of formation of rutile via Zr-in-rutile geothermometry and U/Pb geochronology (potentially) provides the age of rutile formation, both 
of	which	can	be	related	to	the	P-T	and	4D	framework	of	the	terrane	being	explored	to	constrain	exploration	models.	However,	rutile	U/Pb	geochronology	is	more	susceptible	to	modification	by	post-depositional	events	such	as	metamorphism,	simply	because	radiogenic	Pb	is	an	incompatible	element	in	the rutile structure compared to the more compatible elements (e.g. W, Sn, Sb, Ta, Nb) which are incorporated into rutile at the time of formation.
The attributes of rutile described above potentially provide a new or hitherto underutilised tool for gold exploration. We present an example of the 
preservation	of	gold-related	rutile	in	surficial	sediments	from	the	eastern	Yilgarn,	WA.	
IMA2018	Abstract	book
43Contents pageAppendix B J.K. P ORTER 233B.7. CONFERENCE ABSTRACT F-ASSESSING THE
EFFECT OF RUTILE CRYSTALLOGRAPHIC ORIEN -
TATION ON SIMS OXYGEN ISOTOPES
Kennedy, Allen K., Talavera, Cristina, Porter, J.K.
Presented as part of the 9thInternational SHRIMP Workshop, Gyeongju, South Korea. 10–15
September, 2018Assessing the effect of rutile crystallographic orientation on SIMS oxygen isotopes Allen K. Kennedy,1 Cristina Talavera,2,1 J. K. Porter1 1John de Laeter Center, Curtin University, Perth, WA, Australia 2School of Geosciences, University of Edinburgh, The King’s Building, James Hutton Road, Edinburgh, UK *Email address: A.Kennedy@exchange.curtin.edu.au Introduction Crystallographic orientation effects on oxygen isotope ratio and U-Pb age measurements have been studied in oxides, phosphates, sulphides and silicates (Wingate and Compston, 2000; Schmitt and Zack, 2012; McNaughton et al., 2016; Martin et al., 2014; Bonamicci et al. 2014; Isa et al. 2017; Rubatto et al 2014). We have studied the effect of crystallographic orientation on oxygen isotope ratios in rutile.  Reference Material (RM) and Techniques  We used three rutile, CA, MKR and RUTNOR, for which we have conventional 18O/16O data,, as RM while assessing four potential RM (WOD, MOZI, ASONGO and WHQ). The oxygen isotope SHRIMP technique of Ickert et al (2014) was followed. No e-gun was required as rutile is conductive. Standard EBSD techniques (Schwartz et al., 2000) were used.  Results  Figure 1 shows data collected over a 12 hr period from a single large ~500 µm chip of CA. Similar internal precision and reproducibility were obtained for individual chips of MOZI (δ18O VSMOW  = 12.09 ± 0.41 ‰ (2s), MSWD= 0.66) and WOD (δ18O VSMOW  = 1.80 ± 0.34 ‰ (2s), MSWD= 0.33) on the same mount, during the same session. 
 Figure 1. δ18O data for the CA rutile RM collected over 12hrs.  
236 J.K. P ORTERA second large chip of MOZI, run concurrently, gave significantly different results, with 25 analyses giving a weighted mean δ18O VSMOW = 12.93 ± 0.43 ‰ (2s), MSWD= 0.12. To test that this difference was due to a different crystallographic orientation, we constructed a mount containing 10-12 chips or grains of each of the MKR, MOZI, RUTNOR, WHQR and WOD rutile, with different crystallographic orientations. An example of our analytical results on this mount is shown in Fig. 2, which shows the data collected on five chips of MKR during a 20 hr analytical session. There is a 2 ‰ range in the weighted mean δ18O of the different chips of MKR. The respective 2s uncertainty for the five chips are, in order, 0.7, 0.6, 0.4, 0.4 and 0.5 ‰. Each of these chips has a different crystallographic orientation, as can be seen by their location in the Inverse Pole Figure of Figure 2. The data for the other four rutile on this mount, MOZI, RUTNOR, WHQR and WOD, all show similar complexity, with good in-chip, or in-zone, precision and reproducibility, but large variation of weighted mean δ18O VSMOW between chips and zones with different crystallographic orientation. WHQR has a similar δ18O range to MKR. In contrast, the range in δ18O of MOZI, RUTNOR and WOD is >5 ‰.  
 Figure 2. δ18O data for 5 chips of the MKR rutile RM with different crystallographic orientation. The Inverse Pole Figure (IPF) shows the orientation of the five chip surfaces relative to the C axis of rutile.  
Appendix B J.K. P ORTER 237We used Electron Back-scattered Diffraction (EBSD) to measure the crystallographic orientation of regions/zones/twins within the chips of rutile, so that the chip orientation relative to the primary beam could be related to the oxygen isotope ratio bias. We found no relationship between oxygen isotope bias and secondary ion yields, taken as the first cycle count rate on 16O, normalised to the Cs+ primary beam current. This contrasts with the results of Taylor et al (2012) and McNaughton et al (2016) who found, when measuring the U-Pb age of rutile, that +ve secondary ion yield is strongly correlated with rutile crystallographic orientation. Currently we are assessing other possible controls on the oxygen isotope bias, such as rutile surface charge, Cs interaction volume, mineral electronic structure (Carr et al., 2017), and chemical composition. Conclusions CA (δ18O = 8.03 per mil) and MKR (δ18O = 4.04 per mil), are excellent oxygen isotope RM for rutile. RUTNOR (δ18O = 6.2 per mil) may only be useful as a secondary RM, as it contains some alteration patches and a few small 10-30 µm regions with different crystallographic orientation.  WHQR cannot be used as a RM, as the data from this grain separate is scattered and shows no relationship to crystallographic orientation. WOD and MOZI will be excellent RM, when there is conventional oxygen isotope data. Individual chips of rutile that do not contain twins or multiple orientation domains, give excellent precision and internal reproducibility for oxygen isotopes, and this means that the external reproducibility in rutile oxygen isotope data is dominated by any correction for crystallographic orientation. This necessitates that the relationship between δ18O bias and crystallographic orientation is obtained for each analytical session. To do this, RM chips with different known crystallographic orientation, must be measured in each session and matched to the crystallographic orientation of the unknowns. Preliminary EBSD measurements are required to provide a foundation for choosing rutile grains to analyse. Ensuring there are chips with a wide range of crystallographic orientations relative to the incident primary ion beam allows a more accurate examination of the required relationship. In addition, it is necessary to measure a second RM to provide added confidence in any corrections. Using RM that have a wide range of δ18O values is also helpful in checking for any compositional effect on IMF.  References Bonamici C.E., Kozdon R.T. Ushikubo T., Valley J.W., 2014. P ORTER 239B.8. CONFERENCE ABSTRACT G-DETRITAL RUTILE :
A NEW TOOL FOR GOLD EXPLORATION UNDER
COVER
McNaughton, N., Porter, J., Evans, N., McDonald, B., Talavera, C., Doyle, M.
Presented as part of the AGCC Australian Geoscience Council Convention, Adelaide, Aus-
tralia, 14–18 October, 2018
Abstract published in the AGCC 2018 Abstract Volume, Big Issues and Ideas in
Geoscience, pg 120.119 
  
120 
Detrital rutile: a new tool for gold exploration under cover  
Mcnaughton N1, Porter J1,2, Evans N2,1, McDonald B1, Talavera C1, Doyle M3 
1John De Laeter Centre for Isotope Research, Curtin Univ., 2School of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Curtin Univ., 
3AngloGold Ashanti Ltd  
TS5 - 3.1.6 New frontiers in ore system research, Hall E2, October 17, 2018, 3:30 PM - 5:30 PM  
Biography:  
- Isotope geochemist for 40 years with an ore deposit bent;  
- PhD at Uni. Qld, postdoc at Cambridge Uni. prior to academic positions at UWA and Curtin;  
- Published on stable and radiogenic isotopes, crustal evolution, REE -phosphate geochronology, 4D 
evolution of Precambrian terranes;  
- Published on gold (>100 publications), base metals (Ni, Cu, Pb, Zn) and fractionated granites -pegmatites;  
- Currently researching a major industry -governme nt sponsored project on rutile as a very distal footprint to 
hydrothermal gold ores.  
Detrital heavy minerals such as zircon, monazite, xenotime and rutile can be transported >100 km from 
their eroding source rock because they are sufficiently robust to wi thstand physical erosion -transport. Rutile 
can form in a hydrothermal gold ore environment, and importantly, captures a trace element signature that 
can be used to uniquely fingerprint the ore environment. Further, published examples show that rutile in 
the regolith overlying a gold orebody faithfully preserve the trace element signature of the orebody. In 
combination, these features imply detrital rutile grains in regolith and surficial clastic sedimentary cover can 
(1) indicate the presence of gold prospe cts/ores below or upstream from the sampling site, and (2) 
potentially extend the distal footprint of some gold ores to >100 km.  
The utility of detrital rutile grains for gold exploration was assessed in clastic surficial sediments from a 
known Archean gold -mineralised belt in the Yilgarn Craton, but >20 kms from known mineralisation. The 
cover sequence was sampled from drillcore 4, 5 and 7 metres above the Archean basement contact. Heavy 
minerals from each sample were separated, mounted in ep oxy and polished. Mounts were scanned 
automatically using TIMA (Tescan Intergrated Mineral Analyser) to identify TiO2 grains, rutile, anatase and 
brookite were confirmed with EBSD, and a selection of rutiles was analysed in -situ for multiple trace 
elements  using laser ablation ICPMS. A gold fingerprint was found in rutile from the two samples closest to 
basement, with more abundant grains and a stronger “gold” geochemical signature in the sample 4m above 
the basement. 242 J.K. P ORTER244 J.K. P ORTERAPPENDIX C
SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION -
CHAPTER 2C.1. C OMPLEXITIES RELATED TO SAMPLING
As many samples were collected from archived material in museums and university
collections, it is possible that some samples have been mis-indexed and incorrectly
labelled and therefore the database of rutile trace elements may contain inaccuracies
related to ore body or rock origin. Some museum samples, e.g., WA pegmatites, have
a limited description of sample location within the ore system, so differences in chem-
istry between samples from the same deposit may not have a readily apparent ex-
planation. Additionally, variability in rutile geochemistry within ore deposits may
be explained, in-part, by samples being taken at different locations within the miner-
alised zone of a deposit. Some archived samples were missing this information and
textural relationships to mineralisation were lost, particularly in grain mount sam-
ples. Every effort has been made to correctly identify rutile source areas, but where
anomalies in the data suggest a foreign origin, these samples were removed from the
database. Rutile does not form at, nor is it stable under all conditions that favour some
types of mineralisation and, therefore, deposits that do not contain rutile could not be
represented. Certain deposit types are under-represented or missing, such as Cu-Mo
porphyry deposits. As a result, the rutile chemistries in the ore database are biased
towards Archean Au deposit sampling.Appendix C J.K. P ORTER 247
